title: American Dirt
author: Cummins, Jeanine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: From the first page I was riveted, fearful and fascinated both. It made me see the violence in Mexico and South America in a different way, much more From the first page I was riveted, fearful and fascinated both. It made me see the violence in Mexico and South America in a different way, much more intimate. I was afraid, had my heart in my throat as Lydia and her son Luca run for their lives. The migrants, the WALL, attitudes on the USA side, the Cartels, the violence, the corruption....it is all complex but here is a take away for Americans; STOP TAKING DRUGS! Drug consumers are throwing this country away! And how are there so many guns in the hands of the cartels? Who is producing all these guns and making them available to every person who can put on a uniform, legit or not and swagger around with their big guns. I'm raving and I probably am wrong about much, but while driving through Baja there were just random groups of armed teens on the side of quiet roads and drivers had to stop and submit to search of vehicles if the guys felt like it. No way to tell if these guys were legit or not, and considering how much corruption there is does "legit" count for much? I've been on both sides of the opinions on illegals but one thing I notice is that Mexicans (legal or illegal I don't know) work hard and at jobs that are more taxing, say roofing, road construction, cleaning and child care. The other thing I think about is that the land wasn't originally ours. Life is hardly fair but remembering to be compassionate and putting humanity before rigid rules is what seems right to me. Also, watch out for who you befriend. ...more

title: The Other Wes Moore: One Name, Two Fates
author: Moore, Wes
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I liked the concept of the book, that two different Wes Moores grew up a few blocks away from each other in inner city Baltimore; "one grew up to be aI liked the concept of the book, that two different Wes Moores grew up a few blocks away from each other in inner city Baltimore; "one grew up to be a Rhodes Scholar, decorated veteran, White House Fellow, and a business leader, while the other ended up a convicted murderer serving a life sentence" Taken directly from the back cover by the way, here is more from the back cover, "Both grew up fatherless in similar Baltimore neighborhoods and had difficult childhoods, both hung out on street corners with their crews, both ran into trouble with the police." So how come they turned out so different? That is the question that Wes Moore, the author, is trying to answer as he feels his story could have been the other Wes Moore's story and vice versa. He spends quite a bit of time visiting the other Wes Moore in jail and they share and compare their lives. Even though there are many similarities between their lives I feel like there are some significant differences. Wes the author, left Baltimore with his mother and siblings when he was still an adolescent boy. They went to live in the Bronx with his grandparents. Wes's father had lived with his family until he passed away from a sudden illness when Wes was three. Wes's parents and grandparents were all college educated. His grandfather was a Presbyterian minister and his grandmother was a school teacher. They owned their own home in the Bronx. The Bronx wasn't much better than inner city Baltimore but Wes had a great deal of family support. His mother put him in a white school outside of the Bronx which created quite a lot of problems for young Wes as he didn't fit into the neighborhood because of his school and he didn't fit into his school because of his skin color and his neighborhood. Still, it was a different experience than always being in his neighborhood and never experiencing anything different. Also his extended family were close and they visited Jamaica when he was a child (quite a few times I think). When he was getting into trouble his family made the difficult and expensive decision to send him to military school which changed his future in a huge way. He became a leader of men and has been on a straight path ever since from what I understand. The Wes Moore who ended up a convict never left Baltimore, his mother had wanted to go to college but when the Pell grants were stopped she didn't have the money to go. His father was never part of his life. His older brother became a feared drug dealer in the neighborhood and Wes admired him greatly. Wes, in his turn became a drug dealer although never a drug consumer. He had good organizational and leadership skills and the money from dealing and running a crew was a lot of money. He fathered four children with two different women by a very early age, 20? His second woman was a drug addict and he could see how destructive it was to someone he loved. He wanted out of the drug trade so he went through the Job Corp program. He trained as a carpenter and did very, very well. But afterwards, after a year of working minimum wage jobs and trying to support his four children and their mothers and his own mother, eventually the pressure was too much and he fell back into old ways. This was how he came to be part of a robbery with his brother and two other men. This robbery resulted in the death of a policeman. Life in jail was inevitable for both brothers.So, the neighborhood and culture has a huge effect on the children but so does family and education. No question in my mind that both mothers tried their best and loved their children fiercely. I appreciate this book for furthering my education and helping me to understand cultural differences. ...more

title: The Long Exile: A Tale of Inuit Betrayal and Survival in the High Arctic
author: McGrath, Melanie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Have you seen the documentary "Nanook of the North"? This was footage produced by Robert Flaherty in the 1920's. It was meant to show the life of the Have you seen the documentary "Nanook of the North"? This was footage produced by Robert Flaherty in the 1920's. It was meant to show the life of the Inuit but it was, essentially, fiction. While Robert was filming this he had an affair with his lead female Inuit girl. This produced a male child, Josephie Flaherty; a child that Robert Flaherty knew about but never acknowledged, and Robert Flaherty never returned to the Arctic. When Josephie was a man, in 1953, the Canadian government, for reasons complex and unreasonable, decided to move Inuit "volunteers" and their families to the High Arctic. This is not normal Arctic. This is like a massive ice sculpture, with severe winds, crashing ice bergs in the water, very close to no vegetation, and almost no land animals to hunt making it necessary to go on to the very unstable and dangerous sea ice to hunt sea mammals. The people had never lived in such an environment, they were used to the Arctic, not the High Arctic which was a different world entirely. They were severely under equipped in every way: clothing, shelters, stoves, lighting, sleds, dogs, building materials etc. And it was completely dark for 5 or 6 months of the year.They were simply expected to be able to handle this because they were Inuit. There were small children, even babies. The people had been told they could return after a year if they didn't care to stay up there. That didn't happen, they were not allowed to return to their homeland. All suffered, a significant number died. Josephie was one of the people who, with his wife and kids, went to the High Arctic. It is Martha, his six year old who was hunting with her father at that age as he had no other helper or partner to hunt with, who later went south and became an activist for her people. This story is very important; historically, politically, socially and ethically. In my opinion, everyone should read this book. ...more

title: The Island of the Colorblind
author: Sacks, Oliver
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't know that there was such a thing as complete color blindness, just seeing in black and white and shades of grey. This means extreme sun sensiI didn't know that there was such a thing as complete color blindness, just seeing in black and white and shades of grey. This means extreme sun sensitivity but much better sight at night. Night fishing is a popular occupation for achromatopes. But what a situation to have on a South Pacific Island with the sun shining oh so brightly. Bringing sun glasses and sun visors to this population allowed some people to go outside during the day.  I haven't yet mentioned that the Island of the Colorblind is a Pacific atoll called Pingelap. A typhoon in 1776 killed 90% of the population. About 20 survivors were left. Re-population, with in-breeding, commenced. "genetic traits previously rare began to spread" "The first children with the Pingelap eye disease were born in the 1820's, and within a few generations their numbers had increased to more than five percent of the population, roughly what it remains today." The Pingelap eye disease is achromatopsia. "genealogical studies indicate that it was the surviving nahnmwarki (the chief) himself who was the ultimate progenitor of every subsequent carrier."The book covers other atolls, islands and diseases. Guam is one of the islands. What fascinated me about Guam is that an invasive species, a brown tree snake, has eaten all the bird eggs reducing the bird population so greatly that no bird song is heard on the island and the jungles are festooned with spider webs from the huge population of spiders that would normally have been eaten by birds. Snakes and spiders Guam. Not visiting, no. ...more

title: The Clothes on Their Backs
author: Grant, Linda
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The immigrant experience after WWII, here the immigrants are from Hungary and are secular Jews. There are two brothers, one of whom escaped most of thThe immigrant experience after WWII, here the immigrants are from Hungary and are secular Jews. There are two brothers, one of whom escaped most of the experience of the war, the other brother who was not able to leave until after the war. Brother one arrives in England with his wife and they move into an apartment. They have a baby girl and are extremely protective. Basically they never leave the apartment, the building's interior is their world. Their daughter has a wider world as she goes to school. Her education is the paramount importance of her parents. They see education as her ticket to success, as many parents do. The daughter thinks her parents are her only relatives but one day a man shows up at the apartment door and tries to give her chocolate. Her father and the stranger get into a loud argument, the stranger is not welcomed and warned never to come again. No explanation is offered to the daughter. Years pass, history happens. One of the things that happens is that a slum landlord is in the news for his crimes, is prosecuted and goes to jail. It is the man who had come to the door. I'm just telling you the whole story here, better slow down so people can read it for themselves.I thought it was a good story. The characters are stereotypes, but well drawn. I married into a family of Jewish immigrants so I felt like I recognized these characters and I felt great compassion for all of them, not as victims but as human beings going through a life that tries to break them. This world tries to break us all but if you are familiar with immigrants of a particular time and ethnicity, well then the story kind of puts pressure on your heart. I can't really tell you more although I am leaving out a LOT of the story. You will have to read it if you want to know more....more

title: Ghosts from the Nursery: Tracing the Roots of Violence
author: Karr-Morse, Robin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book boldly draws our attention to the infant and the development of the infant brain through the minute interactions between baby and caregiversThis book boldly draws our attention to the infant and the development of the infant brain through the minute interactions between baby and caregivers. What happens in the infant brain if loving interaction is occurring, what happens if it is not. And how is the time of infancy related to the later mental health and behavior of the growing child and adult. Although I think I basically knew most of this I did not know it in such forceful and convincing detail. I wish every pregnant person could be taught this information and every parent should have enough support to be able to provide the best environment for their infant. As I see the news everyday and the daily abuse and murder of babies and small children I think we are just going backwards and I am not sure why although the isolation of COVID did a lot of damage. Since most women will become mothers shouldn't girls be taught infant care and infant brain development? Shouldn't boys be taught as well since they will most likely become fathers? Education and psychology seem very "I" based. When the focus is directed outwards it is towards skills that may or may not be used by an individual in their working environment. Rarely is the education toward parenting and infant development. Parenting classes are most often used too late, after a parent has been found to be doing a poor job, has come under scrutiny by child protective services and so has been ordered to take a parenting class. Rather like the driver's classes that one takes in order to prevent a ticket from being on their record. Too little too late. ...more

title: The Right Stuff
author: Wolfe, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't know what happened to Chuck Yeager. I was six years old but I spent a lot of time in N. Edwards because my grandparents lived out there and oI didn't know what happened to Chuck Yeager. I was six years old but I spent a lot of time in N. Edwards because my grandparents lived out there and owned a restaurant there called The Little Red Barn. I remember hearing the sonic booms and remember the feeling that I was somewhere special with the jets and pilots and all. What happened to Chuck Yeager must have been talked about by the adults around me but I was too young to understand. I can't believe he survived it and kept flying. God bless Chuck Yeager and all the pilots including the astronauts. Kind of through osmosis maybe I took great pride in our Moon Landing and have never forgotten the excitement of that day. Patriotism was built into me early and I think my time in N. Edwards and my grandparents association with the base and the pilots had a lot to do with it. Now that I have a lot of names of pilots from that time I am going to go through the guest book of the restaurant and look for the signatures. And now every time I fly and hear the drawl of the Captain I will be thinking of and thanking Chuck Yeager and his fellow wild boys, all the pilots. God bless America. It's not logic, it's love. This was a great book, I loved reading it. Recommended....more

My first  of this book was critical and dismissive due more to my circumstances than to due consideration.When I read a Farewell to Arms I admired it, thought about it, wrote a considered . This book continues with the same characters but without the war. The war caused injuries and psychological damage but it also provided camaraderie and purpose. This book explores what happens when the war is over, how do people cope? We see our characters coping by drinking, eating and partying without enjoyment. By promiscuity with unloved partners, without considering the feelings and welfare of those partners, and deep longing for those one can't have. title: Juneteenth
author: Ellison, Ralph
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved the writing, it was so painful and so beautiful. Don't let my inability to express my admiration affect your potential opinion of this book. TI loved the writing, it was so painful and so beautiful. Don't let my inability to express my admiration affect your potential opinion of this book. The writing was breathtaking and heartbreaking. But...the author never finished this book. He wrote it over a period of forty years, years that saw great change and social upheaval, but he never finished it, so we don't get resolution. I wanted resolution, I guess I always do, but life keeps moving on and some things don't get resolved. So the story is not complete, it is not resolved. One thing that struck me is that I never learned about Juneteenth! It wasn't taught in school. We had President's day and 4th of July, knew about the emancipation of the slaves of course. But never heard of Juneteenth. That seems like an important day for all Americans, the day we as a country abolished slavery! It is a little more complicated than that, you can read about it on Wiki. Pres Lincoln actually outlawed slavery on Jan 1 1863 but it took awhile for states to comply with the law. Texas was the last state, in the Confederacy, to legally comply and that law was signed on June 19, 1865. Delaware and Kentucky didn't free their slaves until an Amendment to the Constitution abolishing "chattel slavery" on Dec. 6, 1865. The last slaves held in the Continental U.S. were in the Indian Territories and they were freed in 1866. But Juneteenth is the day we celebrate the end of slavery and the emancipation of the slaves, an important day for ALL Americans.Pres Joe Biden just signed the holiday into law and it is celebrated in parts of Mexico as well. ...more

review: Stories by young men incarcerated in the juvenile system. As a reader I was really unhappy with how little help we, as a society, give teens who are cStories by young men incarcerated in the juvenile system. As a reader I was really unhappy with how little help we, as a society, give teens who are committing crime. There is injustice in the justice system with the system going after the weakest, poorest and most marginalized among us. It appears that we want to put as little money into education, early childhood programming and behavioral programs as possible. We prefer to spend the money on incarceration. However, most of these young men had supportive mothers or teachers or someone in their life who was trying to steer them on a right path. The hatred of whites made me sad and fearful, being white myself. The crimes that one young man detailed were in the neighborhood where I am in the process of buying a house. Kind of tied my stomach in knots. I thought these young men were talented, intelligent, good writers and I'd say artistic as well judging by signatures. I also think they chose a lot of their criminal behavior. Well, one of them seemed mentally ill, perhaps he had suffered traumatic brain injury from the abuse he went through. I can't really put myself in any of their shoes but I hope each of them is doing well now, have given up crime and are teaching their children to get along in the world with education, pride in their cultural heritage, compassion and love for all life....more

title: Drive Me Wild: A Western Odyssey
author: Nealson, Christina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, I finished this a week ago and what am I thinking about? Pooka.Let me try to explain why this book wasn't for me. Wife is unhappy with urban sprawSo, I finished this a week ago and what am I thinking about? Pooka.Let me try to explain why this book wasn't for me. Wife is unhappy with urban sprawl in Taos NM where she lives with her fellow writer and backpacker husband, their dog and their Bengal cat. She gets an idea to sell the house and their belongings and move into an RV and travel. Husband seems stunned but agrees. She goes into the woods to talk to Grandmother tree and has a heart to heart, looking for signs. The sun shines down and reveals she is sitting in a giant spiderweb. She takes that as a positive sign. I'd be running saying Grandma said Hell No, scrap the RV plan. They sell their house and most of their stuff. They drive this large RV towing their car. It is a stressful life with the driving, setting up and breaking down camp, figuring out where to park this behemoth every night. 2 adults and 2 animals in an RV doesn't allow for much privacy. They hike separately because they are always together in the RV. Husband starts drinking, moodiness is tainting the free vagabond lifestyle. Dog gets sick and has to be put down. They get another dog, still have the cat Pooka. Husband takes off in the car one night, returns a few days later. They travel some more and wife continues her rambling monologues of signs and portents in nature. Husband doesn't say much but he becomes unwilling to read her writng anymore. So I was reading a book about a couple in a dying marriage. That isn't fun. The reason I am thinking about Pooka is she gets left behind with the dad while mom takes the dog and continues traveling. Pooka is left behind like the less favored child of divorce....more

title: Imperfect Justice: Prosecuting Casey Anthony
author: Ashton, Jeff
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I remember when her verdict was announced. I was in Gainsville with my son who was a recent graduate of Levin School of Law. He told me she was almostI remember when her verdict was announced. I was in Gainsville with my son who was a recent graduate of Levin School of Law. He told me she was almost certainly guilty but she would not be convicted. He was right. But why was he right? That question has remained in my mind for all these years as I would have guessed that she was guilty and would be convicted. I read this book hoping I might get an answer to that question but I didn't. Was it the jury? Was it the circumstantial case? Was it the Prosecution? Was it the Defense? Was it Colonel Mustard with the candlestick in the dining room? What happened that a conviction was not secured?I don't know. The Defense was bombastic and not sticklers for protocol, the Prosecution was on an intellectual and proud high horse, the defendant was cool as a cucumber and didn't look like whatever guilty looks like, and little Caylee was found too late for her body to reveal much about what had happened. Still, I thought for sure the jury would convict her of something besides lying to the police. All the circumstantial evidence was very incriminating. Although the prosecution of Casey did not result in conviction I am sure that ultimately there will be justice. With every effort made to secure truth and justice we now have to let it go and let God and nature take their course to re-balance things. ...more

As soon as Edward decides to make himself a casual test subject of an untested and potentially dangerous substance, I thought, this book is stupid.I don't know the world of medical research but I found the idea appalling and would have thought his colleague would have reported him forthwith. Somebody say something! Mad scientist on the loose!Then being given millions to create a lab and hire researchers on the idea that a new miracle drug could potentially be created, without research to back it up? On the force of somebody's say so? even a smart somebody?? That doesn't really happen, does it? Eventually we end up with scenes from teenage horror movies, silly yet frightening. The book is based on the real theory that the accusing girls in the Salem Witch Trials, that their hallucinations and convulsions were caused by a fungus in the rye which was commonly used for baking bread. title: The Tea Girl of Hummingbird Lane
author: See, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was interesting historically and culturally. This story is about a girl who is a member of the Akha people, an ethnic minority group in the mountaiIt was interesting historically and culturally. This story is about a girl who is a member of the Akha people, an ethnic minority group in the mountains of China. Her mother is the village midwife and healer and wants her daughter to carry on this tradition. But Li-Yan, the daughter, becomes pregnant and the boy is away trying to make money while Li-Yan remains alone. Her mother helps her deliver in secret and Li-Yan leaves her secret baby to be found and delivered to an orphanage. This changes the course of Li-Yan's life. The baby, Yan-Yeh, is given to an American couple and becomes Haley. Li-Yan's village are tea growers and harvesters. When Li-Yan leaves her baby she leaves her with an old and precious cake of tea. This helps Haley eventually find her way back to the area from which she came and to finding both her past and her future.Something about this book reminded me of Jodi Picoult books, maybe the coming of age theme, maybe the teen angst. Also, reading this book during Covid pandemic, this line stood out boldly, "Every pandemic in the history of the world has come from China." That line went off like a mini bomb in my head. Is that even true? Just a brief google seems to support the statement. ...more

title: The Bookman's Wake        (Cliff Janeway, #2)
author: Dunning, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The way the author describes Seattle we have a pretty much full time wicked downpour. But that is not the case. I am sitting here in Seattle, the sun The way the author describes Seattle we have a pretty much full time wicked downpour. But that is not the case. I am sitting here in Seattle, the sun is shining and it is not raining. A lot of the time Seattle rain is more drizzle than full on rain. A small point but it was an irritant to have the weather exaggerated. According to Google, Seattle gets 38 inches over 156 days. Mobile is the city that gets the most rain in the U.S. with 67 inches over 59 days.So, the story, it is a little outdated but there are some outstanding points:1. The story does not dull down, if anything it ramps up and becomes more intense and more puzzling.2. The book information is fascinating. I don't collect books, have given away many with author signatures, don't keep them pristine. I read a lot of them and figure if they have been read then that is the greatest compliment a book can receive. But this book gave me a whole different viewpoint on how to look at books. I particularly was taken with the idea of miniature books, old books and books with art. I'll still read my books and they will reflect that, but my viewpoint has been expanded and I appreciate that....more

title: The Scarlet Letter
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A woman has a baby out of wedlock and is made to wear an A on her clothing, she is made to stand with her infant on the pillory and is reviled and shuA woman has a baby out of wedlock and is made to wear an A on her clothing, she is made to stand with her infant on the pillory and is reviled and shunned. She will not reveal the name of the father who is respected in public life but reviles himself to the point of death. Pitiful that he didn't have the courage to claim the woman he loved and the child that was his. To make matters worse, the woman's husband, who had been missing for about a year and was presumed lost/dead, shows up as she is standing on the pillory with her infant. He becomes obsessed with revenge on the man who took his wife. It changes him for the worse as well. The tale is not just a cautionary tale, it is also critical of the society holds woman to be morally inferior or a witch if she challenges the mores and thoughts of the day.My favorite line of the book is this: "The soul beheld its features in the mirror of the passing moment."...more

review: Very disturbing in some ways, but enjoyable to read nonetheless. I wish I had some manic in me sometimes. I think my favorite part is where she says, "My father and I scream each other down until we are exhausted, completely spent. We stand there panting. "Say," my father says brightly, perking up. "Want to play Yahtzee?" "Sure!" I say. And we sit down to play, laughing and having a wonderful time." That makes me laugh because sometimes it is like that, a huge fight just, poof, is gone.Marya has a great sense of comedic timing. Her conversation with the psych nurse on the eating disorders floor was very funny, and her conversation trying to get her insurance straightened out was a recognizable frustration that many of us can probably relate to.She is fortunate to have so many around her who give her support....more

title: Dune        (Dune, #1)
author: Herbert, Frank
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this 30 years ago and remembered much of it, but 30 years ago I had no idea what jihad was, now I wish I had no idea what jihad was. It is PaulI read this 30 years ago and remembered much of it, but 30 years ago I had no idea what jihad was, now I wish I had no idea what jihad was. It is Paul's night/waking/dream mare? Yes.... I think the world today understands that much better than it did 30 years ago, or maybe it is just me, not sure. In my recall of this book Paul was a much more sympathetic character. Here we see what leadership can do to a person, how the wheel of time turns things, much like the hooks in the worm, pain and all attendant emotions causing the changes that pull us again and again into savagery. Paul was, by genetics and upbringing, a leader, which involves a certain amount of clear-eyed cold heartedness. He wasn't the sympathetic character I recalled from my first reading. 30 years ago my reading was a much more innocent experience; I enjoyed the imagery and adventure. This time a lot more caught at me and I was uncomfortable, it was all too close to home. It was set on Arrakis but it was all too much about human problems. I'm angry about Little Leto. That was unnecessary (in Dune, it may have been necessary for future books in the series). Even though Little Leto is fictional I find myself angry at Frank Herbert for what he did there. Still, putting all the religion and politics aside and my personal grudges aside, it was great adventure with superb imagery. ...more

title: All Quiet on the Western Front
author: Remarque, Erich Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first read this in the 10th grade and it hit me hard. I didn't know much about anything including WWI, I had never heard the details about the frontI first read this in the 10th grade and it hit me hard. I didn't know much about anything including WWI, I had never heard the details about the front, the gas, the conditions. So I wept my way through it and this story has never left me. I wanted to read it again as a senior citizen and see how I felt about it now. Also I read it for banned books week as this book was banned in Nazi Germany. That alone was reason to read it again.I didn't find it anti-German at all, in fact a love of country and countrymen shone through. It is an anti-war book, it does detail the horrors of war at the Western Front in WWI but it acknowledges that the men fighting have no reason to hate each other except that they have been told that the other is their enemy. I found it more simplistic than I remembered it to be, it was a very quick book to read. It is powerful nonetheless. I hope it is still assigned to high school students and that they care....more

author: Mezrich, Ben*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Hard to say why I didn't like this book very much. First, I thought Seymon's reasons for publishing the techniques used, as stated in the "afterword" Hard to say why I didn't like this book very much. First, I thought Seymon's reasons for publishing the techniques used, as stated in the "afterword" didn't ring true. Encouraging people to go to casinos, even to "beat" the casinos, is nonsense. People going to the casinos is the lifeblood of the casinos, most people aren't going to be able to beat the dealer no matter what book or dvd they study. So basically that is just more money in the hands of the casinos. I thought he published the techniques and the book to make money for himself.The story itself is interesting but the conversations seem made up and why wouldn't they be, it's been a long time, who remembers. But my attention kept snagging on it.The gambling techniques themselves didn't seem like cheating, I don't think card counting is cheating either; but I'm not surprised that the casinos saw it differently when they started losing lots of money. I wouldn't expect anything to change; people will go to Vegas etc. and lose, casinos will protect their money. If you win at gambling maybe try to win less ostentatiously and less frequently....more

review: I remember the murder of Daniel Pearl in real time, how shocking and horrifying it was. Each day the news was presenting yet another horrible thing thI remember the murder of Daniel Pearl in real time, how shocking and horrifying it was. Each day the news was presenting yet another horrible thing that happened. I think between 9/11 and the murder of Daniel Pearl, Americans began to understand that they had enemies. Although fast-forward to today and we again don't seem to understand that anymore. We are all turned against each other in a most alarming way.But, to the book, it is an excellent mix of the personal and the religious/political, the past and the time of the event. It is heartbreaking. It also speaks to the horror of our age of internet. Daniel Pearl was kidnapped and murdered on camera specifically so that the video could spread terror among anyone who thinks they could become victims of Jihad such as Americans, Jews, and Christians and many others. And so it could spread feelings of success and bravery among Jihadists. They murdered a good man who was trying to help the world. I thought of him today while listening to the shofar blowing. I was hoping he could hear it and I was wishing that the neshomah of Daniel Pearl should have an aliyah. My heart goes out to innocent and hurting people of all nations and religions, I wish peace and healing on us all....more

review: A good psychological thriller. Expect this; every one of those people are troubled, except maybe Cathy. She is our point of normal on a graph of wildlA good psychological thriller. Expect this; every one of those people are troubled, except maybe Cathy. She is our point of normal on a graph of wildly sick. You know when you observe domestic life through windows of houses that you pass and it looks so nice? Well, Rachel the divorced and alcoholic, riding the train back and forth everyday pretending to go to work, she is not only dreamily observing the passing domestic scenes; one of those houses is her ex-husband's house and she can not leave it alone. She stumbles through her old neighborhood drunk and volatile, she makes many late night phone calls to the ex's house. Not only is this going on, she has also been observing the lives of a couple two doors down and when she sees something that shocks her she goes back to the neighborhood. Because she is an alcoholic everything she says and does is only half remembered, maybe remembered correctly or maybe not. She is entangled in the lives of two unwilling families and what a mess they all are. ----those windows you pass in your everyday commutes? You never know what actually is be going on behind closed doors and open curtains....more

review: I think this book belongs on the historical fiction shelf but it is GOOD historical fiction. It is written as non-fiction but as Farley Mowat himself I think this book belongs on the historical fiction shelf but it is GOOD historical fiction. It is written as non-fiction but as Farley Mowat himself says, I never let the facts get in the way of the truth.Mutt is a great dog and this is a love story about a boy and his dog. I enjoyed almost everything about this and laughed a lot. But, I thought the prank played on the cat lady was downright cruel and Farley Mowat showed a disrespect for women in that chapter. I also was really upset that they moved from Saskatoon and LEFT THE OWLS! The owls were a part of the family and it was cruel to leave them. If the part about Wol flying back 200 miles to his old home with Farley was true, well that was just heartbreaking. (pause to breathe and let this go) Overall it was very enjoyable, laugh out loud funny and probably a lot of fiction mixed in with the truth here....more

review: Well.......There were parts I liked. But it is much too long and goes bizarrely in random directions, like some weird dream. Ralph is a widower and hiWell.......There were parts I liked. But it is much too long and goes bizarrely in random directions, like some weird dream. Ralph is a widower and his social group is a bunch of old guys like himself and an old woman or two. One day Ralph witnesses a lady with a baby stumbling along beat up. He realizes it is his neighbor and friend Helen. When he goes to confront her husband he is just like hey pull up a rock, want a beer? When the husband starts to explain his actions he talks in fearful riddles about a Crimson King. Out of his mind evidently but that's no excuse. Meantime...Ralph hasn't been able to sleep and one night he sees two little bald doctors and he ends up being recruited in a fight against the random in favor of the purposeful. I'm not going to try to explain that to you.I didn't feel like it was tightly plotted, it was longer than it needed to be and if you had a friend or spouse who woke up from a vivid somewhat frightening dream and had to tell you all about, it might be this book....more

title: The Witches: Salem, 1692
author: Schiff, Stacy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have finally finished this tome. It is long, the writing is unwieldy and sometimes incomprehensible. I felt like the author had too much material toI have finally finished this tome. It is long, the writing is unwieldy and sometimes incomprehensible. I felt like the author had too much material to organize properly, or she got bored with writing this book. On the other hand, I learned a lot about the people involved and the sequence of events. My understanding is that we are no different from the people that lived in Salem Village and Andover in 1692. We are vulnerable, petty, jealous, fearful, religious (of whatever denomination), superstitious and capable of accusing others to protect ourselves. We are part of history and people are swept up in the events occurring in their world and tumbled around as their world convulses around them. I am a product of my time in history; Witches, broomsticks? More likely children's revenge and then a sickness of fear as the wave of history grabs the story and pushes, many getting crushed in the process. I could say, based on my moral code and modern beliefs, these people were wrong and these right, but mainly its just people caught in something that was bigger than they were. And of course, no one is all good or all bad. ...more

title: Forty Years in the Wilderness: My Journey to Authentic Living
author: Smith, Yiscah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I know Yiscah, in fact I could count myself among the women in Seattle who had trouble accepting her and certainly feel regret that I didn't just treaI know Yiscah, in fact I could count myself among the women in Seattle who had trouble accepting her and certainly feel regret that I didn't just treat her with kindness and understanding. I did try to be kind but failed in many ways. So a couple of months ago, which is two to three years since I last saw Yiscah, a neighbor of mine told me she had this book and did I want it. I wanted to honor Yiscah by taking her book and reading her story, the least I could do after being a somewhat close minded member of the Seattle community. After reading it I have compassion for Yiscah, I always did actually but was so conflicted and confused because she was also living a religious life and I just didn't know how to reconcile it all. I thank her for sharing her very personal story, her struggles and the pain she went through before her transition surgery. Much of the book is so personal that I don't feel I can comment, but I did feel great compassion also for her wife and particularly her children. But again, that is their life, not mine to comment on. What did upset me is the threat she received, aimed at her children, from a prominent Rabbi in Israel. That is appalling to me. She received a great deal of negative judgment, which while unpleasant, is perhaps somewhat understandable. But threats against her children? Never, no way to justify that, understand it, spin it. That is just wrong.Also, nothing by accident, right? As it turns out there are very good reasons that Yiscah's life intersection with mine was important, and why her book is important to me. I am meant to learn from it, as a gift of learning and understanding that I need. I understand that now....more

title: Born to struggle
author: Hobbs, May
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a nostalgia piece, May Hobbs love for a time and place that no longer exist. She was born in 1938 in Hoxton, a place that another might see asThis is a nostalgia piece, May Hobbs love for a time and place that no longer exist. She was born in 1938 in Hoxton, a place that another might see as a place of poverty, alcohol abuse, and crime, but that May saw as a place of true community, a place and people that were hers. She became a political activist, organizing a union for women who did night cleaning. She was a powerful person and was successful in her fight for poor women, at least in that round of the battle. Urban renewal destroyed Hoxton, scattering its people as they were priced out of their neighborhood and sent on to supposedly improved lives which may not have improved at all in the sense of loss of community and identity. May is completely unapologetic about the drinking and graft as a way of life. It was somewhat eye opening. Also, I loved the "lingo" appendix. Great reading....more

author: Rickett, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Choosing a LitRPG book, a genre I was not familiar with and not particularly interested in, well I went for the shortest one. I got lucky, this book  Choosing a LitRPG book, a genre I was not familiar with and not particularly interested in, well I went for the shortest one. I got lucky, this book is very funny, and even sweet in its way. Grum, the Barbarian ends up in this strange place (modern day earth) and is in search of a quest so he can get back home. He sees a help wanted sign in the window of Tarbean coffee shop, the closest thing to a quest he can find, and before he knows it he is wearing an apron, breaking machines, burning food and alarming customers. The scoring, if that is what you call it, just makes it all funnier, for example: "Dexterity check: (Easy) Critical Failure! Additional Effect Applied" when he is operating the grinding machine, the button gets stuck and he tries to pry it out with a butter knife. Only forty-eight pages, it is funny from beginning to end and is crudely charming....more

review: I'm always a bit surprised by how much life there was in the past, it felt like it could have been about today; same political messes, same religious I'm always a bit surprised by how much life there was in the past, it felt like it could have been about today; same political messes, same religious fueled hatreds, same juggling for power, money, status, sex, same people induced pollution problems, same murder, same terrorism. Everything changes but nothing changes with the passage of time. Do you ever feel like you are caught in the endless loop of a nightmare here on earth? Ugh. Well, on to cheerier thoughts.Peter Ackroyd writes really well; I know I just stated the obvious, but just so you know, the book is well written, fascinating, always interesting, never loses its punch. I could have kept reading it, who else would have a story to tell? Everyone really. If he would have kept telling tales, I would have kept reading them. 1399, I didn't know it would be so interesting....more

title: The Brothers Karamazov
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was with Dostoevsky for so long it felt like we were an old married couple. Some days I loved his writing, laughed at all of his jokes, and admired I was with Dostoevsky for so long it felt like we were an old married couple. Some days I loved his writing, laughed at all of his jokes, and admired his brilliance. Other days I didn't care for him much, thought he was just droning on and on and couldn't he lighten up and enjoy life? I don't know if anybody else thinks some of his writing is laugh out loud funny but I did. His take on doctors; the one who "just can't make it out", the one who sends the patient to a nose specialist and the specialist only takes care of one nostril and has to send him to another specialist for the other nostril. Or Mitya's plan to escape to the U.S., work the land for three years and learn English, then get a wart for disguise and return to Russia where everyone will think he is American! Overall, I am so glad I am done reading this, it is really long and dense, deeply philosophical and religious. I often fell asleep over it. I'm sure I didn't understand everything. Nevertheless, there were times when it was delicious reading, lovely to read out loud if you can find someone who won't moan, "please stop reading!" Great reading experience in some ways, completely exhausting as well. I can happily check this off my reading list but I will never forget it. Amazing writing....more

review: A gene mutation and a child is born intersex. Everyone thinks the child is a girl but when she goes through puberty it becomes evident she is intersexA gene mutation and a child is born intersex. Everyone thinks the child is a girl but when she goes through puberty it becomes evident she is intersex, genetically a boy. I was fascinated and found myself crying, I felt such compassion for this child. A person is not a monster for the way they are born. The surgery to fix the problem is appalling and should never be done on a child or anyone who cannot give knowledgeable consent. Even so, I did not love this book. It was well written but the subject matter was disturbing and extremely sad. We would do well to learn to accept and appreciate those who are different from us....more

title: When Red Is Black        (Inspector Chen Cao #3)
author: Qiu Xiaolong
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Crime is sad, isn't it? Whether on a national scale or a personal scale, how tragic is murder. A political dissident, or someone who might possibly beCrime is sad, isn't it? Whether on a national scale or a personal scale, how tragic is murder. A political dissident, or someone who might possibly be seen as such, is murdered. Sergeant Yu is in charge of the investigation as his boss, Inspector Chen, is on vacation and working on a translation of a big important building proposal that involves overseas funding. Chen ends up with "a little secretary" as part of the perks of doing the translating. Yu is helped with his investigation by his intelligent and hard working wife. Several things were bothersome to me as a reader; the little secretary and all the little perks like a heating unit for Chen's apartment, made me nervous. The turtle that was given as a gift to Yu and his wife also bothered me. Something creepy about these gifts, everything had a price and it was going to come due sooner or later. This is stated quite clearly in the line, "What will come, eventually comes". The book is full of gorgeous poetry, some of the most beautiful I've ever heard, and meaningful Confucianisms. I loved that about it. But it left me with a sense of dread and a weariness that I can't quite explain....more

title: Rebecca
author: du Maurier, Daphne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Absolutely loved it, ticked all the boxes for me. It's a creepy gothic masterpiece of understated horror and brilliant atmosphere. Ah Manderley!RECOMMAbsolutely loved it, ticked all the boxes for me. It's a creepy gothic masterpiece of understated horror and brilliant atmosphere. Ah Manderley!RECOMMENDED if, like me, you like elegant writing that will send shivers up your spine without ever being heavy handed and obvious. What a deft touch this author has.Young woman, lady's companion, accompanying her employer on a vacation to Monte Carlo, finds herself being unexpectedly wooed by a wealthy and sophisticated man twice her age. Two weeks later he asks her to marry him and off she goes on her honeymoon and then to his family home, Manderley. But what is he hiding? Why is he so moody? Why is the housekeeper malicious to the new Mrs. De Winter? How is the very young lady, born into a much lower class, expected to deal with a household of servants and this incredible home which still runs like clockwork to the rules of the former Mrs. De Winter. Speaking of her, exactly what is the truth of what happened to her and can the newly married couple survive the haunting past....more

review: It isn't well-written as it jumps back and forth in time, and is partially written by the author and partially written by writers hired after her deatIt isn't well-written as it jumps back and forth in time, and is partially written by the author and partially written by writers hired after her death to use her notes and finish the book.Michelle McNamara was a true crime writer, blogger, sleuth; the East Area Rapist, Original Nightstalker, Golden State Killer (all names for the same person) was her target. Her question was, the police question was, WHO IS HE? He had been committing crimes since 1968 or so; first as a peeping tom, then a rapist and finally a murderer. All those years, all those victims, all those close calls on getting caught, and this creep just keeps going and no one could figure out who he was. Arrested at age 72, finally caught by DNA. title: The Good Husband
author: Godwin, Gail
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not sugar coating cancer or marriage. Cancer is horrible, marriage is difficult. Some cancers are incurable and take effect quite quickly, some marriaNot sugar coating cancer or marriage. Cancer is horrible, marriage is difficult. Some cancers are incurable and take effect quite quickly, some marriages are mysterious while being beautiful nonetheless. Love is a crazy force, much talked about and little understood. We think we can control our feelings but we can't, we can only, hopefully, control our actions. We think if we do all the right things; eating correctly, exercising, get regular checkups, that we can control our health. We can't, we maybe can assist the body in remaining healthy but outcomes vary. This book is quiet, almost boring, but it leaves lasting pictures in the mind. A young man mopping the kitchen floor in the apartment of a woman he barely knows. A middle-aged, sharp tongued, bad-breathed woman pretending to be asleep with slitted eyes of sharp perception and keen mind watching and understanding. A youngish married woman sitting on a bus next to the man she is in in love with, touching hands and experiencing such heartbreak that the reader experiences it too. There are so many scenes stored in my mind from this book. It is worth reading....more

review: I loved the premise and had high hopes but eventually found myself bored with Basta's threats, Capricorn's colorless eyes and the whole bad guys who nI loved the premise and had high hopes but eventually found myself bored with Basta's threats, Capricorn's colorless eyes and the whole bad guys who never actually do anything very bad scenario, which was good that it was devoid of real violence, but why not just leave out all the repeated threats and knife brandishing once you have gotten the point across that these are bad guys? Meggie and her Dad live alone, Meggie is 12 and her mother disappeared 9 years ago. Meggie is happy with her life but one night a stranger (to Meggie) shows up, his name is Dustfinger and his appearance starts a series of events which will change Meggie's life significantly. It is an adventure story and a growing up story as Meggie discovers more about her father, mother and her own skills. Terrible what the author decided to do to Meggie's mother, I disliked that a lot. Loved the Arab boy Farid and the biting little Marten. The adults were pretty boring, both the bad ones and the good ones, which I guess makes sense for a kid centered book. Great take on faeries, both the vain Tinkerbell, and the blue faeries. Overall it was a good although I disliked the artwork with which my copy of the book was decorated....more

title: A Wall of White: The True Story of Heroism and Survival in the Face of a Deadly Avalanche
author: Woodlief, Jennifer
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A fearsome natural disaster. A huge avalanche falls at a California ski resort burying eight people, one of whom survives five days under the snow. I A fearsome natural disaster. A huge avalanche falls at a California ski resort burying eight people, one of whom survives five days under the snow. I had no idea that bombs, cannons and huge guns are used, near daily during ski season, to cause small avalanches in order to prevent huge ones. Like we are at war against the mountains and elements. I don't like the idea of it, but I can see why it is done, to prevent more disasters like this one from happening.The mountains and weather did their own things anyway, blizzarding for days and then a huge crushing, resort and life destroying, avalanche. It was a search and rescue dog who alerted on the survivor. I wish the rescuers had dug her out at that time but they were worried about another avalanche and the loss of more life and they couldn't be sure the dog had alerted on a live person, it seemed unlikely. They dug her out 71 hours later when the dog went straight back to her location.The reason this book gets a 3 star is that the writing seemed plodding and disjointed to me. I did feel that she cared deeply about what had happened and tried to honor each person who was a victim, family of victim, staff at the resort and rescuer. ...more

title: Gloria
author: Maillard, Keith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Loved the atmosphere, the exquisite rendition of the 1950's. Everything was about to change drastically, but hadn't yet. Gloria is a very smart girl bLoved the atmosphere, the exquisite rendition of the 1950's. Everything was about to change drastically, but hadn't yet. Gloria is a very smart girl but her personality is a construct created after brutal mistreatment at boarding school. She has a "secret watcher" who tells her what to do and say in stressful situations. She wears her beautiful clothes and make up to create illusion. She is very successful in many ways. The last year of college and the summer after she graduates from college are very difficult times for her. She betrays the young man who loves her, she puts herself in danger repeatedly, she fails to confide in her parents when doing so would have made sense. Her inner world is dreamy and confusing, it is hard to know who is real and who is made up to protect Gloria's fragile personality. She has to decide if she is going to take the easy route of marriage to a rich suitor or if she is going to fulfill her academic goals by going to Columbia for post graduate work. My favorite character was her thesis professor, I loved what he had to say about disguises. I was also able to relax when Gloria was with him as he was a safe person and his mind matched hers so well. See, I spent a lot of time worrying about Gloria. When she finally gets the courage to defeat Mr. Dougherty, her method of doing so and the link to the poetry; well that was pretty magnificent. It took me a long time to read this book, I was often upset by Gloria's decisions or something that happened to her and I would have to put the book down so I could relax away from Gloria. The author succeeds in making Gloria more than a character in a book; whatever the reader's personality, the places of likeness between reader and character make Gloria live in her reader....more

title: Gloria
author: Young, Kerry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Overall, an interesting historical novel, although I was left feeling a little dissatisfied. We skimmed the surface of Jamaican history, child sexual Overall, an interesting historical novel, although I was left feeling a little dissatisfied. We skimmed the surface of Jamaican history, child sexual abuse, prostitution, poverty, plantation farming, rural life in Jamaica, life in Kingston, inequality between the sexes, education, religion, homosexuality, love, gambling, money lending, politics, Independence ...but we never settled and got into the nitty gritty of anything. At least it felt that way to me. It was well-written, quick to read....we just never stopped and really dug deep, there wasn't time as we were covering most of a woman's lifetime. It lacked emotional intensity, even the most emotionally wrenching scenes didn't come off the page and make me feel them, I'm not sure why as the writing was confident, mature, and competent. ...more

title: Oryx and Crake        (MaddAddam, #1)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A man with too much brain and too little conscience causes a apocalyptic plague after creating a gentle race of "superior" beings to take humanity's pA man with too much brain and too little conscience causes a apocalyptic plague after creating a gentle race of "superior" beings to take humanity's place. It all starts with genetic manipulation when the genius and his dumber friend Jimmy are friends in school. Gene manipulation is a way of life by this time in history, it is now actually, but even more so in MA's envisioned future. Crake the genius envisions the future, Oryx takes care of the gentle race being raised to take humanity's place. This book is weird, are you getting that? Some of it hits pretty close to home such as the genetically modified food and the possible lengths that may be gone to to provide cheap food for massive populations. Also the pills, all those pills. How many pills do you take before you go to sleep? You trust the manufacturers, right? Should you? And how about the beauty industry? Yikes. Well, our Jimmy writes the ad jingles, the ad hooks that bring the people to purchase. Oryx gives out drug samples. Crake is the game Grandmaster. Do Oryx and Crake believe in what they are doing? What is Jimmy's role in the post apocalyptic world and how long will he survive it?...more

title: Blindspot: A Novel
author: Kamensky, Jane
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This could have been a classy book of historical fiction but for some reason the authors decided to make it a bawdy romance going so far as to name a This could have been a classy book of historical fiction but for some reason the authors decided to make it a bawdy romance going so far as to name a horse "muck" so they could make a rhyme with the word "fuck". Much of this book is serious and worth consideration: slavery in the 1760's colonies, the slave trade, the plantations and all the money to be made, the call for freedom from taxation by the British while subjugating the people bought in Africa, the proper behavior for women in the 1760's and their subjugation to men. So we have a fine historical novel, well written and interesting. But then we add in a murder mystery, which while based on a true case, felt very much tacked in, rather than part of a seamless story. And worse, we add in sex and more sex; it isn't even done in a romantic way, it is done in an aren't we naughty, sniggering way. It was also quite long and had an ending that I didn't like....more

title: Escape from Camp 14: One Man's Remarkable Odyssey from North Korea to Freedom in the West
author: Harden, Blaine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think the world expected Kim Jong Un to fail but so far he seems to be made of the same material as his father and grandfather. Which is bad news foI think the world expected Kim Jong Un to fail but so far he seems to be made of the same material as his father and grandfather. Which is bad news for North Korea, and the world.This book is about a very unlikely and fortunate escape from one of North Korea 's notorious political prisons. Shin was born into this nightmare world; a place without love, loyalty or respect for human life. His life was trying to get enough to eat and snitching on others to earn favor from teachers and guards.Shin did escape and survive. Despite PTSD and severe readjustment problems he has become a well known speaker, author and human rights activist. In 2015 he changed quite a bit of his story and, I think, damaged his credibility. Still, while the details of his story may be fabricated, North Korea is not. The book should be used as a stepping stone to help the reader become interested in North Korea and to pursue further studies and activism....more

title: War and Peace
author: Tolstoy, Leo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is really a book of philosophy, a quest to understand history and the underlying forces that cause wars, revolutions and migrations of vast numbeThis is really a book of philosophy, a quest to understand history and the underlying forces that cause wars, revolutions and migrations of vast numbers of people. The majority of the book is written in story form; the setting is Russia, the time is the early 1800's, the event is the War of 1812, the historic personalities are Napoleon and Emperor Alexander (and many others associated with the government, royalty in Russia and armed forces in Russia and the French Forces), and the story personalities are the Rostov family and their relations and friends in Russian Society. The story is written on a level that I think most readers can comprehend, and although long it is never particularly difficult reading, it is often enjoyable and always interesting. I wish he had written about every war as I got a very clear picture of the sequence of events in the War of 1812 and I'd love to hear what he would have to say about other events in history. Tolstoy is a master writer with a wicked sense of humor, a sharp tongue, an eye that sees much, and an intellect so abundant that it must have burdened him at times. The only part I really had trouble with was the epilogue. It almost entirely consists of his ideas about free will and cause and effect. Captivating ideas but I had trouble grasping it all, most of it sank like sand to the bottom of my brain, too heavy to comprehend. ...more

Poor farm kids from Mali looking for work, promised jobs in the cacao fields, find out they won't get paid and won't get to go home. The conditions are brutal, there is no respite, your family has no idea where you might be. Runaways are caught and beaten badly, let that be a lesson to the others. They work with pesticides with no gloves or breathing protection. They are given a minimum of food to eat. This isn't a job working in the cacao fields, this is out and out slavery. If you live through it then maybe you will be a boss in your turn, beating kids and sleeping in a house rather than a locked shed with the other kids.Well-written and damning, very very sad....more

review: First thoughts: I didn't understand it. It had a dreamlike quality, a lack of logic and substance. I tried, but I got nothing out of it. 2nd thoughts:First thoughts: I didn't understand it. It had a dreamlike quality, a lack of logic and substance. I tried, but I got nothing out of it. 2nd thoughts: I need to clarify that what I didn't understand is how a person (Esther) could have so little sense of self- preservation, how she could willingly sacrifice herself and take the blame as well. I was puzzled at first thinking I missed something crucial, but I didn't, I just needed time to process this woman's utter and complete destruction, which she agrees to in fatalistic fashion. I am left feeling angry and appalled. I could see a continuation of this book being that Lajos, at death's door, pays another visit to saint Esther and gets her this time to agree to trade souls with him so he won't go to hell, she will. Men committing incest and wife-beating, men giving away children that are inEvery man in this book seemed evil until we are near the end of the book. Men committing incest and wife-beating, men giving away children that are inconvenient, men refusing to work, men lying, stealing, cheating, beating, jailing, killing. Black, white, whatever; most of the men are immature and tyrannical at best and some are worse. The women are the substantial characters of strength and hope in this story of race, gender and identity. She writes some strong women. She doesn't seem to have much in the way of good to say about white people (do I need her to?), she isn't necessarily hateful, she just dismisses them as either trouble or not worth thinking about. She is also, evidently, antisemitic. Well, that is her business I suppose. This book was required reading in my 17 year old daughter's Women's Studies course. That is my business....more

The plot was somewhat transparent, the character's actions were unrealistic, the emotions laughable -- and still I enjoyed it. Partly it was just short, fictional and a quick read but it was also to the point, missing all the red herrings and excess verbiage. title: The Education of Little Tree
author: Carter, Forrest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a re-read for me. When I read it back in the early 1990's I would have rated it a 5 stars, I loved it and fully believed it was an autobiograpThis is a re-read for me. When I read it back in the early 1990's I would have rated it a 5 stars, I loved it and fully believed it was an autobiography. After all the facts came out about who the author actually was and what he had done in his life, my feelings about the book changed. This time around I read a juvenile fantasy, an obvious fiction. I still can't reconcile the good heart of this book with the author.Little Tree is orphaned as a young child, 5 years old I think, and is taken in by his Cherokee grand-parents. They live in the Appalachian mountains, run a whiskey still, and read Shakespeare by lamplight; and it is all ridiculously beautiful, meaningful and full of insight and humor. How did a man who formed his own KKK and participated in lynchings, a man who fought against the Civil Rights movement; how did that man write this book? Change of heart? I don't think so, he pretended to everyone that it was autobiographical until the truth came to light. It still is a good book but no way could I take the pleasure in it that I had the first time I read it. Evidently his compassion and admiration of the Native Americans was true as was his hatred of government and politicians....more

If you look at the story in the  I thought the book had merit in the writing. It was rather mesmerizing with dread, indolence, nature, lies and love. If you look at the story in the plain light of day, yeah, it is ugly. But half close your eyes; smell the fruit, feel the sun, hear the wind; rather hypnotic. It seems to me that the author wants to explore social injustices and the psychology of victims and she chose two women; one white, privileged, hard-working, bereaved, divorced, emotionally needy and sick with cancer; one black, young, orphaned by murder, her body sold many times from childhood onward, mentally unstable, poor, in a strange land with no one except a pimp to call friend even as she rejects a wealthy white suitor. She sets these women up to share a house, the young black woman caring for the older sick white woman. I wouldn't dismiss this author's book, it was interesting, thought-provoking....more

title: 12,000 Miles in the Nick of Time: A Semi-Dysfunctional Family Circumnavigates the Globe

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This family takes a lot of trips with the education of their children in mind. Back in their pre-children days this couple travels through Thailand, CThis family takes a lot of trips with the education of their children in mind. Back in their pre-children days this couple travels through Thailand, Cambodia, Tibet, India, the Middle East and Europe. Now they have three kids ages 16, 12 and 9 and decide to recreate the journey with the kids. This book follows the family on this new adventure; the good, the bad, and the ridiculous. I like this way of educating children. I took my kids a lot of places, although never this ambitious. I have a lot of admiration for them in this ambition, although a niggling voice was saying, another lost Jew wandering through India looking for his spiritual home, or in this case, his family's home. The Middle East part of the trip kind of brings up that one is born and belongs to the people and location of his birth. That speech by the old dignified Palestinian Christian was really pointed. I can't imagine how embarrassing it must have been to listen to that in person. Unfortunately, in Israel he doesn't feel one with his own people, he finds reason to criticize, with some poignancy. He wants to be a Humanist, a member of the world, but the world wants to tell you everyone belongs somewhere and you have to have enough awareness to know where you do and don't belong....more

title: Rocks Off: 50 Tracks That Tell the Story of the Rolling Stones
author: Janovitz, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fascinating, this book tells the story of The Rolling Stones using their music as the timeline.I had no idea that originally the band had been a bluesFascinating, this book tells the story of The Rolling Stones using their music as the timeline.I had no idea that originally the band had been a blues band and I really loved most of those early tracks. I'd never heard them before. I was not particularly a Stones fan so I never followed them closely, but this was enlightening, both musically and historically. Well, I say I wasn't particularly a Stones fan, that doesn't mean I didn't recognize all of their popular tunes. They have been a soundtrack to my life whether I call myself a fan or not.I read this book more like a research project than a page turning book. I listened to nearly every song mentioned, I watched Gimme Shelter. I could have done more of course, but I tried to give the book and The Stones my full interest and attention.What is so fascinating of course is Mick Jagger. A mesmerizing individual. Learning about the rest of the band and watching many live performances was great, but that camera was loving Mick, you almost never see the other musicians, and if you do it is almost always their faces, especially Keith and Charlie, not the playing of the instruments. I find that unusual but there was a strong interest in the band members I suppose.The book gives a lot of technical musical /interpretation and a lot of details of their recording sessions. The writer is a musician himself and a Stones fan so he works hard to do the band justice here. This book has nudged me closer to being a fan, I really enjoyed the musical tour.A week later: I can't get The Stones out of my head, listening to them all the time. Yeah, I know, coming a bit late to fandom, but here I am, add me to the rank of fans please....more

review: I read this book because my mother gave it to me, in 1991. My only excuse for taking so long to read it is that I thought I had read it already, but nI read this book because my mother gave it to me, in 1991. My only excuse for taking so long to read it is that I thought I had read it already, but nooo, my mother gave me two Erma Bombeck books. The earlier one was from when Erma was raising her young children.This book was vaguely amusing at times. They are empty nesters when she writes this, and then one son decides to return home while he goes back to school. As an almost empty nester I could relate to some of her feelings and stories. So there is their reaction to that announcement, and their reaction to taking care of the pet snake, and their interactions with their three adult children and the memories they share. My feeling here was that she was trying too hard, the material was not actually very funny so she had to stretch, twist and bend it to make potentially funny to her readers; for the most part it didn't work, at least for me....more

title: Grain Brain: The Surprising Truth about Wheat, Carbs, and Sugar--Your Brain's Silent Killers
author: Perlmutter, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I bought this book about three years ago and put it on a shelf after I read the first paragraph. What he said was that back when our grandparents and I bought this book about three years ago and put it on a shelf after I read the first paragraph. What he said was that back when our grandparents and great grandparents were growing up, if you asked what people died of they would say old age or a specific disease like cholera or tuberculosis, but what you wouldn't hear is heart disease, diabetes, cancer or dementia. I still can't understand why he would say that let alone start his book with that statement. Plenty of diseases in the past including all of the above and many, many more besides. Diabetes has been known about for thousands of years, same with cancer, Egyptian mummies showed signs of cardiovascular disease. So, his statement put me off and I didn't read it until now. I'm an older woman and had grandparents die of cancer. I won't tell you about all the rest of the family medical history but I'm glad I live now, there was plenty of disease, parasites and dementia in the past. So, basically, according to this book, to protect your health, especially your brain, Dr. Perlmutter (and a lot of other people) think a person should go gluten, sugar, dairy and grain free. Actually Dr. Perlmutter is not 100% against dairy but he is against processed foods including processed meats. It is Paleo that is against dairy. So......I'm starving! Yes, I read the book, yes I went gluten free again, yes I have tried to follow the rules, although I am eating potatoes and yams which he doesn't think a person should eat.See I also have the blood work which shows which foods I am sensitive to like sunflower (the oil is in a LOT of processed foods), brewer's yeast and eggs. Eggs!! Ok in Dr. Perlmutter's book he really talks up eggs, loves them, they compromise a large part of his diet. But they are a no no in my own personal pantheon of forbidden foods. Between this book and my own list of reactive foods, well like I said, I am a hungry mungry. I'm not even doing all that well at it, I have to eat too much dairy to make up the lack of carbs. I'm sick of chicken, steak is nice but there are only so many salads with with steak, chicken or salmon that I can enjoy. Why can't I just live on Lay's and coffee with milk? There is my ideal diet. Oh, and pizza, yeah pizza for sure. Maybe some cookies. I'm so hungry and DON'T offer me a handful of walnuts or a dark leafy green salad, cause I'm CRANKY from this diet!...more

review: A tale of warning: beware sudden wealth and both the whims and finality of fate. A indigene couple and their baby son are happy until the morning thatA tale of warning: beware sudden wealth and both the whims and finality of fate. title: Heaven and Hell: My Life in The Eagles, 1974-2001
author: Felder, Don
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Just on general principles, not only regarding the Eagles, I am disgusted at the excesses of alcohol, drugs and sex and the wanton destruction of hoteJust on general principles, not only regarding the Eagles, I am disgusted at the excesses of alcohol, drugs and sex and the wanton destruction of hotel rooms by band members, and the cult like worship of the fans. And it looks like the music industry moguls wring the artists for every penny they might possibly be worth. Altogether an ugly business when it should be an industry of happiness. Music improves life, it improves mood, it gets people moving and having fun. So why is the process of creating music, performing music and recording music accompanied by gross excesses and huge rip offs? I don't know, but it was unpleasant reading. Don Felder was a guitar player with the Eagles and this is his autobiography. He isn't a hateful character but he isn't a sympathetic character either, to me. He seems to be a wants his cake and wants to eat it too sort of character. I really liked his parents and his wife, though. I didn't like the band, as he describes them. I've never actually been much of an Eagles fan. My favorite Eagles songs are Hotel California, which Don wrote the music for, and Peaceful Easy Feeling, and I imagine I know all the other famous ones, soaked up with the California sun of my youth. But my musical preferences are less melodic and controlled. I read the book while listening to the Stray Cats, particularly their performance at Montreux in 1981. I listened to a couple of Eagles performances and enjoyed watching Don Felder and Joe Walsh (who seemed to want to step off his little assigned spot on the stage and start rocking out), but the performances were just too slick for my taste, I got bored quickly.But this  is supposed to be about the book, not the music. The book was too long, there is a bit of whining and lot of name dropping, episodes of self-pity; nevertheless, it was interesting and I'm glad I had the chance to read it....more
