title: The Old Manor House
author: Smith, Charlotte Turner
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is a gruelingly long book at 533 pages of small print, and language that is very wordy and ornate. It was published in 1793, and it is a marvel reaIt is a gruelingly long book at 533 pages of small print, and language that is very wordy and ornate. It was published in 1793, and it is a marvel really, both as social commentary and a demonstration of the manners and speech patterns of yesteryear. I loved saying these long and complex sentences aloud, somewhat to the distress of my family, although the cat didn't mind, thank you. I thought the author was very droll and amusing. She pokes fun at the social posturing of the well born and wealthy, she sympathizes with the poor, she criticizes debtor's prison, she lays out the dangers for young people of leisure with gambling and excesses, she talks about the choices for younger sons which were mainly the clergy or the military, business was deemed vulgar. But mainly this book is about marrying for love or advantage. Orlando Somerive is a second son in love with an orphan niece of a domestic in the Manor House of his great Aunt. This great Aunt is very wealthy but estranged from her family as cousins married down. She is the last of three unmarried sisters and is planning to leave her money and properties outside the family. But she develops a love for Orlando who is the only welcome family member invited to the Manor House. Orlando is playing a dangerous game however, making nice to his Aunt while sneaking to see his love Monimia who is locked into a turret much of the time!There is a lot of family drama back at the Somerive family home; oldest son is a dissolute gambler, oldest daughter refuses an advantageous marriage and marries instead the nephew of her suitor, running away in order to do so. Father is sick, mother is heartbroken, the family wants for money, what is going to happen? There is a lot of hand wringing and much crying.Back at the Manor House there is a lot of hand wringing and much crying as Orlando and Minimia try find a way to a future where they can marry, or at least see each other without sneaking through the house in the dead of night.Orlando makes the decision to join the military so he will have a respectable position and a commission. Contrary to what he had been led to believe, he is sent to America. I think it is evident that the author didn't know nearly as much about America as she did about England. This part of the book reads somewhat like boy's adventure story complete with tomahawk wielding Indians who capture and keep prisoner our Orlando. Although she criticizes the slave trade, she has a pretty unmitigated racial prejudice against the Native Americans. The one nice thing she says about a Native American warrior is nice out one side of her mouth, and then contains a racial insult out the other, "The secret sympathy between generous minds seems to exist throughout the whole humankind; for this young warrior became soon as much attached to Orlando as his nature allowed him to be to anybody;...." My guess is that she was sympathetic to black people because she knew black people in England, but I would think she had only read about Native Americans and had no experience of them herself. Orlando is a sympathetic character with good manners, a kind heart and a strong moral sense. Why he turns into a puling, sneaky child when he meets back with Monimia is a mystery to me. But I get ahead of myself. Orlando is finally returned to America, in rags and penniless. He gets home, and, there is no home! His great Aunt is dead and all his family is missing. Strangers are living in the Manor House as well as in his family home. And people are living high on the money he is almost certain his Great Aunt left for him. The rest of the story is taken up with Orlando's Quest for his Monimia, his family and his inheritance. And his maturity. Expect that it will all work out....more

review: I want to walk it, I need healing, I am bereaved, living off medicines, habits, the support of other people, my blood pressure cuff, my CPap machine. I want to walk it, I need healing, I am bereaved, living off medicines, habits, the support of other people, my blood pressure cuff, my CPap machine. I understand Cheryl's need to do this, herself, to carry that pack herself, to do the hike herself. Let the pain of the trail heal the pain of bereavement. I've done crazy things before, what if I just tossed the medical stuff, packed a pack and started walking?A lot of people were critical of her unpreparedness (her pack weight, her lack of physical training for the trip) and her self-destructive behaviors. I didn't feel critical of her. It was her journey, emotionally and physically, her choices, her feelings, her mistakes, her healing. She is sharing with the reader. Every person on their journey through this world makes mistakes, acts irrationally, carries too much weight and is unprepared. I wouldn't make the same choices as Cheryl; I wouldn't walk it alone, I would attempt to physically train, I would do some day trips, week trips, you know to see how things went. But I would still have to make some decisions that went against conventional wisdom in order to try this. Is never taking chances better? Is it better to live chained to your fears, sorrows and helplessness? What if the trail kills you? Well, something is going to kill you eventually anyway. I don't want to fall off a mountain or get mauled by a bear; but I also don't want to get in a car crash or die of a life of sedentary excess. We all make choices and the best considered choices can have unintended negative consequences, and the rashest and most ill considered of choices may have a positive outcome. The most difficult part of the book for me was nothing to do with the trail, her mother's illness and death, her family troubles, her infidelities, her drug use; it was the shooting of the horse Lady. That shocked and hurt me in a way that the rest of her story never even touched. My favorite part of the book was when Cheryl hitches a ride with Spider, Lou, Dave and the dog Stevie Ray. I love what Cheryl says about Stevie Ray Vaughan's music, in particular Love Struck Baby, Pride and Joy, and Texas Flood. I have read that section at least half a dozen times. Got the pages about Stevie Ray Vaughan bookmarked, page 184/185. I also live the truth of Lou's words, my heart goes out to her....more

review: Catherine De Medici is one scary woman. Xavier Cheney, pirate, son of a nobleman and a courtesan, is hired by the Dark Queen (as she is known) to kidnCatherine De Medici is one scary woman. Xavier Cheney, pirate, son of a nobleman and a courtesan, is hired by the Dark Queen (as she is known) to kidnap a young girl with arcane knowledge and special powers. Before Xavier can get a grip on this situation and do the job, he is caught up in a storm and washes up on Fair Isle, the Island of Witches, on which the said young girl lives. Xavier is in no shape to kidnap anyone, he has a badly broken arm and nearly drowned. His nurse is an English woman named Jane Danvers. Big bad Xavier falls hopelessly in love and Jane falls in love with him. Nice, but wasn't he supposed to be kidnapping young Meg? He doesn't want to kidnap her. His half sisters are on the Island and accept him, he is in love with Jane, he is even friends with Meg. But, oh no, here comes a blabber mouth brother in law who knows Xavier was hired by the Dark Queen and he tells all, thereby cutting the trust between Xavier and his sisters, Jane and Meg. Xavier is very sad and goes off to drink with his buddies, but he decides not to run away, he is going to trick the Dark Queen and win back Jane and the trust of his sisters and Meg. Off he goes, back to France, to attempt to trick the Queen. He finds Jane and is having some success with her. But will he be able to trick the old Queen? Will Meg be able to avoid her dark fate? Will Xavier ever have the family he craves?...more

title: The King of Lies
author: Hart, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ten wasted years! Jackson, or Worker as he is commonly called, was in love with Vanessa from the time he was 12 or 13 years old. But he carries a guilTen wasted years! Jackson, or Worker as he is commonly called, was in love with Vanessa from the time he was 12 or 13 years old. But he carries a guilt that he should have gotten off his chest years ago, and this guilt causes him to marry the woman his father picks for him and to just occasionally visit, in an intimate way, the woman he loves. How stupid! And not only that, he is really cruel with his words sometimes and he is often drunk! He is also a lawyer because his father wanted him to be. Under his father's thumb. Under his society wife's thumb.Jackson's father is murdered after an "accident" that killed his mother. No, Jackson is not guilty of murder, stupidity may be another matter. But Jackson thinks his sister Jean might be guilty and is desperate to protect her. Jean's girlfriend Alex hates Jackson and sends him away whenever he tries to talk to Jean. Well Alex is a weird one, but is she a bad one? Are you keeping track of this? Jackson has no backbone, Jean is suicidal, Alex is weird, Vanessa loves Jackson, Jackson's father is murdered, Jackson's wife wants more, more, more.....and the police think Jackson murdered his father. Oh what a tangled web we weave when first we practice to deceive! I enjoyed reading the story but I was really done with all the characters by the time I was in the final stretch and didn't need pages of explanation and wrapping up at the end....more

She lives through six years of hellish grief and then he shows back up, but only for a mission, and he is undercover as Noah Blake. He is sleeping with his wife again very soon, but he denies being her husband. So he is lying and she knows the truth and they keep having sex, and there is a lot of pain and drama, and sex. title: The Survivors Club
author: Gardner, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Survivors in the Survivors Club are three women who were the victims of rape by the same man. It points out how devastating rape really is. Rape dThe Survivors in the Survivors Club are three women who were the victims of rape by the same man. It points out how devastating rape really is. Rape doesn't get a lot of acknowledgment as the horrifying crime that it really is. There are prevalent attitudes in society that a woman "asked for it" or she put herself in a compromising position by the party she attended or the liquor she drank or the boy she want out with or the clothes she wore. I've heard the attitude that it is only the "feminists" who are making a big deal of rape and that a lot of it is intended as entrapment of men and boys. I also think that porn promotes the idea that women want to be forced, and if they complain about it afterward it isn't because they didn't like it at the time. Rape is also a very under reported crime as it is humiliating to report it and to go through whatever questioning and proof will be needed. I don't know if it is just our religious training or what it is, but we all, men and women, tend to blame ourselves for anything bad that happens to us. When a woman blames herself for her own rape and she is ostracized or treated as a liar or complainer; that is a pretty devastating combination. So this book is murder mystery "entertainment" with a solid dose of what it means to be a rape victim. And what happens if the person who is accused turns out to be the wrong person. The author kind of turns the whole situation around and looks at it from different angles. I thought it was unrealistic in some ways but that that didn't matter as the book was a stage setting in which to look at the serious problem of rape....more

title: Doctor Zhivago
author: Pasternak, Boris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought it would never end. The writing is beautiful but there is just too much of it. I enjoyed the descriptions of the Russian land. I was very inI thought it would never end. The writing is beautiful but there is just too much of it. I enjoyed the descriptions of the Russian land. I was very interested in what he had to say about the Russian Revolution. At first, and I mean the first third of the book, I couldn't keep track of the characters. There is a character guide but because I couldn't pronounce the Russian names, and all of the names had many variations, I was constantly flipping back to that character guide.Once I understood who was who, for the most part, I found myself intensely disliking Dr. Zhivago. The cover of this book calls it a "love story for all time". Really?? Which woman would that be? His legal wife Tonia? His married mistress Lara? His common law wife Marina? He not only cheated on his trusting and loving wife, he eventually deserted all three of these women, betraying all in spectacular fashion. And his kids? All I can think is, Love is as Love does. Dr. Zhivago was more interested in writing than in his children and the women who loved him. But Dr. Zhivago was also a broken man after his experience with the Partisans and maybe he could no longer be held accountable for his actions. Russia was ill with lies and a catastrophic collapse of society. I thought it was false as a love story, and the philosophical musings left me cold. His political insights were brilliant, scary, full of what I perceived to be truth. For incredible descriptions of Russian countryside, and an understanding of war and the Russian Revolution that will slam you in the head it is so vivid and profound, for those things the book is worth reading.It is hard to rate this book as it was so difficult to read and I looked forward with eager anticipation to being done with it. But now that I am finished with it, now I want to think about it and flip through and re-read and contemplate at leisure. 1 1/2 stars for reading experience, 5 stars for teaching me and making me think....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Quite a good mystery, beautifully written atmosphere.Twenty years ago 16 year old Ellie Duncan was found drowned in the river. A piece of paper found Quite a good mystery, beautifully written atmosphere.Twenty years ago 16 year old Ellie Duncan was found drowned in the river. A piece of paper found in her possession had the name Falk written on it. Aaron Falk was a school friend of hers, suspicion immediately falls on him because of that piece of paper. He and his father suffer so much harrassment that they eventually leave all behind and move to Melbourne. At the time of Ellie's death, Aaron and his friend Luke make up an alibi that they were together hunting rabbits as they think this will protect them better, Aaron Falk having been alone at the time, Luke Hadley won't say where he was. This alibi stands but isn't believed by many.Twenty years on, someone shoots and kills Karen Hadley, Luke's wife, and Billy, their young son. Luke appears to be a suicide and it is thought that he killed his family due to financial struggles.Aaron Falk reluctantly shows up for the funeral and things are as bad or worse than he expected. He takes terrible abuse from townspeople who still believe he was responsible for Ellie Duncan's death. But he notices irregularities in the Hadley crime scene and the theory of how it happened. He is a policeman in Melbourne by now, although in financial crimes, and he starts working unofficially with the local police in Kiewarra to see if things aren't quite what they seem. They aren't what they seem.Well written, consistently interesting, intense, beautiful and scary. I enjoyed reading this very much....more

title: The Stager
author: Coll, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Modern day wanna-be Alice in Wonderland. For me, it was a miss in nearly every way. I didn't like the drug use, the character's personalities, the rabModern day wanna-be Alice in Wonderland. For me, it was a miss in nearly every way. I didn't like the drug use, the character's personalities, the rabbit, the neighborhoods, the house, the Stager, her staging, the memories, the adultery, the house. I said "house" twice, and there are two houses. #1 house in a rich neighborhood of Maryland, victim of destruction wrought by rabbit and child, and a place of terrible smells. Man of the House, Lars, only destroyed the #2 house, the posh LONDON house. The house being staged for sale is the MARYLAND house. La-de-da. It is possible if I read Alice in Wonderland today I wouldn't like it either. I prefer my reality un-drugged. I suppose it all is supposed to mean something; like let in the truth and the light will shine, let's get the skeletons out of the closet and dissipate that smell of secrets, let's stop trying to be someone else and find our own identity. Here is a lesson to take from the acting father, drug addict, cuckholded Lars, as repeated by his brat of a daughter Elsa, and given as advice to Lars by the bitter, sarcastic, spleen-stealing male rabbit Dominique: RE-CALIBRATE. And not while you are under the influence as your calibrations are going to be off. That part is my advice.And you might want to be sure of your Stager. This one paints her nails with the child's nail polish, paints a giant rabbit on the wall, and walks off with a tchotchkis. There is a good reason though, sort of. And she did walk through the looking glass when she walked into this house.I have to give the book credit for the clever analogies, the tongue in cheek statements and the black humor....more

title: The Archivist's Story
author: Holland, Travis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Set in Stalinist Russia, in Moscow. It was sad and terrifying. We can all Google how many people were killed during the Stalin years, and it is estimaSet in Stalinist Russia, in Moscow. It was sad and terrifying. We can all Google how many people were killed during the Stalin years, and it is estimated to be as high as a staggering 60 million, but this quiet book explores the juxtaposition between people trying to live normal lives and the constant fear of saying or doing the wrong thing. Women still became pregnant, children played, people got sick and needed medical care, people needed to eat, work and live. But the fear was pervasive and with excellent reason. If you have read 1984 by George Orwell you will understand the terror that people lived with by the parallels between the totalitarian regime of Stalin and the totalitarian regime described in 1984. People were terrified and through fear inspired by murders, tortures and beatings, would confess to anything and implicate anyone. (The building called Lubyanka has a gruesome back story as well, before it became home of the Soviet secret police and a prison. But that isn't part of this book.)This is the fictional story of a teacher who becomes an archivist in Lubyanka after losing his position in the school for his part in the deposition against a fellow teacher. The archivist is having a hard time with his job of burning all of this literature and poetry deemed counterproductive to the revolution. He illegally saves some of the work of Isaac Babel after interviewing the author, who was imprisoned in Lubyanka, to find out whether an unsigned short story was his work. The archivist knows his time of freedom is ending, that he will be arrested soon. He does his best to take care of his loved ones and prepares for the inevitable....more

title: Teacher Man        (Frank McCourt, #3)
author: McCourt, Frank
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoyed reading about Frank McCourt's time in the classrooms of New York. Of course I've read Angela's Ashes, and I read his brother Malachy's autobI enjoyed reading about Frank McCourt's time in the classrooms of New York. Of course I've read Angela's Ashes, and I read his brother Malachy's autobiography, I knew Mr. McCourt had become a teacher. I STILL found this painful reading; this is Frank McCourt and his past is present in his writing, in fact he spends quite a bit of classroom time talking about his miserable Irish childhood. He tells us he talks about it, he doesn't actually spend very much book time talking about it. But the subject tends to fascinate his students, and the kids enjoy storytelling more than they like school assignments. So even as Frank McCourt entertains us with his stories of teaching in New York high schools, he also tells of us his insecurities and self-criticism, his failures and his sins. All of that self-recrimination rang in me like a struck bell. Frank McCourt is funny, successful, he is a survivor. This book didn't hurt as bad as Angela's Ashes, I cried for about a month with that one, but still; I am feeling pain and I don't want to. I suppose there must be some pain in me that matches with the pain in Frank McCourt that is causing this resonating vibrato of pain.The book is certainly not all sorrow; as I said, he is funny and really is a masterful teacher in a non-traditional manner. I think his students were fortunate to have him as a teacher and he was fortunate to have them as students. ...more

The main character, Ellen, is beautiful, talented and educated, but poor. Her mother came from a rich family and had been kicked out of the family when when she married her poor scholar husband in a case of true love. But tragedy strikes and the poor scholar husband dies in a freak accident. This means going home to the mother's family and hoping for a welcome. Mother's sister, Daisy, welcomes her and her daughter Oriana, Ellen's cousin, is thrilled to have a pal. But not so Daisy's husband. Always a fly in the ointment. Stuff happens and Ellen and her mother, Connie, leave. As it happens, they are given refuge by a dressmaker who has a rake of a son who is soon after Ellen. More stuff happens. I don't want to give everything away, but it does have a happy ever after sort of ending if convenient deaths don't bother you. And the stunningly beautiful and amazingly talented poor girl is a cliche that sets my teeth on edge. It seems a Victorian England peculiarity. ...more

title: A Crack in the Edge of the World
author: Winchester, Simon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Great book!I bought it for my 9th grader to read as part of her homeschooling program, but I read it before her. At first I thought I would never get Great book!I bought it for my 9th grader to read as part of her homeschooling program, but I read it before her. At first I thought I would never get through it. His writing is stilted and boring at the beginning, even as he describes the miracles of our astounding planet. And because I am not a student of geology, I was falling asleep over the technical talk.Soon he picks up speed and his language starts to flow, I start using my dictionary to gain an understanding of his geology terms, and we reach a meeting of the minds. I understand what he is saying and he is enjoying what he is teaching.I grew up in Southern California and went through the San Fernando earthquake in 1971, and the Northridge earthquake in 1994. Now I live in Seattle and was here for the Nisqually earthquake in 2001. it amazes me to think that my youngest kiddo, at 15, has never been in an earthquake! She was born later in 2001 than the Nisqually earthquake. I keep thinking we must be in for another pretty soon. That is a little frightening!So I make it through tectonic plate history, placement and movement of; and the early history of quakes along the San Andreas and related faults in Northern California. Good, good. Now onto the history of San Francisco, which I found fascinating, and then the quake itself and the aftermath. Wow! Mind-boggling! I loved this section, it was so very, very interesting. After this, he brings us into the present with a road trip that even includes a trip to Alaska to see the trans-Alaska oil pipeline which crosses the Denali Fault!! The pipeline is very cleverly constructed with expansion curves and sliders and has so far survived an earth movement of eighteen feet to the right without a drop of oil spilled. Well hey for human ingenuity in this case. Recommended read!...more

author: Jackman, Clifford
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: During the Civil War a man named Quentin is put in charge of a group of men. He totally ignores the orders he has been given and takes a core group ofDuring the Civil War a man named Quentin is put in charge of a group of men. He totally ignores the orders he has been given and takes a core group of the men and leads them where he wants to in order to carry out his own insane and violent needs. Soon the war is over, but not for these men who are now outlaws and murderers. Augustine Winter becomes the leader of the group, the men fear and respect him. He doesn't kill for the thrill like Quentin, but he doesn't hesitate either. He leads the group for 25 years. One day he walks away, after a firefight in a town where he is betrayed by one of the gang. Some of them find a more peaceful existence. Then a civilized white man who is greedy for some more land and a Pinkerton detective set on "justice" manage to reactivate the gang for a final showdown. That is a very brief synopsis, there is a lot that goes on in this book and many things to think about regarding war, criminality, justice, loyalty, greed, friendship, and free will. Violence is on nearly, or maybe all of the pages of this book. It is written in a spare and factual manner, impressive writing, and I wonder if I have swallowed a literary bomb that will later explode emotionally within me....more

review: I remember seeing the movie when I was a child and being rather terrified by it. Reading the book was terrifying as well. I kept thinking "there is noI remember seeing the movie when I was a child and being rather terrified by it. Reading the book was terrifying as well. I kept thinking "there is no way this is going to end well". Every time he wrote in his diary or trusted someone I was screaming to myself, "No, don't do it!" But just as Winston Smith is lulled, I became somewhat hopeful that perhaps it wouldn't be as bad as I thought and I was glad for the happiness he did briefly have. The bad came though, and it was so bad. The worst thing for me was the non-ending. In our world, wars end, totalitarian and murderous regimes end. Of course, it always comes back, the evil, the murder. But it does end. We always say, "and this too shall pass". In 1984, it doesn't pass and the control is absolute. Big Brother is watching. Terrifying and heartbreaking....more

title: The World According to Garp
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Emotionally crushing, embarrassing, disgusting, boring.First off, being a John Irving book, I wondered when his first mention of breasts would be. HerEmotionally crushing, embarrassing, disgusting, boring.First off, being a John Irving book, I wondered when his first mention of breasts would be. Here it is, first page, 2nd paragraph: "In Jenny's opinion, her breasts were too large; she thought the ostentation of her bust made her look "cheap and easy."Sex is the central subject of the book, but I've never read a less sexy book about sex. Jenny is a nurse who does not want a romantic relationship, she wants no husband, but she does want a child. She conceives her child in a one time act with a patient who dies not long afterward. She doesn't reveal the nature of the child's conception nor the name of the father for many years, although she does name her child Garp after the father. She raises him on the grounds of a boy's school where she is the nurse. Garp becomes a student, a wrestler, a writer and a lusty young man. He marries his wrestling coach's daughter and they have two, eventually three, children. Infidelity interferes in their domestic happiness and has terrible repercussions. Garp doesn't fully recover, none of them do fully, but Garp says that his life feels like an epilogue after the terrible tragedy occurs. They go on, nonetheless. As a reader I didn't really go on, the rest of the book feels like an epilogue to me. I relate too much perhaps. In my own mind, I am in the epilogue state of my own life.The book is well written though, I already knew John Irving could write. In this story Garp is a writer and numerous pieces of his fictional fiction are included in the story. My favorite was the first chapter of The World According to Bensenhaver. I liked Police Inspector Bensenhaver and could easily have seen a series of detective novels based on his cases.And I liked the justice done, the victim saving and avenging herself, the detective's approval and emotional support. I probably would not have liked the rest of the book as described, but didn't think the first chapter was the trashy horror that all the publishers thought. I also thought if was incredibly gross of the publisher to use the tragedy of Garp and his family to sell this book.The feminist angle was boring, all the transsexual parts were boring. Again, probably because in those cases I don't relate. I did love the "Under Toad". I know exactly what that is and I am making it a part of my own lexicon. ...more

title: How to Be Good
author: Hornby, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was interesting but ultimately led nowhere. A married woman is having an affair and decides she wants a divorce, not because she wants to be with hIt was interesting but ultimately led nowhere. A married woman is having an affair and decides she wants a divorce, not because she wants to be with her lover, but because she is unhappy. Her husband, a chronically angry man, doesn't like this and responds with sarcasm and negativity. Then he goes away, meets a healer and becomes a different man. He isn't angry, he is nice and polite; completely loses his sense of humor and his edge. He brings the healer home to live with them. The healer and the husband start trying to save the world by giving away worldly goods, money and food. Then they get the bright idea of asking all the neighbors if they have a spare room that they could house a homeless teen in. The wife doesn't know which was worse; her mean husband or her seemingly lobotomized husband. But she is the constantly indecisive one and was driving this reader crazy with her drivel. She had an obsession with "being good" which is why she became a doctor. She is a liberal in her viewpoints, but when it came to giving away to all those in need she comes out with a more honest response. As far as doctoring, she felt herself somewhat of a failure. She reminded me of most doctors that I see; unable to help the patient and angry when the patient keeps coming back. Depressing and meaningless. ...more

title: Great Expectations
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A morality tale, written, if my guess is correct, for young adults.Pip is seven years old when we meet him, in the cemetery by himself, some distance A morality tale, written, if my guess is correct, for young adults.Pip is seven years old when we meet him, in the cemetery by himself, some distance from the house. He sees a convict in a leg iron, an escapee from the convict ship, who promptly terrorizes Pip into giving him the bread he has and extracts a promise from Pip that he will bring food and a file to him the next morning. Pip steals the food and the file from the house and gives it to the convict as he promised to do. Pip lives with his sister who is unkind to him, and his sister's husband Joe who is very kind to him. He might have stayed and been a blacksmith like Joe if not for the circumstance of meeting Miss Havisham and Estella. Pip starts thinking his family is common and wants to distance himself, and things get worse when Pip gets an anonymous patron and has great expectations of wealth and being a gentleman. He is also head over heels in love with Estella and she is terrible to him, playing on his insecurities and his love for her. Pip now deserts his family and lives in London. What eventually happens is that Pip matures and becomes a decent person. I felt the message of the book was a warning to young people to appreciate what they have, to repay kindness, to be thrifty etc. In a young person's immaturity they might make similar mistakes to Pip's mistakes. Here is a cautionary tale for young adults, if they have the patience to read it....more

So Abby decides to hire a good looking actor, give him a pen name, and pass him off as the author of the book while holding the copyright herself. She enlists one of her best friends, fellow lawyer Morgan Spencer, to help her. She finds her actor but ends up with his older brother instead, a guy named Jack who is a frustrated writer himself. Jack has the looks, Jack has the charm, eventually Jack has Abby. Morgan has a problem with that. Jack tells her one thing, Morgan tells her another. Who to trust? OK, just as note here. title: A Farewell to Arms
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The person who registered this book with bookcrossing said this about Hemingway, She said, "The Master of the understatement". I had been trying to fiThe person who registered this book with bookcrossing said this about Hemingway, She said, "The Master of the understatement". I had been trying to find the words to express that, trying such things as "the author's voice is flat", but it wasn't that exactly, it is the understatement that is the key to Hemingway's writing, and it is the voice of understatement that is so captivating and depressing at the same time. You can't get away from the futility of life in this book, even through his happy times, it is still there. He is in the army and has friends, he is wounded and in the hospital,; he is in love, expecting a child; through it all he drinks a lot. In the end he loses everything, nothing to do with alcohol, everything to do with life just beating a person down. He tells us in the book that life will kill you, quickly or slowly, probably more quickly if you are a brave and strong person who will not break then life will kill you quick. If you break and break and break and are full of partially healed breaks, an old person full of memories and bitterness, confusion and resentment, then life will kill you more slowly. Reminds me of that line from The Princess Bride, "Life IS pain your Highness". That is what I think Hemingway is telling us, Life is Pain, it breaks us, it kills us. It is interesting to me though, for a man who wrote a rather negative book about war, he sought out a lot of war zones in his life. That made me think more about the way he writes about his friends and his job in the army, his feeling of place, his positive sense of self that came with being in the army. When he loses that he still has his girlfriend but even she questions if she is enough, doesn't he need things to do, men to be friends with. The love and loss part of the story also seems to echo his real life love for a nurse in Italy who married someone else....more

title: Enola Gay
author: Thomas, Gordon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A well balanced and interesting book about the creation of the atomic bomb and the use of it on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. There is a lot of information A well balanced and interesting book about the creation of the atomic bomb and the use of it on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. There is a lot of information about the secrecy surrounding the creation of the bombs and the training of the pilots, the thoughts and actions of the people involved, and a look at what was going on in Japan as well. It is history but well written and full of enough human interest and anecdotes that it reads more like a novel.The problem for me was that I wasn't going to get to the end of the book without reading about dropping the bomb. I kept going slower and slower as the time approached. I finally forced myself to finish it, but it was so painful.  The United States killed 100,000 people in one night of firebombing Tokyo. We killed approx 80,000 in the first eye blink of the atomic bomb explosion in Hiroshima and many died after that. In fact the bomb exploded directly over Shima Hospital instantly vaporizing the people in it. I think something like 40,000 + died in Nagasaki. And there was not much of an expression of doubt or regret at the time, just a lot of hurrah and positive media blitz. It did end the war, so that is understandable to some extent.The book presents the other side as well of course, you know like how many people would have died on both sides had we not used the bomb and the war continued, that sort of thing. I'm not making a case for either scenario, but the bombings were very difficult for me to read....more

Bluesman eliminates evil in a gnarly fight, and then is murdered himself by some redneck bullies who like to say words like "boy" to old black men. Two of those in the redneck group are pretty bad men, beyond their kin. But it doesn't end there because evil never dies, it just waits. And it is coming back!With all the episodes of Supernatural out there, they should have known to salt and burn the bones!But no. Instead of the Winchesters to the rescue, we have a delightful (and I mean that) trio of characters: Crow, a man whose brother was murdered by the evil thirty years ago; Val, the love of Crow's life; Iron Mike Sweeney, superhero, a teenage boy whose home life leaves something to be desired.It was a good book in its way, but I wasn't in the mood for the gruesomeness, nor up for the idea of evil rising again....more

How do you answer life's challenges and choiHow long does it take to find your true love? Is one lifetime enough? What do you do when you do find it? How do you answer life's challenges and choices?Cormac O'Conner is born in northern Ireland in 1723, loved and cherished by his parents, happy with his parents, dog, horse and home. His father is a blacksmith and makes a very special sword. When he is nine he loses his mother, when he is sixteen he loses his father. The Earl of Warren, who lives in Belfast near them, is indirectly responsible for both deaths. The Earl, who ships slaves, is quite wealthy and he leaves to America to make even more money. Cormac, who has money from his father and the sword, follows the Earl to America after promising to avenge the death of his father.Through acts of kindness to blacks who have been captured and are in the hold of the ship, Cormac is given the gift of almost eternal life as long he does not leave Manhattan. title: Travels with Charley: In Search of America
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When John Steinbeck was fifty-eight years old he decided to travel the United States, in a truck with a camper built on the back, with his dog. It wasWhen John Steinbeck was fifty-eight years old he decided to travel the United States, in a truck with a camper built on the back, with his dog. It was 1960 and Mr. Steinbeck felt that he no longer knew the United States, that it had changed and he wanted to know the people and the national temperament, and of course to write about what he found. He was born in 1902, so certainly the country had changed a lot from when he was a young man to 1960. He had lived through both World Wars, the Great Depression, and in 1960 the Civil Rights movement was getting underway and the country was on the verge of changing much further with the Vietnam War and all the social changes that took place in the 1960'sSo here is Mr. Steinbeck, with his dog Charley, driving through the country, stopping and chatting with people, offering them coffee and liquor, just being sociable. He is a very, very intense personality and the book is much more about Mr. Steinbeck himself and about Charley, than it is about the places he stops. I personally liked this quite a bit, I found his mind very intelligent if somewhat gloomy. He was lonely for his wife and home much of the time. This is a book that I would read again because I don't think that I absorbed it all. I don't really want to read about his experience in Louisiana again, with the women shouting horrible things at the little black girl who was being integrated into the white school. It reminded me of the Westboro Baptist Church, and it was most unpleasant. I think his assessment of the situation was right on, but then I agreed with much of what he said. Such a brilliant mind; every Steinbeck book is a book that I would read again. ...more

But she has her two children there with her on vacation and she does a lot of cooking which makes her happy. She has brought along her best friend, who is a gay man, and the best friend's husband. She hires a Spanish tutor for her seventeen year old daughter. She flirts with all available men, including the young Spanish tutor.Son has never matured into the grown man he should be. This book; Just Another Kid, is in the time period between those two books. She is still anticipating going to Wales and getting married. She still has a lot of the hope and optimism that young people have and she does a very good job with the kids. The title "Just Another Kid" refers to the mother of one of her kids in the class. This mother is very troubled and an alcoholic and has some run ins with Torey. Despite her problems, or perhaps because of them, she asks if she can volunteer as an aide in the classroom. Torey certainly needs an aide, and the mother, Ladbrooke, needs to have something productive to do and someone to look out for her. She does surprisingly well with the kids and bonds with Torey. Evidently they remain friends later. Five years after the end of this book they are still friends, both are married and have new babies. I'm wondering what Ladbrooke is doing now, if she succeeded or what happened to her. As a parent of a special needs child I found the classroom techniques very interesting. I can tell you that there must have been less rules in place regarding hugging students and restraining students back when Torey was teaching. ...more

review: I want to like Agatha Christie books, but I find them boring, at least this one was.This one had a good premise and an interesting ending, but there iI want to like Agatha Christie books, but I find them boring, at least this one was.This one had a good premise and an interesting ending, but there is just too much talking and speculation. First off, the ruse the PI uses to talk to people in the village is just stupid. He pretends he is writing a book about superstitions, but he never questions people about superstitions, just about recent deaths. Then he mis-remembers a conversation that causes him to look at the wrong suspects. As a reader who either remembers or who can look back at the conversation, it just makes you feel the detective is thick. The most boring part of the book has to be when he goes through each suspect and victim seeing if they tie together. I wanted to tell him to make a spread sheet, solve it already and leave us out of all his ridiculous musings. Reasonably good ending though, saved it from being utterly boring. I also liked some of the descriptions, enjoyed the pictures created in my mind....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Julie Gregory's parents were both mentally ill. Her mother suffered from Munchausen by Proxy, meaning she perpetrated upon Julie constant doctor visitJulie Gregory's parents were both mentally ill. Her mother suffered from Munchausen by Proxy, meaning she perpetrated upon Julie constant doctor visits for illnesses that she either induced in Julie or conned doctors into believing that Julie had. Her father was unable and unwilling to stop the abuse and participated in it to some extent. This sick couple even got licenses to take care of war vets and foster children. As any child will, Julie believed her mother and thought that she was sick. She participated in the physical abuse of the foster children in order to gain her mother's approval.When Julie got old enough she reported her mother's abuse. It took awhile for anyone to take her seriously but when she was successful in getting the vets and foster kids removed, she was still unable to live normally and cut ties with her parents. The damage was extensive. Not only was her mother sick, her grandmother was also sick --- and for how many generations back, who knows?Julie is now an educational speaker on Munchausen by Proxy. Here is an interview she did:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xAAUQ... ...more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In Tehillim (Psalms as it is known in English) 119 verse 37 we say, "Avert my eyes from seeing futility, through your ways preserve me."This book justIn Tehillim (Psalms as it is known in English) 119 verse 37 we say, "Avert my eyes from seeing futility, through your ways preserve me."This book just stares the abyss in the heart, it stares at the futility and refuses to look away. That makes for pretty bleak reading. For example, from pages 592 - 594, the paragraphs that start with,"But depression wasn't the word. This was a plunge encompassing sorrow and revulsion far beyond the personal: a sick, drenching nausea at all humanity and human endeavor from the dawn of time. The writhing loathsomeness of the biological order. Old age, sickness, death. No escape for anyone. Even the beautiful ones were like soft fruit about to spoil....."and ending with these words,"But in strong light there was no good spin you could put on it. It was rotten top to bottom. Putting your time in at the office; dutifully spawning your two point five; smiling politely at your retirement party; then chewing on your bedsheet and choking on your canned peaches at the nursing home. It was better never to have been born."Funny, but extremely bleak, right? Truth, but not, depending on what you make of it. One does not need to look, it probably won't help.She also tackles a question at the end which is noteworthy,"Because isn't it drilled into us constantly, from childhood on, an unquestioned platitude in the culture------?......How do we know what is right for us? Every shrink, every career counselor, every Disney princess knows the answer: "Be yourself." "Follow your heart."Only here 's what I really, really want someone to explain to me. What if one happens to be possessed of a heart that can't be trusted---? What if the heart, for its own unfathomable reasons, leads one willfully and in a cloud of unspeakable radiance away from health, domesticity, civic responsibility and strong social connections and all the blandly-held common virtues and instead straight towards a beautiful flare of ruin, self-immolation, disaster?....If your deepest self is singing and coaxing you straight toward the bonfire, is it better to turn away?"In Judaism we are told to follow our brain, the seat of the intellect, and NOT to follow the heart, the seat of passions. And for good reason, right? Self-immolation and all that? This concept is gone into in the Tanya. As you can see by the parts I have quoted, Donna Tartt is an incredible writer, muscular and brilliant writing. She tackles life here using the characters of Theo Decker, his best friend Boris, his beloved Pippa, his protector and teacher Hobie, his other family the Barbours, and his parents in their love and their fallibility. Truly an amazing book and I recommend it if you can hold strong and not let it knock you down. It almost certainly won't let you down....more

title: The Girls Who Went Away: The Hidden History of Women Who Surrendered Children for Adoption in the Decades Before Roe v. Wade
author: Fessler, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought I had written a  for this book but evidently I didn't save it or something. This book is about adoption, specifically in the years betI thought I had written a  for this book but evidently I didn't save it or something. This book is about adoption, specifically in the years between the end of WWII and the early 1970's when both birth control and abortion became legal and widely available.I am one of the babies who was given up for adoption by a teenage mom who hid her condition from everyone except her mom, the birth father and her best friend. I found her when I was 30 and she was 45, married and mother to an additional four children. Her husband never knew about me and has since passed away. What I can tell you is that lost years can never be recovered. Strangely, although I have a relationship with my birth mother and am so grateful for that, we have never discussed what it felt like for her to give me up. We love each other now and that seems to be enough for both of us. My relationship does not extend much beyond her to the other members of the family. My adopted sister and brother have found the same thing to be true with their birth mothers. It is impossible to go back. You can't be the infant and they can't be the teenage girl who just gave birth. In some ways that is hard to accept and causes a renewal of the grief before a relationship can begin in real time. The book had a very strong impact on me. Even knowing my birth mother for 25 years I was not disabused of the idea that the girls had a choice, a real choice. I was always told that "your mother loved you so much that she gave you up for adoption because she knew she couldn't care for you herself." I believed that. Now I wonder why I believed it so thoroughly for so many years. I have children, I know how fiercely I loved them from the time I knew of their existence and how devastating it would have been to give them up. I have even been bereaved, well I am bereaved, it doesn't go away, so I know how it feels to suffer the loss of a child. I don't understand how I could imagine that it would be different for my birth mother, or any birth mother, to give up a child. What I faced in this book is the reality of the stigma, shame and blame heaped on these teenage girls, and the grief they suffered when they were forced to leave their babies. Well of course they suffered! And why are there so many adoptees who search for their mothers? It is a bond created by DNA and the 9 months in the womb. Adoption is not without consequences for mother and child, and father if he wanted his child and was never given the chance to be the parent.That is not to say that adoption has no place; many children are born into truly untenable situations with drug addicted or abusive parents who are not capable of parenting. These children need to be safe and loved so adoption is the best answer in many cases. However, this adoption boom in the 50's and 60's had everything to do with being shamed by the evidence of teen sexuality. Most of the families could have given the girl their support and helped her emotionally and financially to parent her child. It was particularly sad when a young couple, near adulthood, wanting to marry, were forced to give up their baby because one set of parents or another would not permit the marriage. But really it was sad in every case as child and mother were forced to separate by social workers and religious workers who did not understand what they were doing.I think abortion has the potential for as many complications for the mother in terms of loss, grief, trauma and regret, as giving up a baby for adoption. And of course, the baby never gets a chance. I think this is an important book and recommend it....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you don't already have a poor opinion of the Greek Frat and Sorority systems, this might make you take a second look at those systems. We all know If you don't already have a poor opinion of the Greek Frat and Sorority systems, this might make you take a second look at those systems. We all know the general problems of drinking, peer pressure and date rape that occur on our college campuses. Add to the general problems the problems of the Greek Houses; hazing, social ostracism for non-conformity, and (at least in this book) strange and secret rituals. You have all the makings of a cult, yet no one seems to take the problem seriously or even recognize it as a problem.Young man in first year of college; boisterous, often drunk and obnoxious, vulnerable. Young woman in college, member of sorority, falls in love with the young man, or does she? Young woman dies in car accident in which young man is driving. He is accused of being drunk when it happens; he himself cannot remember the accident. He goes back to college and is ostracized. He keeps thinking he sees his former girlfriend and even receives cards and phone calls from her. His roommate is deeply involved in the betrayals and deceptions, although the ultimate betrayal is a surprise to him as well. Things don't work out well. Many people didn't like the ending of the book but in a way I found it fitting; the drama ends and before you know it life has moved on and no one even remembers....more

In Puritan New England the swimming is particularly horrifying as only witches are thought to be able to stay afloat. Nearly everything Kit does gets her into trouble. She makes friends with the local "witch" who is actually a very sweet and lonely old Quaker woman. She befriends a young girl whose mother treats the girl very badly and teaches this child to read. She acts out Bible stories with the children she teaches. She helps a young seaman thatch the roof of the Quaker woman and when a mob comes after the woman she rescues her. Soon enough Kit herself is accused of witchcraft. This book is a children's book so we are spared any true horror and tragedy. The rescues work out, the romances work out, all is well. That Electric Chair! How could we have ever used that to execute people? You might find this interesting https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electri...The Green Mile is the walk the condemned prisoner walked from his cell to the chair for execution. This fictional story involves the case of a black man convicted of raping and killing two young girls. He is an unusual individual and innocent of the crime he has been convicted of. There are other killers on the row who are guilty and we see the humanity despite their crimes. One of them is just completely off his rocker and evil. Then there are good guys who aren't so good. Mixed up world. There is also a very special mouse. We often see a person's character by how they treat animals. And then there are people who can kill other people but love animals; something seriously out of sync with that but it happens. Our main character is the head boss on the death row, a man of intelligence, compassion and insight who does his job the best he can, but what a job. It is an excellent story and I recommend it.I've never seen the movie but I am going to make a point to see it now.I have increased my rating on this book because it is brilliant; it had a very big impact on my way of looking at things and is one of the books that stands out in my memory while most books fade away....more

review: When I read Frank McCourt's book "Angela's Ashes" I cried so much that pretty soon I didn't even have to read it, I would pick it up and start sobbingWhen I read Frank McCourt's book "Angela's Ashes" I cried so much that pretty soon I didn't even have to read it, I would pick it up and start sobbing. I never cried so much in my life.Malachy McCourt is Frank's younger brother. He is the wild one to his older brother's more responsible and measured nature. Malachy has a wonderful voice, he is very funny, but this book is so painful. I didn't cry like I did with Angela's Ashes but I felt the pain. All of Malachy's drinking and antics and rages and jokes...just pain and more pain. If you are not familiar with either brother or book; they grew up in dire poverty in Limerick, Ireland. Real poverty, not the kind of poverty that has a T.V. and an indoor toilet. Their upbringing was more than tragic. Their Dad was an alcoholic, Malachy is as well. Whatever hope the family might have had was destroyed with the drinking. This book is not the classic that Angela's Ashes is, but I think it gives a lot of insight to what happens in an alcoholic and desperately poor family who suffer various abuses. Malachy was not a likeable person much of the time, but my heart always went out to him anyway. And like I said he does possess a wonderful wit and an amusing way with words....more

title: Skinny Dip        (Skink, #5; Mick Stranahan #2)
author: Hiaasen, Carl*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Funny book for the most part. Joey Wheeler is thrown off a cruise ship, off the coast of Florida, by her husband on the their second anniversary cruisFunny book for the most part. Joey Wheeler is thrown off a cruise ship, off the coast of Florida, by her husband on the their second anniversary cruise. She survives the fall and starts swimming. Guy in a boat finds her delirious and clinging to a bale of pot. He takes her in, hears her story and instead of going to the police the two of them plan a wacky revenge. Joey would like to know why her husband, Chaz, threw her off the ship.Chaz is a biologist working as a water quality specialist for a big agricultural company in the Everglades. His job consists of lying about the amount of phosphorous in the water. When his wife is reported missing and assumed fallen overboard and drowned, this brings a lot of unwanted attention from the police who are rightly suspicious of the circumstances of Joey's assumed death. The company, protecting its interests, posts a gorilla of a body guard on Chaz. Farce ensues, justice is served, this is South Florida in all its hilariousness. I lived in South Florida for a little while and found it to be a place that generated amusing stories, including for me; the septic system (don't let your kids play in the sprinklers, walking barefoot in the grass - don't, the DOL - big room for waiting, people get called out in groups of 10, there are 10 chairs in a row and every time a person gets called to the counter everyone moves one chair closer to chair #1 from which you will get called to the counter - not even joking about this. Carl Hiaasen kicks it up a notch for laughs but he really portrays South Florida with an eye for its innate comedic value....more

title: The Innocent Man: Murder and Injustice in a Small Town
author: Grisham, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Certainly does not make a person feel warm and fuzzy about cops and the justice system. Ron Williamson is a small town baseball star in high school. LCertainly does not make a person feel warm and fuzzy about cops and the justice system. Ron Williamson is a small town baseball star in high school. Later he plays in the minors for the Yankees. But he is moody, drinks too much and chases women more than he plays baseball. He gets accused of rape twice, so when a young woman in his neighborhood is raped and murdered Ron becomes the #1 suspect along with a friend of his. It makes sense to look at someone previously accused of rape. The problem was the evidence. The evidence does not support the theory that Ron Williamson committed the murder but the cops believe they have their man and don't pursue other suspects, including the man who was last seen with her. Ron's moodiness becomes full blown mental illness, the justice system grinds on and eventually Ron, insane and not receiving proper health care, is on death row. The cops refuse to accept that they could be wrong. It isn't until DNA evidence technology advances to the point where matches can be made or eliminated that Ron and his friend go free. It is a long haul. The process pretty much takes Ron's life even though he doesn't die on death row. I was amazed by how hard his sisters worked to support him financially and emotionally through all of the years of accusations, incarceration and mental illness, especially his oldest sister Annette. The justice system pretty much chewed him up and spit him out, but he was blessed with a wonderful family, many fine legal people on his team who worked to save him, and some really good friends. ...more

title: Little Big Man
author: Berger, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It took me a long time to read as I slowed down and quit every time I couldn't handle what was going on. I don't have any objectivity on this subject,It took me a long time to read as I slowed down and quit every time I couldn't handle what was going on. I don't have any objectivity on this subject, no space between me and the killing, so I read with dread. I loved the way the ending was written though, there was so much dignity.Jack Crabb is carried off, sort of, by Indians when he is 7 years old. He is adopted by the Cheyenne Indian Chief of this small band of Cheyenne. He lives an Indian life but never forgets he is white. In the midst of a battle with whites, while in his young teens, he defects the Indian tribe and rejoins the whites. He is adopted by a white couple, eventually leaves them, marries a Swedish woman and they have a child. Things being what they are, life turns and his life is thrown into chaos when his business partners cheat him and his wife and child are carried off by Indians. Eventually, through various life circumstances, he rejoins the Cheyenne and marries again, has another child. Life turns, he loses them too. And on it goes. He sees some of the worst as an Indian when he is present at Washita. He lives through Little Big Horn as a white man. One thing that I really like about this book is that it does not sugar coat either side and has a sense of humor about both, and best, the Indian Nations are given dignity; they win, they lose, they win, they lose, life turns and it turns and it will turn again. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Jack Reacher, ex-military police, homeless and unemployed, is in Nebraska hitchhiking to Virginia. He has a badly broken nose for which he should get Jack Reacher, ex-military police, homeless and unemployed, is in Nebraska hitchhiking to Virginia. He has a badly broken nose for which he should get medical attention but doesn't and it is freezing out. Nevertheless, he continues to hitchhike until he is picked up by two men and a woman, none of whom are revealing their true identities. In fact, looks like the two men are fresh from a murder and the woman is a hostage. Looks can be deceiving. Is Reacher in danger? He spends much of the road trip trying to work out what is going on. He gets shot at which makes him a bit mad, they leave without him and he takes out after them to rescue the woman. An FBI agent is after them also because the woman appears to have been kidnapped. Then more FBI agents, CIA, Department of Defense and the local sheriff from the town where Reacher was first picked up and the woman was kidnapped; all of these people become involved. It is a three ring law enforcement circus, and no one is having any luck identifying or controlling Reacher. Jack Reacher is that lone cowboy, that hero on the side of the angels. Side of the angels is one of the author's phrases. The author uses a writing technique of repeating the same phrases in a deliberate manner that is pleasing. If only Jack Reacher was real and could save America.This book is a solid 3 1/2 stars....more

review: A corpse turns up in Yorkshire. Who put it up there, next to an old stone wall, where a sheep farmer discovers it? That is the question the book asks.A corpse turns up in Yorkshire. Who put it up there, next to an old stone wall, where a sheep farmer discovers it? That is the question the book asks.I ask, why is there so much filler in the book, like Detective Banks and his troubles with pipe smoking and eventual return to cigarette smoking? Why aren't there enough clues for either the detective or the reader to figure it out until the end, after another senseless murder, and then there are pages and pages of explanation. We don't actually figure it out; we just get told at great length about the solution and why that makes sense and why the detective couldn't figure it out earlier.So, while I always enjoy the slow pace, dry humor and beauty of Yorkshire highlands, I thought the book was lacking in story layout and conclusion....more

title: Thug Kitchen: The Official Cookbook: Eat Like You Give a F*ck        (Thug Kitchen Cookbooks)
author: Kitchen, Thug
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Best cookbook that I own. Every recipe I've tried is really quick to make and super scrumptious delicious and it is all healthy food. The language is Best cookbook that I own. Every recipe I've tried is really quick to make and super scrumptious delicious and it is all healthy food. The language is terrible and I love it. Maybe it reminds me of growing up in the San Fernando Valley. This is the first cookbook that inspired me to eat breakfast, a meal I have been avoiding for over 40 years as I prefer coffee and some sort of sugar filled breakfast bar. Here is what Thug Kitchen says about breakfast, "Seriously you need to eat breakfast. You've heard the same shit a million times, but it's true: breakfast is the most important meal of the day. Consider the fact that when you wake up, you haven't eaten anything for six to eight hours - sometimes longer, depending on whatever the fuck you justified as last night's dinner. So you really think it's OK to coast on fumes until lunch? Skipping breakfast is not only lazy but that shit is detrimental to your health."The language makes me laugh and the food is excellent and did I mention how fast it is to make? I made a double batch of quinoa oatmeal and ate it with strawberries and maple syrup. I'm feeling so righteous. My favorite cookbook ever. Thanks Thug Life!In retrospect; I found the book much less appealing when I discovered it was written by two white people. Does that make me a bigot or non-bigot or just confused? I have no idea. I just liked the idea of THUGS in the kitchen. These people are just white vegans who talk like thugs. Hmmm, I think I am really twisted in my thinking here, but that is what I am thinking. I still like the cookbook, food is still good. But book rating is going to a 4 star....more

review: Fictional story of a Jewish kid, child of immigrants, who grows up in Brooklyn's lower east side slums. He is the oldest of the children and when his Fictional story of a Jewish kid, child of immigrants, who grows up in Brooklyn's lower east side slums. He is the oldest of the children and when his father dies when he is twelve, he takes over the responsibility for keeping the family alive. He starts out selling bagels and coffee, then starts selling theater tickets. Later he acts in the music halls and then starts his own Nickelodeon theaters. He is clever, he makes money, and he loves the idea of moving pictures. He makes it all the way to millions of dollars, a big studio in the Los Angeles area and the beginning of the talking movies which was in 1927.Sadly, he was never appreciated by his family. His mother is a terrible character, written in such a gross stereotypical fashion that towards the end I just skipped the scenes that had her in them. His whole family was just a mess of Jewish stereotypes and it made for unpleasant reading. His brothers were thieves, two sisters married worthless bums, one sister was a spinster, the mother was a shrew. Most of them couldn't get enough money and never contributed. Max was the only one who made money, was generous and liked to help people. The people he should have been able to trust betray him for complicated reasons of their own. It would have been disturbing and upsetting if it wasn't fictional.As a book it was kind of long-winded and, well me being me, I would have preferred to read histories and biographies of the real people who made those early moving pictures....more

title: Sutton
author: Moehringer, J.R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Willie Sutton was the ultimate gentleman bank robber. Although he carried a gun he used it as a prop to convince those he was robbing to do as they weWillie Sutton was the ultimate gentleman bank robber. Although he carried a gun he used it as a prop to convince those he was robbing to do as they were told. With his costumes, his charm and professionalism, he almost made bank robbing seem like a legitimate career. I couldn't help but like him. I'm not the only one; cops and criminals respected him, banks had good reason to fear his intelligence and diligence. Prisons had a hard time holding on to him, he successfully broke out of prison three times. He worked as hard at robbing banks as any dedicated person works at a job that they love. There is something about him, the way he stands up to the banking and financial systems that pretty much grind most of us down, that made him an American folk hero and has won my grudging respect and admiration. I wouldn't want my sons to follow in his footsteps, but I liked Willie. Willie suffered a lot in his life, most of the time he was not enjoying the spoils of his robberies. He never had what one might call a normal life. There was a period of his life when he would anonymously donate to have old people with no family buried properly. Who knows, but I'm thinking that Willie was probably not a candidate for hell. Wily, canny, intelligent, book-loving, bank robbing Willie Sutton was a criminal that maybe we all have a little of in our heart. I'm hoping Willie looks after Colton Harris Moore- the Bare Foot Bandit, in a guardian angel sort of way. Colton is a young man who didn't have many chances in life, like Willie, and committed non-violent acts of robbery in a charming way that made him a bit of a folk hero like Willie. It's a tough life.Very memorable book, so I am increasing my rating to a 5 star....more

review: **spoiler alert** The writing was good, but the story was not one that I enjoyed.There is this nice suburban family; father is a doctor, mother is a p**spoiler alert** The writing was good, but the story was not one that I enjoyed.There is this nice suburban family; father is a doctor, mother is a part-time school teacher and home maker, there are three young children. They suffer from 'living in a village neurotic syndrome' meaning they are bored and worried about the "littleness" of their lives. On the advice of and following the example of the Scottish grandfather who sent his son Archie away to school, they also send their nine year old son away to boarding school which gives young Thomas more problems than just the village malaise that effects the adults.Then the same very proper Scottish grandfather, who is very close to his son Archie, falls in love. Archie doesn't like this, he feels left out. When the new woman, Marina, comes to the house to meet everyone; they all fall in love with her. Then the grandfather dies and the whole shebang goes all Prince of Tides. We are supposed to buy the premise that Archie having an affair with this woman was just what the family needed to wake it up and send it out of its complacency. My opinion of that premise? Utter and complete rubbish. And the way that the wife Liza is portrayed takes her from competent and happy wife to making her a ghost of her former self, a woman who no longer believes her skills and love are worth much, her husband views her as a pitiful person. We are supposed to believe that the marriage will be better after the upheaval. After all, they are chucking the village and moving to Scotland. ..........and this fixes things because moving to Scotland does what??I pretty much hated it, as I expected I would. Bumped up to a 2 star rating because the writing, especially scenes with the children, was good....more

I've eaten outside and unless the South of France is bereft of the normal wSuffers from a bit of idealism, like with all the wonderful meals outside. Maybe she had all the proper plants, citronella candles, etc to drive the buggies away. Never had much success with it myself.But the idealism also makes the book pleasurable. She seems to be a happy person by nature, an optimist. She is also in love which can make even outdoor eating bearable, maybe. Her optimism runs thick throughout the book.She and her love Michel buy a tumbledown farm in the South of France. They don't have much money and have quite a lot of finagling to do to make this work. They become Olive Farmers and their success is sweet, even inspiring. Now don't laugh, but after everything I just said about eating outside, I decided my yard really needed work and I wanted to make pleasant sitting and EATING AREAS in my yard. We are having a spate of nice weather in Seattle so I've been weeding and visualizing what kind beautiful yard I might have. The reading experience was about 3 1/2 stars but because her writing inspired me to work on my own yard and visualize beauty I bumped the score up to a 4. Nice to be inspired, thank you!...more

There is a strong life force in the book when she shares these memories. Such as this one, inspired by driving through the green hills of Italy:"The greens! Hills look as though footlights angle across them-neon green, poison green, velvet green, Life-Saver green. When I was five, I saw an irresistible green moss and jumped on it. I quickly sank into sludge and my father, in a pale linen suit and shouting "Jesus H. Christ," had to fish me out. I had jumped through a brilliant, thick algae covering the surface of an open septic tank behind the cotton mill."Or this memory zings like an electric shock, at least it did me,"I'm talking to friends in the living room when I see my nephew arrive in the crowded foyer. As I walk toward him, I introduce myself to the man talking to Ashley. "Hello, I'm Frances, Ashley's mother." I shake his hand and see the startled look on his face. "And I'm Frank," he answers with a laugh. My former husband. Ashley's father. We were married for a life time. I do not recognize him. He thinks I am surely joking. .... Once he said to me, I'd know your hand in a bucket of hands, one of the strangest intimacies I have heard. I step outside and take big breaths of air and try to adjust to the jolt... For a long time, I will be feeling my hand go out to shake that of a stranger."The parts of the book that interested me were the parts where the author revealed herself. title: On the Road
author: Kerouac, Jack
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: That was an incredibly sad book. A book of lost souls. First of all, what is the "Beat" generation? I always thought it had something to do with musicThat was an incredibly sad book. A book of lost souls. First of all, what is the "Beat" generation? I always thought it had something to do with music! Or the Bohemian lifestyle. I was surprised to find out that it refers to a group of authors, including Jack Kerouac in the core group. Here is the Wiki definition:The Beat Generation was a group of authors whose literature explored and influenced American culture in the post-World War II era. - def from WikipediaAs I was reading this book I was becoming aware that the 1960's started in the late 1940's with the Beat generation. Everything was "kicks", sweet little "gone" girls, and the booze? it never stopped flowing, lots of marijuana too and benzedrine. "...compulsive psychosis dashed with a jigger of psychopathic irresponsibility and violence." It was all couched in this search for the truth of life, the true experience of life. They travel all over looking for the authentic experiences of life. They seem to find their own backgrounds and their own selves inauthentic, or at least emotionally hollow and constantly needing to be filled up. Haven't we all been there to some degree? Isn't that why we listen to music, travel and ingest mood altering substances? It is an emotional yearning.But these guys? They take it way beyond. They are hedonistic, wild, irresponsible to the point of criminality. And they seem to me to be such sad and empty people, trying to fill up with noise, booze, drugs, girls, and constant motion. Maybe we all are, except now we are trying to fill up with FB, everyone always on their phone, being present anywhere but where they are. The writing is authentic, it is American to its core. It makes me feel love, nostalgia, disgust and anger; love for my country, disgust at the irresponsibility of the actions of Jack and his friends, sorrow for their emotional wreckage, anger at the damage done to the generations influenced by this book and the cultural change it wrought to drop the moral code and seek the kicks, shock at the ignorance of east coast intellectual liberals with their dreamy eyed vision of the indigent and indigenous peoples and their assumptions of these people's simplicity. There is a lot to rant against in this book, but then there is the nostalgia for the road, to just drive off without plans and see what we shall see. A classic book indeed, the Beat Generation, to a large extent, created the 1960's and the reverberations continue to this day. I was born in 1957, my whole life was influenced by the Beat Generation and Jack Kerouac. I didn't know it though. I was a teen with a soul that vibrated in time with the likes of Jack. I went after the wild times and all that went with it. To some extent it was the culture, but some of the kids went for academics, sports or Prom Queen. I didn't. I can blame the Beat Generation for the culture but not for my own personal choices, not totally anyway. The culture changed, I changed and became a more responsible person than I had been. Doesn't this book give us something to really think about in regards to culture, how it comes about, and people's choices within it? Some people did not like the writing in this book but I thought it was brilliant in its way. Didn't anyone else want to cry when Dean walked away that last time? Didn't everyone feel the pain of little lost boy Dean always looking for his father in the bars and streets he used to frequent?...more
