review: I've read two other books by Caleb Carr and know him to be a good writer, so I was puzzled by why he was writing this book. It is a Sherlock Holmes stI've read two other books by Caleb Carr and know him to be a good writer, so I was puzzled by why he was writing this book. It is a Sherlock Holmes story written in the attempted voice and style of Sir Author Conan Doyle. It doesn't quite make it. At first I thought maybe he is poking fun here  "I believe that I divine your next statement as clearly as I would see this train, were I standing miles ahead of it and upon a flat track" at the original Sherlock Holmes stories, but no, this story is as serious as any of the originals. It is, perhaps, as good as the lesser of the originals but, I'm sorry, this is only opinion, not as good as the great originals. So why was he writing it? That is revealed in the afterward.Caleb Carr was, so the editor says, very interested in the story of the murder of the Italian Secretary David Rizzio, in Holyrood Palace in 1566. I wish he had written one of his own books about it, fiction or non-fiction, but in his own way, not as a Sherlock Holmes story. History is fascinating and I would have voted for more history and less fiction.Just as a point of personal interest, one of my sons built a large-ish (more than twice his own height) trebuchet....more

title: Super-Cannes
author: Ballard, J.G.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think if I had a shelf called "yech" I would list this book on it. I mean, really? I got sick of hearing it. I got sick of the sickos running this "I think if I had a shelf called "yech" I would list this book on it. I mean, really? I got sick of hearing it. I got sick of the sickos running this "multi-national business park" called Eden Olympia. What kind of a future were they creating? There were no kids in the book except the shadow kids we hear about being used for sex. There were so many films of crimes, both of sex and just beating the life out of "Arabs" and "immigrants" that it felt like a sick version of the Nixon White House and the Watergate scandal. Sorry for insulting Nixon and his White House; they were nothing compared to Eden Olympia. But there are some parallels with taping and filming and with the official sanctioned government thugs. In Eden Olympia the author calls these bands of executive thugs out for some fun 'the bowling team' because they wear matching leather jackets. Evidently beating people up really cleanses the psyche, releases tension and keeps them safe from viruses. David Greenwood was a British doctor working at Eden Olympia. One of those sainted types; loved by everyone, working so hard, giving his all to both the population in Eden Olympia and the poor immigrant orphanage outside Eden Olympia. One day he goes nuts and shoots a bunch of people. What a crazy aberration! Enter Dr. Jane Sinclair, hired to replace Dr. Greenwood, and her, at loose ends recovering from an injury, pilot husband Paul. They are moved into Dr. Greenwood's former home. Dr. Jane goes to work (she does? she is a paediatrician and there are no kids in Eden Olympia. She doesn't even get to volunteer at the orphanage were Dr. Greenwood worked, as all those "nubile thirteen year old girls" have gone elsewhere) and Paul lounges around the pool wondering about Dr. David Greenwood and his motivations for the murders.I never hear of anyone ever actually doing any work although there is plenty of talk about the terribly long hours and the need for recreation to satisfy the beast within. No one in Eden Olympia wants to play games with balls. Noooo, here they want to let loose the raging beast. It is all OK because the Doctor in charge of mental health in Eden Olympia prescribes these activities as therapy. In the meantime, Dr. Jane is spending time with her prurient neighbors and her husband is channeling Dr. David Greenwood. Read it if you want, I don't recommend it.The author does have a way with words. I was trying to read the book and ignore him at the same time, but he did amuse me sometimes. "It could be racist, or some mad animal rights thing. Fanatical Greens always veer off-course, and end up trying to save the smallpox virus. On the other hand--""Everyone works hard--it proves nothing. People are impressionable, they snatch powerful emotions out of the air. The one thing Eden Olympia doesn't need is its own Green movement. Why doesn't anyone want to save the planet's concrete?""I guess it can look after itself.""Can it?" Penrose turned to stare at me, as if I had conveyed a unique insight.'...more

review: Soporific, nostalgic, full of both grief and love. I had the hardest time getting into the rhythm of the book, I couldn't hear the voice until I was mSoporific, nostalgic, full of both grief and love. I had the hardest time getting into the rhythm of the book, I couldn't hear the voice until I was more than halfway through. All of a sudden it clicked with me; the grief and love were overwhelming but it was too late to quit reading, the story had become part of me. This is a story of a Scottish family who have lived on Cape Breton for four generations, we follow (although not as you might think, it is non-linear) the changes that are wrought in the people and the land, the connection of the people through their native language, the losses and the lives of the family. The connection between brothers, between brothers in law, between children and grandparents; I was crushed by some of the scenes like the ones between Calum and his younger brother Alexander, the scene between Alexander and his grandmother when she is in the nursing home. The author brought it all straight to this reader's heart. This is truly an excellent book, I recommend it.Because I didn't actually remember this book until reading my  I am removing one star. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At least as much about relationships as it is about cops/crime/detective work. Also, two of the main characters were EMT. That added a lot of interestAt least as much about relationships as it is about cops/crime/detective work. Also, two of the main characters were EMT. That added a lot of interesting detail. A man is panicked, afraid that he is being followed and will be killed. We meet him when he crashes into a pole in a non-fatal car accident. We meet our EMT people when they are first responders to this accident. Later that day they all meet up again when the car accident victim becomes a fatality when he falls/jumps/is pushed under a train. Now it is police business; the detectives must determine if this was a suicide or if a crime has been committed. Our victim had been a witness to a crime some years ago and testified against the perpetrator. That perpetrator had recently been released from prison but he has an alibi for the time that the man went under the train. He also has a nice/deluded girlfriend who believes in him and defends him. Detective Marconi believes that once a criminal, most likely always a criminal. Her boss is convinced the case is a waste of time, that the victim commit suicide. Interwoven through this are the psychology and trials of parenting and love. I enjoyed this book and hope to read this author again. ...more

review: Socialization in school is a bitter thing; in fact, finding your place in life is a bitter thing for most people. There is pain from feelings of rejecSocialization in school is a bitter thing; in fact, finding your place in life is a bitter thing for most people. There is pain from feelings of rejection and inadequacy. One realizes very early on where one fits. I knew from before I have clear memory that I was not going to be popular. Fortunately I didn't care much and I was happy with the friends that I had. I was never beat up or taunted the way Jodee was. For whatever reason I never drew that sort of attention and I'm glad. But I remember kids who did and I don't have a clear understanding of why some kids are picked on. Reading Jodee's story, I always felt she put too much importance on what the popular kids thought, but it was her reality, her life, her emotions and her decisions about what to do in regards to the unkindness she was shown. She got the best revenge by her success, her beauty, and most important of all, her forgiveness of those who hurt her....more

title: This Cold Heaven: Seven Seasons in Greenland
author: Ehrlich, Gretel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My first reaction is an emotional one, a feeling of sadness at the loss of the traditional Eskimo culture, although I appreciate that there is an effoMy first reaction is an emotional one, a feeling of sadness at the loss of the traditional Eskimo culture, although I appreciate that there is an effort to keep the old ways alive and to teach these ways to the young generations. The author does not ignore the difficult aspects of the traditional life of subsistence hunters, which if the hunting is not good can mean starvation. Starvation can lead to the deaths of those who contribute the least and need the most, the children and old people, eating the dogs and even eating the people who have died. I don't know the extent to which the violence, domestic abuse and sexual abuse, which the author tells us are all too common today in the Inuit villages, existed in the time before the culture started to change due to alcohol and the introduction to modern life. The traditional life wasn't an easy life, that is without question, but it had beauty, organization, purpose and history. Now much of that is lost through a kind of purposelessness. As the author's friend, Hans Holm, states,"It is easier to be a loser now because they have exchanged some of the old ways for the Internet, the snow scooter, and, of course, the booze. So if you aren't technically trained or have only enough money for beer, then you have an excuse to fail. That was not possible before. Failure meant certain death. Now, too many people are not living in the old ways, making it with just a knife and a string and only eating seal."On the other side of the emotional spectrum, I find myself wishing to go to Greenland, to see and experience it, to ride a dogsled as the author did. I don't know about eating raw seal (apart from the kashrut issue), I would imagine that takes some serious getting used to. I could see myself having some problems; I'm too cold, there are seal guts and dog shit everywhere (actually the pictures of northern Greenland Inuit villages are very attractive), THAT'S the toilet?! I can't understand a word anyone is saying!! Nevertheless, my brain and heart are responding in a positive way to the idea of going to the northern Eskimo villages of Greenland. The author's descriptions created a longing in me for this. And looking at pictures on line made it even more so.There is so much to this book; politics, questions about the future for the Eskimo people, global warming's effect on the Arctic, the animal populations, global pollution. The writing is poetically beautiful, but it also historically, sociologically and politically interesting.Recommended....more

title: The Good Nurse: A True Story of Medicine, Madness, and Murder
author: Graeber, Charles*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a very intense account, horrifying and so terribly sad. Charles Cullen, for sixteen years, works in hospitals and commits murder repeatedly byThis is a very intense account, horrifying and so terribly sad. Charles Cullen, for sixteen years, works in hospitals and commits murder repeatedly by administering drugs that will kill at a high dose such as insulin and digoxin. Sometimes he would just inject IV bags with the killing drugs before they were designated for any particular patient. He didn't appear to hate anyone, he appeared to be a competent nurse. As complaints accrued against him at any given hospital they would ask him to leave but they would not pass on any warning to future employers. It was a CYA situation. This is what allowed the killing to go on for sixteen years. So sad; all the killings (and there may have been as many as 400), Charles Cullen himself and the pass the buck hospitals. Heartbreaking also was Amy's role in gathering the information to convict him. This is an excellent non-fiction book and I recommend it....more

Juliet is a Federal Marshal, much of her family is law enforcement. A neighbor of Ethan gets kidnapped while in Columbia and Ethan has to go get him out. Juliet has been threatened by a criminal she had put in jail and who has just been released. And then there is Juliet's vegan 17 year old niece who has a knack for wrong decisions. I thought she and Ham, the genius eccentric young man who was kidnapped in Columbia that Ethan had to rescue, belonged together. There are some conspiracy theories and some high level government stuff, I didn't follow it all that closely. I was more interested in Ethan. Juliet and Ethan become a couple and their cases become a couple, and everything ties together. Juliet's brother and a government executive are becoming a couple. I already mentioned that I thought Wendy the niece and Ham the genius should be a couple. The government and conspiracy stuff had me yawning.I just wanted to know what was going to happen with Ethan. title: Touching the Void: The True Story of One Man's Miraculous Survival
author: Simpson, Joe
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love this book. Such a plain statement, "I love this book", but it contains the total engagement of my heart and mind with Joe's story. Joe and SimoI love this book. Such a plain statement, "I love this book", but it contains the total engagement of my heart and mind with Joe's story. Joe and Simon are in the Peruvian Andes, young healthy experienced mountaineers, to climb the West Face of Suila Grande. They start out in high spirits but the climb on very treacherous terrain and the brutal weather are taking their toll. They make it to the summit, cross the ridge and start to head down but as they proceed Joe falls off a cliff and when he hits the ice at the base of this cliff he breaks his leg badly. I don't want to tell this story, it should be read in Joe's words, Joe's astoundingly beautiful prose that puts you right there with him as he struggles to survive. I cried with him, was breathless with fear for him, and celebrated his survival with tears of joy. Yes, I was that involved in this story. This is one of those books that I never want to part with....more

Who is responsible for all of these murders? Goodman and Bradley reluctantly team up to figure out what is going on.The book has the feel of being written by an older man, in fact the character Goodman is an older man suffering heart problems but he feels fortunate to have a younger woman as his lover helping ease the pain of divorce and a flagging libido. His older brother Stanley experiences another trauma in the school the boys go to after they are removed from the family home. It sears into him in a way that is heartbreaking. I do understand the 'hole in the world' concept being both an adopted child (even with excellent adoptive parents there is still a baby with a hole in her world where the birth mother is absent) and there is a hole in my world where my deceased son is absent from this world. title: Murder at Spouters Point        (Miranda Lewis Mysteries #3)
author: Wheeler, Leslie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Miranda is a white woman and Nate, her lover and partner, is Native American. It is already awkward for both of them to be with the family and friendsMiranda is a white woman and Nate, her lover and partner, is Native American. It is already awkward for both of them to be with the family and friends of the other, but when Miranda's friend's fiance is murdered and the suspicion falls on Nate's good friend in the Native community, then everyone has their racial hackles up. Hard to figure out what is going on when it becomes all about racial hostility rather than who killed whom. This affects even Miranda and Nate despite their feelings for each other. Two dead people and a dead dog. A tragic shipwreck. A homeless woman. A pow wow. And then we come to the conclusion and the answers to the questions about who did what. The last chapter in the book was my favorite, an ending that left me pleased and happy as a reader....more

title: Around Sarah's Table: Ten Hasidic Women Share Their Stories of Life, Faith, and Tradition
author: Zakutinsky, Rivka
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sarah hosts and leads a weekly Parsha class in her home. In a way that relates to the Parsha of the week each woman's story is told. Example: Parshas Sarah hosts and leads a weekly Parsha class in her home. In a way that relates to the Parsha of the week each woman's story is told. Example: Parshas Lech Lecha, Shaina's story is told. Each Parsha a different woman's story is told. This is how the book is organized and it works well.The authors also explain quite a bit of basic Judaism incorporated into the stories in a way that enhances them rather than interrupts them. I used to host a Parsha class in my home some years ago although it was taught by a Rabbi. Sarah's Table is idealized, at least compared to those groups I have belonged to, but not so much that it is unreal. What I mean by that is at Sarah's Table there is always an abundance of delicious home cooked food, the women all get along and seem close to each other, no one complains (well there is one token complainer at Sarah's table), takes the group off topic or expresses negativity. All the women have problems they are struggling with but everyone's attitude toward their problems is very pious. A lot of Chasidic women are like this, it is true, but this is an idealized version that leaves out the gossip, cliques, petty disagreements, complaints and other negative behaviors that are part of most women's groups and only the most determinedly pious are able to avoid.I enjoyed reading it although it is a little boring. Learning Parsha is actually more exciting than is expressed in this book if you have a learned and passionate-about-Torah teacher. That is my personal preference though; to learn Parsha rather than to belong to a women's group....more

Erin Gilbert and Steve Sullivan are interior designers in the same town and they are at odds with each other. But they are hired to participate in a contest against each other. Erin is to design a bedroom in one house, Steve is to design the den in a house down the street. This is a mystery so obviously someone dies, then someone else dies. Every character living in this neighborhood is a potential killer. And to add to the confusion, Erin finds a baby picture of herself in the wall of the house she is working on. Her adoptive mother told her never to research her birth parents. In fact, it was her dying wish. But how could she resist finding out if one of the nuts who live in this neighborhood is her birth mother or birth father. title: Black's Law: A Criminal Lawyer Reveals His Defense Strategies in Four Cliffhanger Cases
author: Black, Roy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I found this book fascinating. Miami defense lawyer Roy Black shares four of his cases with us, each case quite different than the others. The first iI found this book fascinating. Miami defense lawyer Roy Black shares four of his cases with us, each case quite different than the others. The first is about a black 20 year old shot in an arcade by a Spanish cop. Miami goes crazy; we'll burn the city down if he is acquitted, we shall overcome etc. Roy Black wades into the furor and wins an acquittal. There are some riots but Miami doesn't burn, it is still there. The next case involves the cold blooded murder of two people by a man who is found cowering in a hole with the money he stole from the people he killed. We hear about the mental illness of the defendant and the life he had as a child and the severe beatings he was given which may have given him brain damage. Roy Black gets him acquitted. The third case involves a young man who shoots his girlfriend, leaves her body in her car at a drive through ATM. He claims it was an accident and he was so upset and he couldn't find the hospital ER and he just panicked. Roy Black gets him acquitted. The fourth case is a federal case against a Cuban banker accused of laundering drug money. Terrifying the power the federal prosecutor's office has. And all the drug dealers they give reduced sentences to in exchange for information. As Roy Black says, powerful inducement to lie. Roy Black gets him acquitted but the government goes after him again and this time won't let him hire Roy Black! This is what Roy Black says about being a defense lawyer."When most people see me on the nightly news, I am striding into a courtroom beside a person who has been charged with an awful crime: murder, money laundering, rape at a historic mansion. Time and again I hear friends ask me, "How could you defend him?" Or: "Certainly he must have done something or he wouldn't have gotten in trouble, right?"The answer is one that comes out of hard experience in the courts. Ours is an adversary system of justice. This means we determine truth through testing both sides of the story at a trial, not by means of a sixty-second news clip or a talk-radio rant or the latest CNN poll. We have INALIENABLE RIGHTS, meaning ones our government can't take away. Rights are not self-executing. The don't exist unless you have a lawyer to enforce them. Article 125 of the Constitution of the U.S.S.R. issued by Stalin in 1936 provided that "the citizens ...are guaranteed by law a) freedom of speech b) freedom of the press c) freedom of assembly including the holding of mass meetings and d) freedom of street processions and demonstrations." But these were just so many words, because Stalin did not provide for attorneys independent of state control to speak for those rights vigorously. He did not offer his people our crucial Sixth Amendment, which allows the accused to "enjoy...the assistance of counsel for his defense." Lawyers are the ones who transform abstract rights into reality."I recommend this book.Upgrading my rating of this book because it is intelligent, thought provoking and stayed bright in my memory while so many other books were quickly forgotten....more

review: The writing is so beautiful, so elegant....I'm not sure how this story turned out to be kind of ho-hum. Despite the story itself, Sherlock himself is The writing is so beautiful, so elegant....I'm not sure how this story turned out to be kind of ho-hum. Despite the story itself, Sherlock himself is fascinating. I think we readers study Sherlock with the intensity that Sherlock studies crime scenes. The story opens with Sherlock Holmes in a funk, using cocaine in lieu of anything else to occupy his mind. But then there is a knock upon the door! A young woman comes in and explains the strange case of her father's disappearance; her receipt of several valuable pearls and a request to meet a mysterious someone and to bring with her two companions. So off they go. The mystery involves a treasure taken from India and all the machinations of those who would possess the treasure. We get a little bit of happiness with the romance that develops between Dr. Watson and the young Miss Morstan. Things happen quickly; I like you and you like me, let's marry. Then there is the casual racial superiority. Should I open the can of worms and call this story innocently racist, a product of the times?...more

title: Careless in Red        (Inspector Lynley, #15)
author: George, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Obviously I had missed a few books in the series as I had no idea about the huge, life-changing loss that Inspector Lynley suffered. The start of thisObviously I had missed a few books in the series as I had no idea about the huge, life-changing loss that Inspector Lynley suffered. The start of this book finds him walking the Cornish coast; filthy, unshaven, just walking, walking, walking in a world of hurt and grief. Even in the state he is in he sees something crumpled at the base of a cliff, and the something turns out to be the body of a young man who fell while abseiling. Lynley breaks into the nearest cottage in order to make a call. There is no phone but the woman who owns the cottage comes home and finds this scary looking stranger in her house. He tells her what he found and they go to look together and then she brings him to the pub to make a call. Hence, both of them are suspects. The story is interesting. A couple of themes run through it; grief and the process of moving on, or not; sexual promiscuity and whether that is a strength or a weakness, a preference or a sickness and if a sickness, when does it cross the line into sickness; the relationship between fathers and sons and the difficulties in growing up and meeting the expectations of parents; the gulf between the the social classes and whether that gulf can be bridged or not. There is also the excitement of surfing; not something I've ever wanted to do but I am kind of in awe of the whole sport. At 721 pages it is pretty long, but it reads quickly. I had a good idea of who the murderer was and I was correct, but the reveal was very well done....more

review: I very rarely quit on a book, but I am quitting this one. I read 57 pages, struggling to make sense of what he was saying. It is written in a very unrI very rarely quit on a book, but I am quitting this one. I read 57 pages, struggling to make sense of what he was saying. It is written in a very unreal way; for example the same scene written again and again, changing each time in some way. It is hard to tell if the main character is dreaming, mixing past, present and future, or hallucinating. There is also a lot of testing the boundaries of reality; if a tree falls in the forest kind of thing. It is a combination of wandering bewildered in someone else's dream thoughts, and being in a philosophical debate while on drugs. This is the paragraph that finally made me quit:"Soundlessness surely is almost never found in the natural world. Deep quiet is in fact made up of various small sounds and voices. But perhaps it can happen that this profound hush will through some chance occurrence-maybe a tiny sound or voice- suddenly veer toward the infinite boundary of soundlessness, those countless minute sounds cancelling one another into nothing."OK, that is just not for me. For someone else surely, but not for me....more

title: An Unexpected Light: Travels in Afghanistan
author: Elliot, Jason
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is what I wrote when I was about a quarter into it:An Unexpected Light: Travels in Afghanistan by Jason Elliot. It was published in 1999 when theThis is what I wrote when I was about a quarter into it:An Unexpected Light: Travels in Afghanistan by Jason Elliot. It was published in 1999 when the Taliban was first coming into power. It is interesting, although it is sort of the hunky-dory version of his trip across Afghanistan by foot, horse, truck. He has a guide for some of it but mostly he is an Englishman with rudimentary Persian (at least in the beginning) traveling on his own and getting by on his wits and his trust in fate. It is interesting for sure.Then after I finished the book I wrote the rest of this :What I mean by hunky-dory, is it seems he makes an effort to tell us the good things and put all of his experiences into some kind of positive light. The more unpleasant things are briefly mentioned, usually with a self-deprecating sense of humor, so one kind of dismiss them. I think that this is because there is so much negative opinion about Afghanistan already that he is trying not to add to it.I found the book became more intense as it continued, and sad. I found myself repeating what one of the residents of Afghanistan says, "Why Afghanistan?" One can't help but feel heartbroken at the destruction of Afghanistan. He published this in 1999. People were hoping that war would end and that the Taliban would just disappear or something. No such thing, right? Why did we declare war on Afghanistan after 9/11? What a betrayal of a country that thought we were allies! The Taliban were giving refuge to Osama bin Laden, but to declare war on the country? The US evidently had a significant role in arming and supporting the formation of the Taliban. The people who perpetrated 9/11 were Saudi. Did we declare war on Saudi Arabia? No we did not. Maybe that would have endangered the flow of oil. Oh, I am plenty confused. But I am heartbroken for the people of Afghanistan. The Russians, the British, the U.S., the various groups vying for power within the country, the Taliban. Will Afghanistan ever see peace? So this book is written by a unaffiliated British traveler to Afghanistan. Some of his writing is brilliant, very funny. Some of the political and religious opinions he expresses are slightly confused as he tries to avoid taking sides or expressing strong opinions. I bookmarked a lot to share but in the end I just can't, I'm not even sure it matters. The book takes an emotional bite out of the reader and like the author at the end, I "began to weep". ...more

He broke up with her, she left town and she hasn't seen or spoken to him in ten years. Then, ping, she gets an email inviting her to an old friend's "hen" weekend. Nora hasn't seen this friend for years, they haven't been in touch, why would she be invited? She isn't invited to the wedding. But another friend, Nina, says she is going and so Nora agrees. That Nora agrees is the weak point of the book in my opinion. But she and Nina drive out to some weird modern monstrosity of a housewith huge glass windows overlooking the forest in the middle of nowhere, with no cell phone reception, natch. It is a small group of very mis-matched friends stuck for the weekend. And, gut-wrenching news, the bride to be is marrying Nora's old boyfriend. What will happen now? Tense and dramatic. review: It hardly made sense! It had all the right ingredients, but mixed up, out of order and dead ending into.....what? I kept thinking it was going to pullIt hardly made sense! It had all the right ingredients, but mixed up, out of order and dead ending into.....what? I kept thinking it was going to pull together but it never did. The bad guy was so scary and then he runs off like a scared rabbit at the shake of a stick. What were the connections between the incidents in Ireland? Who was Keira's father? Is it just me who doesn't know? Who is the guy who keeps walking out of the mist? Was that disappearing and reappearing angel statue a Wal-Mart prop? Frustrating story. I couldn't even classify it. Was it romance? a mystery? a paranormal story? a serial killer story? It just didn't work. Maybe I missed some vital connections that were actually present. In any case, sorry! title: The Bell Jar
author: Plath, Sylvia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sylvia Plath was intelligent to a self-destructive fault. She could see through a lot of the cultural trappings while still wanting to be part of it aSylvia Plath was intelligent to a self-destructive fault. She could see through a lot of the cultural trappings while still wanting to be part of it all. But being part of it didn't seem to be a choice she could make. She could see the futility which is never good for a person's mental health. She is a high achiever; one of these girls with excellent grades and many awards. But she feels socially inept and unattractive. When people did like her she could see all their faults and couldn't like them back. The only person she liked was her snarky, bitchy, slutty friend who was always getting her into trouble, usually involving alcohol and men, although Sylvia didn't sleep with the men. She seemed to find everyone either ridiculous or disgusting. There is a possibility that she was raped while she was in New York. Putting together several scenes in the book and the aftermath, I think it is a very strong possibility.When she is 19 she has a breakdown and tries to commit suicide. She is committed, given shock treatment, and seemingly recovers.That is the point at which the book ends but I looked her up to see what happens next. She works, she teaches, she marries and has two children. She is also sick a lot and her marriage falls apart.Sadly, she does kill herself eventually, after the book is published. She may have been upset by the s the book was receiving. She was so smart but full of self doubt, a difficult combination. But I think she probably never truly gave up the idea of suicide completely. like leaving her options open. After her husband's infidelity (that may be plural, I don't know) and their separation I would imagine it beckoned, this suicide option. She did contact a psychiatrist evidently but didn't alarm anyone. This time she successfully hid what she was thinking and kept working and caring for her kids until she succeeded in her suicide. Why a suicide picks one moment and not another only the suicide knows. I was glad that she protected her babies from the gas she used to kill herself, but it didn't protect them from growing up without a mother. Her husband's mistress also commit suicide and killed their child as well. From what I read it is thought to be a copycat suicide of Sylvia's. Sylvia's adult son also commit suicide. He suffered from depression like his mother. From what I've read about suicide in general there may be genetic predisposition, copycat suicide, and just the phenomenon of suicide passing through families, friends and communities like a contagion.If I made any mistakes in this , getting something wrong about Sylvia's history or personality, I apologize. ...more

review: The history of beer in America and all the crazy stuff that gets done to sell it, all the in-fighting, all the idiotic decisions and lack of common s The history of beer in America and all the crazy stuff that gets done to sell it, all the in-fighting, all the idiotic decisions and lack of common sense, all the bigger than life personalities of the founders and owners of beer companies. It is a lot of fun to read. Personally, I don't drink beer or any alcohol. My last beer was probably in high school during the mid 1970's. I think it was Coors. I also don't watch sports, so I am unfamiliar with beer commercials. If you had asked me, before I read this book, for a beer slogan I probably could have come up with "This Bud's for you". So I am someone who really does not know beer. But that didn't stop me from enjoying this book, it is interesting reading. Statistics wise it doesn't look like things are so different now than when the book was published in 1997. Excluding microbrews, you still have Budweiser at the top. Bud Light is the best selling beer in America, Budweiser is third best selling, and they are still fooling around with ICE and lime flavors. Coors Light is the second best selling beer and Miller Light is the fourth best selling beer. Corona comes in fifth. On the list of the top twenty we still see Michelob Ultra, Heineken of 3 types, Miller High Life and Pabst Blue Ribbon. Lots of microbrews around which sound interesting. And even gluten free beer which doesn't have all bad s. Interesting world of beers out there. ...more

title: How Starbucks Saved My Life: A Son of Privilege Learns to Live Like Everyone Else
author: Gill, Michael Gates*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I liked this book in a lot of ways because I am a fan of Starbucks. My own experiences with Starbucks coincide with what the author tells us. When my I liked this book in a lot of ways because I am a fan of Starbucks. My own experiences with Starbucks coincide with what the author tells us. When my son passed away in 2004 I struggled to control my depression. I was often in Starbucks, drinking coffee and crying. I was given extra free shots of espresso and even free cups of coffee as the staff tried to do what they could to ease my pain. When traveling with my special needs son, who has to eat on a schedule and a special diet, we have always been able to take our own food into Starbucks and sit at a table and eat. I usually tried to buy at least one drink, but we were never challenged if we did not. And yes, Starbucks is renowned for their clean public bathrooms! In Times Square and have to use the bathroom? Find the Starbucks of course. Starbucks is, to me, a cultural comfort. I was so surprised when I went to New England and all they had were Dunkin' Doughnuts! My GPS could locate them all! And I wasn't looking for them. My experience of Boston was getting lost, nowhere to get gas, nowhere to park, and nowhere to go to the bathroom. I squirmed in discomfort in Boston. I needed Starbucks!!On the down side, with the book, not with Starbucks, is the author's affair. It gave me what I call "bad brain", meaning a depressive sinkhole. Maybe other long-term married women in their late 50's didn't feel the horror of it. He becomes impotent with his wife but has no problem with a younger and most likely better looking woman. Maybe other women can read that and not feel threatened, not feel ugly, useless and undesirable, not feel redundant, not feel that their husband would probably prefer a younger and better looking woman. We value youth and beauty in this culture. It didn't help that the author came across as a nice guy. Maybe he had cheated before this but it only came to divorce because he fathered a child with the woman he was cheating with. I don't know. But, like I said, it gave me a case of "bad brain". I couldn't forgive Mike for it. I was happy when he got his job at Starbucks and that he had success with it. I wanted that for him with most of my heart. But I never lost a touch of the feeling of, you bastard, I hope you suffered....more

As an adopted child I felt many of the same things that her mother did; abandonment, wondering what was wrong with me or with the family that I was born to, feeling alone and needing to create the family that I could call my own, the strange question of who am I, what race am I if my blood is one thing but my family is another? title: Rescuing Sprite: A Dog Lover's Story of Joy and Anguish
author: Levin, Mark R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I appreciate that Mark Levin and his family loved their dog Sprite and suffered when the dog became ill and they made the decision to have him put to I appreciate that Mark Levin and his family loved their dog Sprite and suffered when the dog became ill and they made the decision to have him put to sleep. As a book, it becomes somewhat repetitive as Mark tells us many times how much he loves Sprite and how he is suffering both the potential loss and then the actual loss, and how he second=guesses the decisions he made in regards to Sprite's health care and the decision to put the dog to sleep. Mark agonizes, I sympathize. That doesn't make it a great book. It is simplistic in its grammatical construction and short on substance. The substance is Mark Levin has a broken heart. As someone who has suffered a broken heart over the accidental death of one of my children, well I understand a broken heart and that it does not act logically nor respond to the dictates or logic of others. But there are only so many ways to say I am bereaved, and only so long that your heartbreak will hold the attention of the reader. So I sympathized but found my attention drifting as I wondered about his good friend Rush Limbaugh, and I pondered the ethical pros and cons of putting an animal to sleep.  I only caught a couple of Rush Limbaugh's shows back in the 1990's. I remember his slying saying that there was a new dog in the White House and up came a picture of Chelsea Clinton who must have been about 13 at the time. I thought that was so cruel that I never watched another of his shows and I haven't liked him since, although I read another book where a good friend of his talks about how kind and thoughtful Rush Limbaugh was to him in his time of need. I can't remember who that was now. No matter. So I am willing to concede that Rush Limbaugh can be a good friend, despite his cruelty to a young teenage girl on National Television.  i felt the pain and guilt of Mr. Levin in putting Sprite to sleep. How easy we use that euphemism, "put to sleep". i can't judge, but i hope that decision will not be mine to make, ever. I'm pretty sure I would not choose to put to sleep. When I was a young child our cat was nearly cut in half by the fan belt of our car. My dad was going to shoot him but we all screamed so much that my mom rushed him to the vet. Eight hours of surgery and weeks of recovery saved his life. He lived until I was in college when he finally died a natural death from cancer. i just don't know that we have the wisdom to know when life should be ended.  These were some of my thoughts while reading about dear Sprite, his good friend Pepsi, and the Levin family who loves their dogs. ...more

title: The Witch of Lime Street: Séance, Seduction, and Houdini in the Spirit World
author: Jaher, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After World War l, and the great loss of life that occurred, there was a resurgence of interest in the possibility of contacting the dead. UnderstandaAfter World War l, and the great loss of life that occurred, there was a resurgence of interest in the possibility of contacting the dead. Understandable. I lost a son, I understand completely.But, OMG, the weirdness of seances, with the levitating tables, the floating musical instruments, and worst and weirdest of all, the "ectoplasm", which, according to Google definitions, is "a supernatural viscous substance that is supposed to exude from the body of a medium during a spiritualistic trance and form the material for the manifestation of spirits." It says "any orifice" so I guess the mouth, ears and nose are common orifices from which to exude ectoplasm. Margery's orifice of choice was often her vagina. Well, never mind that because the ectoplasm thing is the fakest part of a common con, imo. Are all mediums frauds? Or are there genuine mediums who can contact the dead? It is an interesting question. I once went to an event for the families of the victims of a multiple shooting tragedy. My son didn't die in this shooting, but he did die and he kept coming through the strongest for this medium who was at the event. Well that sounded just like him and I was shaken. Was that true? I don't know. So, this question about mediums and contacting the dead? That is the question that a panel of scientists and experts are given to answer for Scientific American. The panel includes Houdini who is quite certain that all the mediums are fraudulent, as he has been in the magic and illusion business all of his life and knows all the tricks. The panel interviews and attends the seances of a number of mediums but the medium who they really can't figure out is "The Witch of Lime Street" given the public name of Margery, although actually her name is Mina. She is quite an interesting character, a very charismatic and seductive character. Most of the men go into a deeper trance than Margery and believe her. Houdini doesn't believe her, although he is drawn to her, but he sets out to prove she is a fraud and that all mediums are frauds. Show time! For whatever reason, I was very fond of Houdini and felt protective towards him. The hatred expressed towards him from the people who are in the spirit movement was shocking. They are vicious in attacking him as a Jew, and enjoy predicting his death. It was really sad to see. Houdini is usually the gentleman and never a complainer. He went after the mediums with a vengeance because he couldn't abide the fraud, but could he prove that Margery was 100% fraudulent? I received this book from Goodreads as a winner in a book giveaway. Thank you!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this story, or maybe I should say, I was in love with this story, I was in love with Joe and his eccentric ways. I loved the gardening, the w I loved this story, or maybe I should say, I was in love with this story, I was in love with Joe and his eccentric ways. I loved the gardening, the wine making, the magic. I was in love with the bond of love between old man Joe and young man Jay. This is a book about the young man growing into maturity, into a man who can love a woman and a child and protect what he values. Growing into a man who can accept the weaknesses and mistakes of others, accept those same things in himself, and figure out how to make things better. It is about an old man passing on his skills and dreams to the next generation. It is about the value of the past to the creation of the future; respect and love for the land and diversity of species. Although the story has many fantastical elements the only thing that struck a somewhat odd note for me was Marise's past. Lovely woman, but more than her share of conveniently dead in her life and rather iffy taste in men, although let's hope that we are looking at a brighter future for her. Truly, I just loved this book. For me, it was better than Chocolat and better than Five Quarters of an Orange. I don't drink wine but I related absolutely to the wine in this story; to the stories it tells, to the stories it releases. Sometimes I want to hug a book. This is one of those books. I haven't yet looked to see how others liked this book, but I recommend it. ...more

See, there is nothing cozy about murder or the heartbreaking reasons that might lead a person to commit murder. So I have a basic disagreement with the cozy mystery premise. In this book, someone is trying to kill Breanne Summour, Matteo's fiance. The murderer kills two innocent women by mistake in his attempts to kill Breanne. I didn't find that entertaining, and I certainly did not find it cozy. I also find Matteo's sleeping with every woman disturbing and disgusting. What I did like, besides the coffee, was the idea of who got killed during the last dramatic scene at the wedding. A middle-aged, homeless alcoholic dies in his sleeping bag on the beach one night. The only thing he has in his pocket is Kinsey Millhone's name and phone number. But Kinsey has never seen him before in her life. Curious, she goes to talk to his homeless friends down on the strip of beach where they lived. One thing leading to another, she finds out that the man is related to her and has left her all his money, which is a goodly sum. His kids are none too happy with this turn of events. Sliding over to another thread of the story; a down on his luck, unscrupulous PI, that Kinsey has known for some years, is found murdered in the local bird refuge. Add in a guest appearance by Dietz (PI, body guard, and former lover of Kinsey) and a few new characters (including the most adorable kitten Ed) and some great old characters, and the story works itself out nicely....more

Judaism acknowledges that sexual boredom can be a pA short little book, a pep talk really, about the importance of keeping the laws of family purity. Judaism acknowledges that sexual boredom can be a problem in marriage. The laws of family purity require a couple to separate for 12 or 14 days a month and then for the woman to immerse in the mikveh before resuming her intimate relationship with her husband. The laws are complex and this book does not cover those laws in any detail at all, but it does talk about how family purity keeps the freshness of desire in the marriage. I'd say that this is true if both partners are completely and totally dedicated to both the complex laws of family purity and to the sanctity of their marriage within the greater context of religiously observant Jewish life. ...more

title: Lord of the Flies
author: Golding, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a very powerful and disturbing story about a group of British school boys, aged about 6 to 12, marooned on a tropical island. At first it is aThis is a very powerful and disturbing story about a group of British school boys, aged about 6 to 12, marooned on a tropical island. At first it is a big adventure but as the time passes it becomes less an adventure and more a nightmare.The boys choose as their leader a good looking, charming and decent boy who tries his best to get them organized to keep a fire going so the smoke might be seen, build shelters, hunt food and keep a society of rules and order. Trouble is visible right from the beginning with another boy with leadership abilities, a brutal and intelligent boy who craves to be in control. So there you have your tug of war between good and evil. I will call these two leaders 'light' and 'dark'. Just like creation right? OK, so dark leader wants to hunt, and he takes 'his' boys and they are the hunters. Light leader doesn't mind this but he is having trouble getting 'his' boys to work, they want to play all the time. Dark leader is having trouble killing the pigs of the island until he puts on paint, then, masked, he is able to kill. Trouble explodes between the two leaders when the hunters, who are in charge of the fire as well, let the fire go out while they are hunting. Missed opportunity for rescue perhaps. Dark leader is angry and gathers 'his' boys more tightly together, paints them all and they go out for a hunt. They kill a nursing sow most brutally and rejoice in the killing, performing dances re-enacting the kill. Dark leader, through his ability to offer food, disguise, hunting and dancing, is able to gather all but five of the boys to his side. He sets up a different camp and, ..... I don't want to say more, it just gets ugly in a way that is inevitable and tragic. I was reminded of The Hunger Games but this was more to the point of the condition of the world and what happens to us in the constant struggle between light and dark, how, in our struggle for survival, we pick our leaders, and how otherwise good people end up doing evil things. ...more

title: Mister Pip
author: Jones, Lloyd
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Heartbreaking. This story is fiction, but the place and the war going on are not fictional. The setting is Bougainville Island in the early 1990's aftHeartbreaking. This story is fiction, but the place and the war going on are not fictional. The setting is Bougainville Island in the early 1990's after the blockade. The rebels are in the jungle, the red-skins (from Papua New Guinea - as far as I could tell from reading about this conflict on Wikipedia) were fighting the rebels and the villagers were caught between, unable to get off the island and victims of both the rebels and the redskins. We meet Matilda and her mother living in a small village on the island, and living among them, a white man married to an islander. The white man is a bit of a mystery and a spectacle, but he reaches out and offers to teach the children. He does this in the most extraordinary way; by reading Great Expectations by Charles Dickens aloud to them. The children, especially Matilda, are caught up in the story and learn a way to leave their lives temporarily through the words of a book. The white man's name is Mr. Watts but he becomes Mr. Pip for the red-skins who are demanding to know who this Pip is. Pip is the character from Great Expectations but this explanation is not believed leading to terrible consequences. Mr. Watts also invites the parents into the classroom to teach what they know. It is a remarkable classroom.I was slow in reading this book because I was afraid of the inevitable violence. Long after everything is over and Matilda lives in Australia she goes to find out more about Mr. Watts. It is surprising to learn what she finds out and the understanding it brings to the whole picture of Mr. Watts. And Matilda, I am glad she makes the decision she does at the end of the book....more

title: The Dovekeepers
author: Hoffman, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a fictional story based on the history of the Jews on Masada in 73 CE. I have been to Masada and like everywhere in Israel, the past lives andThis is a fictional story based on the history of the Jews on Masada in 73 CE. I have been to Masada and like everywhere in Israel, the past lives and breathes. The past is the past but it is also the present, you can feel it. It is incredibly powerful and very moving. For me, the most powerful experience on Masada was watching a scribe work. The Roman Empire is gone, the Jews are still here. Kol Hakavod! Chazak! Chazak! Venischazeik! (Be strong! Be strong! And may we be strengthened!) For anyone who does not know the story of Masada; Jews had taken refuge on Masada as the Roman Empire took Jerusalem and enslaved/and or killed all the Jews of the lands they took. When all the other Jews had been conquered, the Romans of the 10th Legion gathered to take Masada. When the Jews, who had fought very bravely, knew that the battle was over and they were to be enslaved or killed, they made the decision to take their own lives. It was done systematically by slitting the throats with the last person slitting his own. I can 't judge that, I don't know if they did right or wrong or what I would do in that situation. I can only love them, grieve for them, and carry them into the future. As for the fictional story; I have a very serious problem with adultery and this story has quite a bit of it. It made the reading bitter for me. Also, the story contains idol worship and witchcraft by a Jewish character that she calls the Witch of Moav. I don't know the history of these things in Judaism and was a little uncomfortable with it and confused by it. Idol worship is strictly forbidden by Jewish law and I think that bird bone divination and the casting of spells are considered witchcraft and are also forbidden. ...more

review: This is Liza Campbell's autobiography and she is mainly writing about her father. He is a total pig; maybe he didn't start out that way. In the beginnThis is Liza Campbell's autobiography and she is mainly writing about her father. He is a total pig; maybe he didn't start out that way. In the beginning he is eccentric (in that way of British nobility) and casually cruel. He is married to a very nice woman who loves him. She has five children with him and he becomes more and more difficult. He is an alcoholic and a drug user, he is nearly always committing adultery. His wife becomes a shell of a woman; only maintained by her good manners and breeding. He kicks her out eventually after doing his best to destroy her. He is cruel to the children; mainly with words. He is incredibly, horribly irresponsible with his wealth and properties.Her father's name is Hugh and this is what she writes about him:"Hugh had neither earned nor bought Cawdor. It had taken no talent to receive all this extraordinary privilege other than being born the correct sex. These possessions were entrusted to his care, but Cawdor was not his. Not only had he shafted his own son in the will rewrite, he had shafted the previous twenty-four generations. This stony treasure had survived six hundred years of wild Scottish history, including a crucial battle fought on its doorstep, yet it took only one drunken rake to piss it away. Hugh's life achievements amounted to a list of perfidies: demolishing Stackpole; selling Golden Grove and all the Welsh land; brutalizing his first wife; rebuffing his extended family; discarding friendships like used tissues; indulging in fabulously injudicious sexual adventrues; destroying his health; and then revealing his most wretched act only after his final exit."His second wife is a total complete horrible bitch. The only thing good Hugh ever did was to marry his first wife. She must be the reason that his son Colin turned out as good as he did. I do realize I am reading one person's viewpoint, but it is condemning. ...more

review: This is a fictionalized (I hope) version of a true story. The true story is that for four years a father and young daughter lived in a lean to that thThis is a fictionalized (I hope) version of a true story. The true story is that for four years a father and young daughter lived in a lean to that they built in Forest Park in Portland, Ore. until one day some extreme joggers saw them and worried because the child was young. They called the police which resulted in a lot of attention which the father and child did not want. The child was well cared for, very well educated and showed no sign of abuse or neglect whatsoever. Her father was a Vietnam vet and was proficient in living off the grid. The police were kind enough to let them stay together (I'm not sure if this lifestyle was illegal or just eccentric - do homeless people in cities have their kids taken away from them?) and a place was found for them to work and live. They stayed awhile and then disappeared. The father did not like the media attention and thought they were being spied upon via helicopter, raising questions as to the mental health of the father. In this fictionalized version there are questions as to the true parentage of the child, how the father obtains the child and the decisions he makes in his deteriorating mental condition. Then there is the girl herself and her decisions and viewpoint of the world. Back to the non-fictionalized story: As far as I can tell no one knows what happened to them after they left the home found for them by social services. Gone since 2004. ...more

title: In My Blood: Six Generations of Madness and Desire in an American Family
author: Sedgwick, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I liked the history starting with the Revolutionary War and the years afterward, which were not all peace and happiness for our country. The prominentI liked the history starting with the Revolutionary War and the years afterward, which were not all peace and happiness for our country. The prominent personalities, the machinations, the in-fighting, the corruption, and the alliances in our new government, the interpretations of the Constitution and Law and how these things played out in our new country, told through the story of the early Sedgwick family, made for fascinating reading. The story kind of goes downhill from there as the personalities in the family become less influential in American history and diluted as personalities in general. The story John Sedgwick is trying to tell is the story of the strain of manic depression that runs through his family history and through his own veins. But being a woman nearing sixty, the story I kept hearing was the one of the women who were no longer loved once they reached fifty or so, whose husband's left them alone on one pretext or another while they gallivanted around for politics, war or work and enjoyed themselves while their wives pined and wasted away; unloved, depressed and often eventually mentally ill. Oftentimes for the women this was preceded by the grief of losing children. That was incredibly sad to me. Not that the men didn't suffer from mental illness, many of them did to one degree or another. Manic behavior and dementia were not uncommon as men dealt with the stress of making money and maintaining status, while also having a predilection for manic depression. I was kind of tickled to run into Opal Whiteley again (I had read a book about her at an earlier time) and have a background in which to place Ellery Sedgwick as he was the editor of The Atlantic magazine who published her diary. It was like running into people that I already know. What I didn't like was the way the story seems to run too long. There were points when I was just tired of it. I also did not find the Sedgwick propensity toward manic depression truly that unusual, except for Francis and the terrible result his mental illness had on his children. What family history is "normal"? I realize that a lot of them were under psychiatric care; but they had the money for the care and the connections to follow the latest trends in mental health. Overall it was interesting and I am glad that I read it. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't start listening to SRV until 2013 but when I did, I was stunned, overwhelmed with emotion, addicted and obsessed, finding comfort and soul heI didn't start listening to SRV until 2013 but when I did, I was stunned, overwhelmed with emotion, addicted and obsessed, finding comfort and soul healing in his music. How could I have not known about this music when he was alive?! I used to listen to BB King, Aretha Franklin, CCR, Canned Heat, Johnny Cash, Jimmi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, The Who, The Doors, Alan Jackson...What I am trying to say is I listen to music, I love music. How could I have not known about the best and most passionate Blues guitarist in the world? When I go to yin yoga they play some new age ooooooo type music. I hate it! What relaxes me and soothes me is SRV. I listen obsessively. In my car I am almost always playing Guitar Hurricane, Letter to My Girlfriend, Cross-Cut Saw, Pride and Joy, Voodoo Child, Little Wing and my favorites The Sky is Crying and The Things That I Used To Do (and everything else he ever performed that I can get on CD). I especially love his performance of The Things That I Used To Do on the last concert he gave. Just gives me chills. I have also watched videos where he is interacting with fans; how kind he is. He has a sweetness, he gives off a loving energy. I love the man. So this book, I was bound to love it too, it is about SRV. I laughed and cried my way through it. His antics just kept me laughing and his strength in quitting his addiction, and bringing friends and family on the journey to sobriety, just blew me away. The ending was hard. I'm still a mess from reading it. I earmarked so many passages in this book to share in this , I couldn't possibly put them in, way too many. I'll just settle for the last thing I bookmarked, "Joe Cook kept thinking back to the time he got a telephone call from his famous nephew. "Where you at?" Joe asked him. "I'm in a plane thirty-five thousand feet over Dallas, just callin' to say "Hi," Stevie said."That is Stevie. I'm laughing and crying. Rave On, Stevie Ray Vaughan!...more

title: The Sum of Our Days
author: Allende, Isabel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I liked House of Spirits very much. This? Well this is a memoir, written some years after the death of her daughter Paula. It is sometimes written in I liked House of Spirits very much. This? Well this is a memoir, written some years after the death of her daughter Paula. It is sometimes written in the form of a dialogue with Paula. It has the feel of confession, apology and regret; not uncommon in memoirs written in later life. But Isabel Allende is such a firebrand, such a fighter, a real spitfire that she doesn't sink into it. She basically calls up her tough attitude and gathers her family and imposes both her will and her intense love to do her best to keep everyone together. As an author she can be very funny, but she is also a bereaved parent and that unbearable sorrow runs through the book like an underground river, occasionally surfacing but mostly just below the surface of Isabel's personality and writing.I can't say I enjoyed reading it as much as her fiction. Everyone's life is somewhat boring to other people unless it is written in the form of entertainment. Isabel is entertaining, but she is also explaining, confessing and purging. The best part of this book is Willie, her husband. Their love story is beautiful, a real story of love and hope, not a youthful fairy tale, but a real love of life, pain and age. At the end I felt it was a memoir of the beauty, fragility and durability of love....more

title: Proof of Heaven
author: Alexander, Eben
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Dr. Eben Alexander mysteriously contracts bacterial meningitis and spends a week in a deep coma. The chances of his survival are super slim to none. WDr. Eben Alexander mysteriously contracts bacterial meningitis and spends a week in a deep coma. The chances of his survival are super slim to none. While in the coma he experiences some interesting phenomena; a Near Death Experience. Despite all medical predictions and statistical chances for survival he comes back, functional and not in the vegetative state predicted if he did survive, and he has a story to tell.Do I believe that Eben is telling the truth as he remembers it? Yes. I believe in God and life after death, so why not this version? This was his experience and I don't judge it. His work as a neurosurgeon, status as a scientist and disinterest and disbelief in the spiritual aspect of existence before his NDE increased the dichotomy between his life and beliefs before and after and made his story more interesting than it might otherwise have been. The fact of the miracle of his survival is certainly enough to give a reader pause. That alone said something is going on here beyond a purely physical event.I do find fascinating the adoption part of Eben's past and how that played into, well everything about who Eben is. As an adopted child myself I do feel that there are parallels in my emotional experience of being adopted to Eben's experience. I wonder about those seven years between the rejection by his birth mother and his NDE. Those years seem key to his illness and his NDE. I guess I just want to understand Eben's psychology more than he offered here, and he did actually offer quite a bit.The only parts of the book I didn't care for were the parts where he promotes a meditation method and the organization that promotes and practices it; and the promotion of his own organization, an NDE non-profit. I didn't want to be sold on something or channeled into being involved in an organization. I just wanted to read Eben's experience. But maybe these promotions provide value to other people who have experienced NDE, although I always feel the "that happened to me too" factor can reduce any validity to an NDE story. It is like leading the witness....more

title: The Shed That Fed a Million Children: The Extraordinary Story of Mary’s Meals
author: MacFarlane-Barrow, Magnus*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Magnus Macfarlane-Barrow is raised in a religious Catholic family in Scotland. When he is a teenager he and his siblings go to Bosnia as there is a reMagnus Macfarlane-Barrow is raised in a religious Catholic family in Scotland. When he is a teenager he and his siblings go to Bosnia as there is a report that the Virgin Mary has appeared to some children there and has been giving them messages. --to me that sounds weird and possibly scary, but the good that came of this is remarkable. Magnus is very moved by this event, his whole family is. His parents, who already run a guest house, open their home and property as a religious retreat. Magnus becomes a fish farmer as an adult but doesn't forget his experience in Bosnia. Then when Yugoslavia splits into different states and war breaks out he feels called to collect and bring aid into Bosnia. This is the beginning of the aid that eventually blossoms into Mary's Meals. The idea of Mary's Meals is to provide one meal a day for children in school in very poor and developing nations. A lot of these children would never be in school if it weren't for these meals; they would be working for their families or sick/dead. Mary's Meals provides a meal for children in school thereby reducing starvation and giving children a chance to get educated so they can break the cycle of poverty and become a source for positive change in their countries. It isn't just aid either; Mary's meals are cooked by volunteers in the community where the meals are served, the food is grown locally if possible. It is program designed to give means to the community, not just charity. It really is marvelous. And the way it is run; humble, costs kept down, faith based with all faiths accepted. I like Magnus as well; he seems like a man who lives what he professes. I like also that the book stays away from political rhetoric and religious rhetoric. That is pretty amazing considering the places he works are often torn apart by politics and religion. For Magnus and Mary's Meals it is all about the kids, feeding and educating the kids. The inspiration for Magnus to do good in the world is founded in his faith. Amazing and inspirational.Recommended. ...more

review: I enjoyed learning about the various Level 4 viruses like Lassa fever, Ebola, and other hemorrhagic fever viruses. It was fascinating learning what thI enjoyed learning about the various Level 4 viruses like Lassa fever, Ebola, and other hemorrhagic fever viruses. It was fascinating learning what the vectors for passing the diseases to human could be, such as ticks, mice urine, rats etc, how the diseases are spread in hospitals by the lack of proper barrier nursing procedures and the re-use of needles, and all the symptoms of these diseases and how they are treated in developing countries under crude conditions and how they are treated in first world countries like the United States and England. So those were the parts of the book that I liked and that made the book worth reading.What I didn't like was the switch between narrators and constant Sue and Joe and Joe and Sue and Sue and Joe...after they started working together in 1983. I didn't want to be involved in their personal lives and to start thinking about when their romance started and the reasons for their divorces etc. But the Sue and Joe and Joe and Sue...kept my mind there and without knowing what went on in Joe's marriage, besides his constant absence from home, I started feeling sorry for his first wife. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sweet and totally unrealistic what with breaking people out of jail and assaulting a sheriff.....well, whatever.It is the story of a young woman, 20 ySweet and totally unrealistic what with breaking people out of jail and assaulting a sheriff.....well, whatever.It is the story of a young woman, 20 years old, who is NQR. That stands for Not Quite Right. Gibby was in a car accident in which both her parents were killed and she was left brain damaged. That was three years ago. Now she lives with her grandfather and works in his cafe and goes fishing with him and picks up the egg delivery for the cafe. She also writes a newspaper that she researches herself and gets printed and distributed around town. When she finds the dead body of a prominent citizen on the beach she decides to keep this information to herself until she can publish her big story. She wants to make this amazing story so her mother in heaven will rest easy knowing Gibby is now QR again. Gibby has memory problems, half the time she can't remember that she even found a body. She has a friend named Billy who is a Vietnam Vet plagued with flashbacks, and is friends with a girl named Carol Lever who Gibby calls Clever. Gibby is often very insightful and witty for a brain damaged girl, she also has a problem with cussing and saying inappropriate things as a result of her brain damage. The things Gibby says and thinks are what make the book charming. I think what bothers me is that very serious subjects are brought up here: brain damage, infidelity, sexual assault, rape, incest, murder, corruption, PTSD, promiscuity, alcoholism and racism; but it is all written about in a glib and superficial way. It doesn't come off like the author doesn't care, on the contrary, but I was struck by dissonance.It is a sweet book and feel good book in some ways, with things eventually coming right in a totally unrealistic way. And therein lies the dissonance for me because life doesn't work that way....more

review: I am overwhelmingly disappointed. Sometimes "literature" leaves a lot to be desired. This book is about a couple of people who are like prime numbers,I am overwhelmingly disappointed. Sometimes "literature" leaves a lot to be desired. This book is about a couple of people who are like prime numbers, always close, but never actually in contact. I want more of a reality; nothing feels substantial here. It is all about absence: the absent twin, the uneaten food, the unspoken words, the missing touch, the unfulfilled love, the empty womb. I had such high hopes for this book as it is brilliant in its way, but I couldn't handle the non-ness of it which includes the lack of resolution. We can only guess at what might happen. I felt like Alice the anorexic; I read this book and it had as much substance as that lettuce she consumes as her only calories. The only part of this book I actually liked was when Alice photographs Viola's wedding. She acted like a person then and not a shadow. I actually feel physically sick from reading this book, my disappointment is that great."Mattia thought that he and Alice were like that, twin primes, alone and lost, close but not close enough to really touch each other."That quote is the book in a nutshell....more

author: Bohjalian, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was horrifying. It starts out almost normal and then it starts to unravel and by the end the author has dumped you into a whirlpool of madness. I sIt was horrifying. It starts out almost normal and then it starts to unravel and by the end the author has dumped you into a whirlpool of madness. I say it starts out "almost normal" but the story is scary from the beginning. One just doesn't realize how scary. As a reader I felt unease from the first pages, followed by confusion and a suspicion of the truth.The story starts out telling us about the attack on and near rape of a young woman as she bikes down a logging road. It has been seven years since that attack. Now the young woman works at a homeless shelter, she swims every morning, she has an older boyfriend with two young daughters and no interest in a long term commitment. One day at work she is given a box of photos, quite good photos, that were the property of a homeless man that the shelter had helped. The owner of the shelter thinks perhaps they can have a showing of the man's photos as a fundraiser and asks her young employee, who is interested in photography, if she can fix the damaged photos and print the rest from the negatives. Unfortunately there is a photo of a young woman on a bike on a logging road. So starts the search for who this man was and what he was doing with a picture that looks an awful lot like herself on her bike before the attack.The pictures in the book are quite good. How some good black and white photos taken, in real life, by a guy who became homeless, caused the author to come up with this story is a leap I can't quite make. It was a very imaginative leap, but it takes the reader down, down, down. Straight to hell on earth....more

review: Done perfectly for the genre, this story of a ghost writer, an ordinary woman, who becomes a ghost writer for an up and coming star. The star, a youngDone perfectly for the genre, this story of a ghost writer, an ordinary woman, who becomes a ghost writer for an up and coming star. The star, a young woman from a bad neighborhood and background, goes on a reality TV show and with a combination of charm and coarseness makes herself well known. She is named Scarlett and becomes known as Scarlett Harlot. Ghost writer Stephanie Harker is hired to write a book about Scarlett, making her seem more human and less trashy. In the process of writing the book the two women become friends and Stephanie is there for Scarlett through the birth of her son, the death of her husband and finally Scarlett's cancer. But who is Scarlett really? Things start to unravel when Scarlett's son is kidnapped from Stephanie's care. It seems the women have underestimated each other. The end is so creepy, horrifying really. Excellent, not a wasted word, not a moment of boredom. I am not ing this book as literature, for me it is pure entertainment. I had no trouble with aspects of the story that simply wouldn't be true in real life. The story is told through an interview of Stephanie Harker at the airport after the child is abducted. Of course a real interview wouldn't go on like that, but that didn't diminish my enjoyment of the story one bit. And the ending, it didn't have to be real; it managed extremely creepy and left you there. I thought it was a good ending....more
