title: Birdsong
author: Faulks, Sebastian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was afraid I would emotionally fall apart when I read this book but I was able to keep my distance for the most part; interested and involved but noI was afraid I would emotionally fall apart when I read this book but I was able to keep my distance for the most part; interested and involved but not torn up; angry at the terrible waste of lives, but I didn't cry for many hours as I did when I read All Quiet On the Western Front or saw the movie Ghandi. Truthfully I appreciated that I could keep some distance. I think the reason for this is that we are not immediately plunged into the war, we are instead in a home in a village in France where Stephan, a young Englishman in France for business, and Isabelle, the wife of the boss and mistress of the home in which he is staying, become involved in an intense adulterous relationship. I'm always a bit put off by that kind of thing so I was given some breathing space in the book and an easing into the war scenes. The book is always interesting, often heartbreaking. There are some strong parallels between what happens in the war years and what happens 60 years later when Stephan's granddaughter starts looking into her grandfather's life and experiences. Truly, fictional character that she was, I still wanted to hug her and thank her for caring, for looking into things, for carrying on. It is a powerful story of love, of friendship and of humanity. Recommended....more

So that is what happens in this book, the people avert their eyes from seeing futility and we are engaged in an unlikely world of life.This book is absolutely stunning, it is almost perfect, and so so sad. title: Nocturne: A life of Chopin
author: Jordan, Ruth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of many biographies about Chopin but the first one that I have read so I had no clear idea of who he was, all I knew was that he was a famThis is one of many biographies about Chopin but the first one that I have read so I had no clear idea of who he was, all I knew was that he was a famous classical musician. Obviously I don't listen to much classical music although I like the idea of becoming familiar with these works. So who was Chopin? He was born in Warsaw, Poland in 1810 to loving parents, father a French peasant (although by the time Chopin was born that was not generally known) and mother a Polish gentlewoman. Poland was regularly in political upheaval but Frederick Chopin had a mostly happy childhood, his father taught French at the lyceum to the sons of Polish gentry, he had 3 sisters to whom he was close, he had many friends and he showed musical promise by the time he was 6 years old. He composed a Polonaise in G minor at the age of 8 and become a Warsaw celebrity being invited to play in the drawing rooms of society hostesses and the palaces of the the Polish nobility. He gave his first public concert shortly after his 8th birthday. The family was exposed to tuberculosis, common then and incurable; his youngest sister Emily died from it at age 14. Chopin suffered ill health because of it, he was frail, but he lived into his late 30's before it killed him. In his personality he was reserved, loyal, indecisive, temperamental, creative, nervous, passionate about music and, just my opinion, somewhat effeminate. In this book there are some letters which are controversial, the author and others believe they are letters that he wrote to Countess Delphina Potocka, the Chopin Society believes them to be forgeries. After reading the book I am of the opinion that they are probably forgeries. They do not fit with his personality as otherwise characterized. In my opinion.But I am also of the opinion that although I can know some basics facts of his life I cannot even come close to a rudimentary understanding of who he was without listening to his music. His music was how he expressed his inner self. ...more

author: de Bernières, Louis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The story is fictional but much of this book, the true weight of the book, is Greek history, World War II and the Greek island of Cephallonia. WWII caThe story is fictional but much of this book, the true weight of the book, is Greek history, World War II and the Greek island of Cephallonia. WWII can be viewed from so many different angles and this is one view I had not yet seen. I was appalled, really, by the waste of life. I know it, we all know it, but it shown here in such a way that it is almost any agony, like when is it going to end??!! One could easily hate Mussolini so it is very enjoyable to see him lampooned here. Albanania, in winter? in war? So many young men, Italian and Greek, dying. For what? Mussolini's whim? And then the slaughter of all those Italian soldiers by the Germans who said they would accept surrender and then killed them all. I kept thinking, Amalek! Amelek! right there. And Eisenhower did what??!! WTH??!! And then the Greek Communists take over to destroy what was not destroyed during the war, they make war on their own. Misery upon misery. Insanity, the world is insane.The history is told through the story of a village doctor and his daughter Pelagia. When the Italians occupy the island a mandolin playing captain is billeted at their home. A love develops between the captain and Pelagia and this story is charming at times. What I don't understand is why the author made the ending as he did. It was both unrealistic and disappointing. I mean just so unfulfilling. Although the continuation of history, the linking of past and present was very good.I both liked and hated this book and it is occupying a big part of my heart at the moment....more

review: I liked this book very very much. It is set in the time of King Christian IV of Denmark in the 1630's when a young lutenist from England, Peter ClaireI liked this book very very much. It is set in the time of King Christian IV of Denmark in the 1630's when a young lutenist from England, Peter Claire, joins the King's orchestra. The setting follows the historical facts regarding the King's early life, his private marriage to Kirsten Munk, her adultry with a German officer, and the subsequent drama. I found the story delightful; it is oddball and magical, gothic, strange and lovely. The characters were fully believable to me, very three-dimensional, popping right out of their historical period as real people, which of course they were but the author is successful in her portrayal of them. My favorite  of this book from it's cover is this from Patrick Gale:"Tremain's achievement in Music and Silence is extraordinary...She whips up a narrative world (of) vast louring palaces, doomily dangerous women, crazed ambitions and, nestling miraculously at the foetid heart of all this, a tale of pure and courageous love."I especially like that "doomily dangerous women" description. But I would have called this a successful love story for three couples; each of these couples important and central in their own way to the story. Nothing sappy or unfinished here. This was a very satisfying historical fiction novel. Recommended....more

title: The Silent Duchess
author: Maraini, Dacia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ugh. Hard to tell what I hated; the book or Italy. Since the book is well-written and interesting in its way then I suppose it is Italy that I have suUgh. Hard to tell what I hated; the book or Italy. Since the book is well-written and interesting in its way then I suppose it is Italy that I have such a strong dislike for. The Inquisition, the "Great White Fathers", the burning of people at the stake - a vast public event with all the royalty and religious big-wigs in their ceremonial clothes, the castrati, the hypocrisy of the dual face of Italy - pleasure seeking and piety. And then there is the story itself of the duchess, her condition of being deaf and dumb, her forced marriage at the age of 12 or 13 to her uncle. OK, so the story is very interesting, especially in the beginning. It does move very quickly through the duchess's life; in one chapter she is a child, in the next she is a mother and it continues to move through her life in this way.She is an interesting person although I didn't always care for her or understand her. By the end of the book I had tired of the whole thing and found the last chapter or so incredibly tedious to read. Wasn't sure what the last few lines meant; did she or didn't she?The book was largely symbolic and feminist, and I knew that to a certain extent while reading it but that did not help me to enjoy it.I would have given this book a one except that some of the imagery was excellent....more

author: Behrens, Peter*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A very fine book but I have never ever read a happy book about Ireland and this is no exception. This book starts with Fergus and his family living asA very fine book but I have never ever read a happy book about Ireland and this is no exception. This book starts with Fergus and his family living as tenant farmers on a landlord's property. They are poor but the situation is manageable until the potato famine hits. It is very hard to read about such terrible suffering and the desperate measures that people will go to try to survive. To make matters worse, typhus is rampant, people are dying from "fever" all over Ireland. When Fergus loses his family there is no longer any reason to stay on the farm. He quits it and begins his journey that will eventually lead him to America. What makes this book so good is the lyrical writing which is gorgeously realistic. For example when Fergus climbs to the very top of the mast of the ship I am experiencing very real fear with racing heartbeat, sickly stomach and clammy hands and feet. That is how real the writing is. It is also studded with these little gems of insight. There are many in the book but I happened to mark this sentence, "The world, latent; a gun loaded with chance and mistakes." I appreciated that the author gave us a hopeful ending....more

It certainly did not seem quiet when I was reading, someone was always getting shot. On the other hand, silencers were often used on the guns. There were a lot of dead bodies in this book, at least a dozen. The premise of the book is that a woman who saw the face and knew the first name of a man she suspected of committing a crime is badly beaten, nearly killed but the killer is interrupted. She becomes understandably frightened and hires a PI to help her disappear. She is gone for six years but when new evidence shows up and her old boyfriend is arrested for her murder the PI goes searching for her to prove she is not dead. In the meantime the man she suspects of having commit a crime has hired professional killers to kill her. A trail of dead bodies are scattered throughout the rest of the book. There is a bit of black humor running through the book that saves it from being altogether banal....more

title: Hannah's Dream
author: Hammond, Diane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really liked it a lot but somewhere in the last 20 pages or so the theme song from Free Willy started playing in my head. Fortunately I like that soI really liked it a lot but somewhere in the last 20 pages or so the theme song from Free Willy started playing in my head. Fortunately I like that song. The book has a lot in common with Free Willy especially at the end where on page 311 we read this paragraph,"You been driving elephants for long?" Sam asked the driver?...."A few years," the driver said, resting a meaty forearm on the wheel. "Not just elephants, though I done'em all -- elephants, tigers, lions, giraffes. Walrus, one time; a killer whale one time, too. Big box of water sure made a mess when you stopped, slopping all over the place."Yeah, yeah, Free Willy!It makes sense that this book is like Free Willy, (except with an elephant) because the author actually worked on The Keiko Project. She says "From 1995 to 1998 I was lucky enough to work with an ailing killer whale named Keiko - the star of the movie Free Willy - and the staff that rehabilitated him."This book even has a counter-part to the boy star in Free Willy, you know kind of a slightly troubled (but basically good) kid about age 11 who doesn't have parents, and finds some purpose and happiness at the zoo. Then there is the kind of run down zoo, inadequate housing for the big animals, a gifted man of integrity who works with the animal in question, and the zoo management who just want to make money off the animal to support the zoo. Oh, it was Free Willy all over again! Fortunately I like that movie. The movie made me interested in killer whales, the book made me interested in elephants. I love the way Hannah wraps her trunk around her keeper's head in affection, the way she watches movies, eats Dunkin' Doughnuts, plays drums and paints pictures. Honestly I am very interested to find out what is going on in the real elephant world. As far as the rest of the book, it is slightly shallow, but it has a sense of humor, a lot of love and some really, really interesting characters, like Johnson Johnson, and some terrific improbabilities, like Truman and Winslow's pet pig. Oh, it is a book worth reading, it will probably make you smile. ...more

title: Still Water Runs Deep
author: Gutteridge, Marianne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book reads like grandma's memoirs, very Little House on the Prairie, with just a bit of domestic violence and murder thrown in, but that was onlyThis book reads like grandma's memoirs, very Little House on the Prairie, with just a bit of domestic violence and murder thrown in, but that was only one troubled family. Basically this book paints the life of an Iowan farmer in the early 1920's as a very happy life, a hard-working life sure, but lots of family and community harmony; the children don't cry, if anything is dirty or unorganized it is dealt with immediately in a sort of Mary Poppins spoonful of sugar kind of way. Well actually in this case a coffee and cookies kind of way. They drink coffee and eat cookies continually and never experience any bad health from this habit. The one troubled family is the only dark cloud in this Iowan community. And the murder part of it seems like an afterthought, perhaps the only part of the book that reads like fiction. The rest of the book read like a sanitized version of, as I said, Iowa 1922 rural farm. Our main character is a teacher, assigned her first job in a community away from home, and our story concerns her first 4 months living as a boarder with the Jensen family and teaching school.When you read the "About the author" you will see that she is the daughter of an Iowa school teacher. "She started a family history through nightly phone calls she had with her mother. Stillwater Runs Deep is the result of that research."I knew it was grandma's memoirs! ...more

title: Cross Country: Fifteen Years and 90,000 Miles on the Roads and Interstates of America with Lewis and Clark
author: Sullivan, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's see, what took longer; Robert Sullivan driving across the country from Oregon to NY City or me reading his book? It was me. Truthfully it wasn'tLet's see, what took longer; Robert Sullivan driving across the country from Oregon to NY City or me reading his book? It was me. Truthfully it wasn't always exciting to read. Reading about driving across the country probably has a lot in common with driving across the country; stretches of boredom; something to break boredom (in the case of this book that would mainly be the history of roads, driving and cross country trips in America starting with Lewis and Clark.) On the other hand, I could really relate. I love road trips myself; that anticipation and excitement to get going, the willingness to see what this trip will bring, how it will differ from plans and expectations, the happiness of sharing this with your children, the appreciation of the beauty of our country and our freedom to travel in it. Mr. Sullivan seemed kind of uptight at the beginning of the book, nervous, his jokes fell a little flat and sounded more like self-criticism than anything else. But he loosens up as he talks about history and he seems like a really nice guy when he talks about his family. His love of family and country come through loud and clear. I appreciated that he did a lot of research to write this book, I think he really wanted to teach his readers and I was interested in learning.Some of his philosophical thoughts near the end of the book:"On this bridge, in this daredevil-like moment of multilane over-the-river traffic, I can see that the modern American road is a common space where people share nothing. It is the thing that, while separating us, we all have in common""When I wonder about the future of the interstates, of these things that cross and bind and rush-hour America in to a stupor of convenience and aggravation, and when I think of what seems so unlikely to change, I think again of how quickly things came to be--of the generations of my parents who saw the birth of the interstates, of the generation of their parents, who saw the birth of the car, of the generation of their parents, who rode the first railroads." In the afterword the author actually relaxes and says some truly funny things.http://www.npr.org/templates/story/st... It is an interview with Robert Sullivan and his two kids. Their performance of a song they sing on the road is really good. ...more

title: At Swim, Two Boys
author: O'Neill, Jamie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think that I picked this up at the library sale without any idea of what it might be about except it had won an award and lots of praise. There is nI think that I picked this up at the library sale without any idea of what it might be about except it had won an award and lots of praise. There is no question that this book is written by someone who is very well educated and writes beautifully. The language was often dialect which got easier to read but which I often did not understand fully. Then there were the archaic words, the Latin words, the Erse words, the French words. I struggled to make sense of what he was saying and I was often looking things up on line. But I wasn't going to make a great study of it and that left me with an incomplete understanding.The subject matter was disagreeable in some ways; lots of homosexual man/boy relationships. I really, really did not want to hear it. Historical homosexuality also was not an area of interest to me, the Spartans in particular. The book is heavily about male homosexuality, whether between boys who are best friends or boys and men. It is also about war, the Easter uprising in particular, and Ireland's fractured relationship with the British. This actually was of interest to me but the story was so wrapped up in the other that it was hard to take one and leave the other.I did like a few of the characters; Jim and Gordie's father was my favorite. I also liked Doyler's mother. A few people asked me why I was reading this book if I disliked it. It is a good question and I can only say that I think it was because the author's intelligence was challenging and intriguing to me. There was beauty in his language and I wanted to experience that. The ending was sad, although unlike other readers I never even remotely felt the urge to cry. My overall feeling about the ending was a relief that I had finally finished this 562 page book. ...more

title: Shooting the Boh: A Woman's Voyage Down the Wildest River in Borneo
author: Johnston, Tracy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book in a way; it is so interesting and out of the ordinary. What we have here is a group of adventurers, mostly unaware of the real circI loved this book in a way; it is so interesting and out of the ordinary. What we have here is a group of adventurers, mostly unaware of the real circumstances of what they are getting into, who join a river rafting trip down the Boh River in Borneo. It is through the adventure company of Sobek and supposedly has been run or at least mapped before. It is billed as Class 3 white water (hahahahaha). Supposed to be a 3 day trip (a 3 hour tour, a 3 hour tour). Yes, it is a bit Gilligan Islandish, only with a lot more bugs and foot rot and impassable waterfalls. They are bedeviled by bees, sucked on by leeches, and covered by ants. They sleep on rocks in the rain, they get terrible foot rot, everything is mildewed. And of course they have near drowning experiences. It is also hot as h*ll because it is the rain forest. A great thing about this book is that she includes excerpts from earlier travelers to Borneo. They are fascinating. And I haven't even mentioned the natives yet; these are the people who were headhunting until, like the 1940's. I'm so very very very glad that I was not on this trip, but it was great reading about it.Only thing I didn't like is the author's discussion about menopause and getting older. Ho Hum. ...more

title: The Memory of Running
author: McLarty, Ron
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In some ways this book gave me the uber-creeps. Bethany's illness was really hard to read about, it seemed like demon possession to me and I don't eveIn some ways this book gave me the uber-creeps. Bethany's illness was really hard to read about, it seemed like demon possession to me and I don't even know if there are such things as demons. Since I was having trouble with her condition I googled the symptoms and think she would fit the def of catatonic schizophrenia. Just being able to put a medical name to it made me feel a little better. I think it was the dog incident and the bow wow call that sent me into a state of shivering dread. Also that she didn't need to use "the voice" to say the most awful things. So there is that aspect to the book.Then there is the redemption of Smithy Ide, Bethany's brother and the narrator of the book. He is a fat alcoholic in middle age but when his parents are killed in an accident and he finds a letter regarding Bethany, he gets on his bike and rides from Rhode Island to Los Angeles. Mostly eating bananas and drinking water he loses a lot of weight, as you might imagine. He also re-establishes his relationship with his next door neighbor Norma, a woman he has neglected for most of her life even though he is aware that she loves him. What I didn't understand is why at the end of the book he starts eating junk food again and gives away or loses all his biking gear. This was disturbing to me, but maybe it just meant that his quest was done and he was going to live a "normal" life now, not alcoholic and guilt driven, but not spartan either. In any case, his trip across the U.S. was interesting and made me want to ride a bike. Maybe a recumbant would work... Am I looking for redemption? ...more

title: Running with Scissors
author: Burroughs, Augusten*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, OK, Hmmmm.First of all, this thing it says on the back of the book "The harrowing, and best-selling account of an ordinary boy's survival under Well, OK, Hmmmm.First of all, this thing it says on the back of the book "The harrowing, and best-selling account of an ordinary boy's survival under the most extraordinary circumstances" where do they come up with that? Augusten is far from "ordinary" long before he joins the evil psychiatrist's wacko family. As a child he is boiling his spare change, polishing his jewelry, obsessively combing his hair (must be perfect!), and wrapping his dog in decorative aluminum foil. This is an ordinary boy??!! I think not. And having a mother who is starring in her own drama and a father who is an alcoholic does not explain all, no way. Augusten is also gay and mostly refuses to go to school. The only way he is ordinary is in that he trusts his parents, especially his mother, and goes along with whatever they are doing. He spends a lot of time with his mother in Dr. Finch's office and then is left with Dr. Finch's family while mother goes off to deal with herself. Mother is, of course, being well drugged by Dr. Finch. So is Augusten for that matter, along with everyone who lives in that house. So Augusten, despite his objections, is left, at 13 years old, to live with the doctor's family. They are disgusting and despicable. Augusten finds himself fitting in quite nicely, especially once he starts on his "love affair" with a 33 year old pedophile also living at Dr. Finch's. Augusten thinks he has won the lottery sex-wise, but he hates being told how much he is loved and how much he means to this guy, because on some level he does understand that he is being taken advantage of. Well maybe this is ordinary in a pedophile/child relationship, I don't know. I guess I shouldn't be blaming a 13 year old, he was pretty much stuck in the situation, but wow, he doesn't make himself a very sympathetic character here. This is a book about living without rules, and it is awful. Do psychiatrists ever wonder why their profession has a tarnished reputation and why a lot of people distrust psychiatrists? Points in this book's favor: it is hard to put down, the writing is good and the subject fascinating despite how ugly it is. Augusten also has a sense of humor, sees the irony in things and so makes the reader laugh. He also gives credit for the good that any of his characters do.The more I think about this book the more I question its veracity. I very much wonder why the portions of the book that deal with pedophilia sound more like they are written from the point of view of a pedophile, rather than that of a child. In any case, true or not true or partly true, it is creepy. ...more

title: Run
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoyed it, although I thought it lacked the depth that makes a truly good book. It was written in a way that could be adapted for screen and would I enjoyed it, although I thought it lacked the depth that makes a truly good book. It was written in a way that could be adapted for screen and would make a popular feel-good family movie.The strong points were characterization and description. Kenya and her running, Tip and his ichthyology, Teddy and his speeches; all very vivid, enough so that we can forgive the places where she shortcuts what might actually happen in real life and the reader can allow her that creative license without feeling that they are giving up too much.The author does use her book as a forum to discuss race; being black in a white family, in a white neighborhood, with money, being white or black in a mixed-race family, being black and poor, being poor and black and living in proximity to wealthy whites, being black, poor and without health insurance. But she doesn't do this in a negative way, more in thoughtful and gentle way, giving only the occasional sharper statement. She also discusses adoption and the feelings that brings into a family in regards to ownership and family ties; and what happens when parental attention and dreams are transferred from one child to another. This is all good, but not gone into really, just skimmed....more

title: Rabbit, Run        (Rabbit Angstrom, #1)
author: Updike, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess this book was pushing the edges of decency in 1960 for a mainstream book, although that couldn't have lasted for very long.My question is whatI guess this book was pushing the edges of decency in 1960 for a mainstream book, although that couldn't have lasted for very long.My question is what would Harry (nicknamed Rabbit) be diagnosed with today? ADHD almost certainly. He couldn't complete things, he jumped from one thing to another, his attention was all over the place --- unless he entered the zone, like he did when playing exceptional basketball. So Harry is always looking that zone again, for his teenage success. That ADHD behavior, that search for the zone is where he stays, only without the success. He also seemed to suffer some delusional thinking, beyond that magical thinking that children have. He was vastly immature, but that didn't explain it all. In some ways he wanted to do the right thing but he was so impatient and so self-centered that he would get in a snit and off he would go, either leaving physically or being unkind or both. His one area of success as an adult was with 2 year old Nelson (except for running off for 2 months), but when he was with Nelson his behavior became patient and mature, he wasn't a bad father.Now is wife Janice is a different story although she is also immature, child-like. She has very low self-esteem and is an alcoholic. She relies on other people, most of all her husband. Her family gets her through the first time he leaves, but the second time they are too late and tragedy happens. Her strength disappears when her husband walks out the door and she turns to alcohol. Why her husband couldn't see her weakness (he actually did know she was an alcoholic but not what that meant in consequences) and realize that he had to take care of her like a child - well I guess he was too much of strutting teenager (although he was 24) to see it. He just thought she was "dumb".This book reminded me of John Irving's writing, although I don't know if anyone else would think that. Maybe this book is meant to be a warning; kids don't have kids, your life is over once you have kids so don't expect it to be about you anymore. ...more

title: All the Drowned Sailors
author: Lech, Raymond B.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I just finished reading this book called All the Drowned Sailors about the sinking of the Indianapolis in the Philippine Sea in 1945. It was torpedoedI just finished reading this book called All the Drowned Sailors about the sinking of the Indianapolis in the Philippine Sea in 1945. It was torpedoed by a Japanese sub because the Admirals, Commodores, Officers and their staff didn't let the Captain know that there were Japanese subs in the area (which they did know), did not reroute his ship nor give it an escort. Then the men who survived the sinking were in the water for 4 days!!! Because no one was tracking the ship, they realized it was late to port but just thought it was late and didn't check to see where it was. 1,196 originally on board, 800 safely abandoned her and only 316 survived the 4 days in the sea. The worst of it was though that the captain got blamed by the commodores and admirals to cover all their idiotic mistakes. They court-martialed the captain of the Indianapolis (who did everything right under the circumstances and showed bravery and good leadership) and brought the captain of the Japanese sub to the US to testify against him!!!!!!! Gave that Japanese captain $100 to buy gifts for his wife and children while he was in the US. There was nothing to testify about by the way. It was a complete travesty of justice. I'm really disgusted with the US Navy at the moment.As the words on the cover of this book say succinctly:"The cover-up of America's greatest wartime disaster at sea, the sinking of the Indianapolis with the loss of 880 lives because of the incompetence of admirals, officers, and gentlemen." ...more

title: Driving with Dead People
author: Holloway, Monica
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The author has a great voice, she really is funny; but the story is just so grim! Crazy-making grim, brain-rattling grim.Monica grows up in this familThe author has a great voice, she really is funny; but the story is just so grim! Crazy-making grim, brain-rattling grim.Monica grows up in this family with a violent father who loves to humiliate his children. Obviously something is wrong with the man, probably his own rotten childhood. He is also quite a character, keeping a movie camera in the car so he can film things like car accidents and tornadoes. Monica develops a fascination with death when a young girl in her community dies. Then she becomes friends with the girl whose father owns the mortuary and the two of them do things like play in the coffins. But something is wrong with Monica too, despite how funny she is and how successful she is. Something is wrong with all of her siblings as well. Her Mom is weirdly self-absorbed; first in the image of the family and later with her boyfriend. She ignores anything that does not fit the image and the life she wants to have. Basically she deserts Monica when she is in her teens leaving her living alone in the house with no money for food and other necessities. All around it is bad, but then it gets worse when her older sister begins remembering childhood sexual abuse. It would almost sound fanciful except I have seen this. An adult who is likely guilty of pedophilia and incest, children who accuse him but by then they are their own messed up selves and who believes these young adults who are addicts, who habitually lie, who can be violent, who are in the spotlight of the police and under the care of psychiatrists? Mr. Pedophilia looks like an upstanding citizen. Before you know it the next generation of little children are under scrutiny of CPS as likely victims of sexual abuse by guess who? The previous victim of the pedophile. And the strangest thing? The family denies and protects the pedophile. If I didn't see this denial with my own eyes I simply wouldn't believe it. Try talking to a family in denial and you will get silent disapproval as if you are the one doing wrong by daring to accuse or even ask questions about this person. And everyone continues to love this person because he is the father, grandfather, brother or whatever. It is so strange, but knowing this made Monica's story something that made sense to me. I wish it didn't make sense to me. A very good and terrible read. btw, just like most memoirs there are parts that do not ring true. I don't know whether this is faulty memory or just the amazing human ability to reconcile completely contradictory information as if it is all linear and makes total sense. Or could be just for the sake of writing a good page-turning story. ...more

review: A Commissario Guido Brunetti Mystery, #16 in the series.A less complex and bitter book than some of her previous ones, although, true to form, she doeA Commissario Guido Brunetti Mystery, #16 in the series.A less complex and bitter book than some of her previous ones, although, true to form, she does make critical remarks about Americans and tourists. I did enjoy this "mystery" as she sticks to the story, doesn't try to bring in all of Italy's social problems, just a few. She often contends with social ills in her stories and that makes them interesting to a point; she doesn't overdo it here, although she possibly under-did it and the ending is, I don't know, not likely, not real.A young couple's home is raided by the Carabinieri and their baby taken away. As the story unfolds we see that the couple is being accused of having adopted the baby illegally. Investigation follows, both by the Carabinieri in a formal manner, and by the Commissario in a can't leave this situation alone, something is fishy kind of way. The ending feels almost tacked on as the book is really about infertile couples and the "baby market", not about a crime or a mystery. I am always left with a mildly unpleasant feeling after reading her books. I think it is a combination of the writing style which, while interesting, is cynical and somewhat depressing; and her anti-American and anti-tourists statements. ...more

title: Guests of the Sheik: An Ethnography of an Iraqi Village
author: Fernea, Elizabeth Warnock
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: From the back cover of the book:"A delightful, extremely well-written, and vastly informative ethnographic study. Guests of the Sheik is an account ofFrom the back cover of the book:"A delightful, extremely well-written, and vastly informative ethnographic study. Guests of the Sheik is an account of the author's two-year stay in the tiny rural village of El Nahra in southern Iraq."Can you imagine? It is 1957 and Elizabeth (known as Beeja in the village) and her husband are newlyweds, Americans, and Bob is doing anthropology studies. They move to a small mud hut, Elizabeth dons the abayah, and they both start the struggle of understanding the language, fitting in, making friends and getting used to the practicalities of their new lives. What is interesting of course is that when you get down to it people are people, adapted to their physical and social environments, acting as they have been taught.Sadly I don't think the differences between the middle east and the west are any less now than they have ever been. The tolerance is less. Understanding is pretty absent.From page 313:"How many years would it take, I wondered, before the two worlds began to understand each other's attitudes towards women? For the West, too, had a blind spot in the area. I could tell my friends in America again and again that the veiling and seclusion of Eastern women did not mean necessarily that they were forced against their will to live lives of submission and near-serfdom. I could tell Haji again and again that the low-cut gowns and brandished freedom of Western women did not necessarily mean that these women were promiscuous and cared nothing for home and family. Neither would have understood, for each group, in its turn, was bound by custom and background to misinterpret appearances in its own way."I will say that there were a few times in reading this book that I wondered if she was being absolutely truthful, but I guess truth is subjective and with 2 years written into 331 pages a lot gets left out....more

title: Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them
author: Franken, Al
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Mocking Fox News, Al Franken calls this book "A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right", which it is not but I understand why he calls it that. He may beMocking Fox News, Al Franken calls this book "A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right", which it is not but I understand why he calls it that. He may be right about a lot (maybe most or possibly even all) of what he writes about the Right, but fair and balanced it is not. He praises Clinton throughout the book and never mentions that Clinton himself was a liar. I am not actually at all convinced that one can be a politician and not be a liar. One has to do a certain amount of saying and doing what will please one's supporters. I myself am a moderate Democrat living in a houseful of men who are "Right". Avoiding discussions of politics is a good idea. What we all agree on in my house is Israel's right to exist and policies and people that protect and support Israel. Al Franken agrees with this also. He disagrees with aligning ourselves with the religious Christian Right. I agree with his disagreement on this. Al Franken is an entertainer first, jokes are his stock in trade. So he jokes throughout this serious book; the subject matter is serious no matter how many jokes are made. The jokes just make it more palatable and keeps people reading and listening. The people he particularly criticizes are Ann Coulter, Bill O'Reilly, Sean Hannity, Rush Limbaugh and "the Bushies" (George W. Bush (Dubya) and his administration. That is not a complete list of course. Much of that criticism was probably well earned. My favorite chapter of the book was Operation Chickenhawk: Episode One, which is a totally made up spoof in which Bush, Cheney, O'Reilly, Limbaugh, Ashcroft, Thomas and some others are in the Vietnam War. Oh, and the part where Al meets Barbara Bush. A lot of this book is laugh out funny. My least favorite part is where Al Franken and one of his protege go to Bob Jones University and pretend that they are not who they are.But Al Franken says he doesn't feel very good about having done that.I know this is cynical, but I don't trust either the Left or the Right. I aim for a balance in office so that hopefully they will deadlock and cancel each other out so that nothing too destructive takes place. ...more

Her sisters are around as well, angry at her for living and for having a home again. Through the years of her childbearing and married life the ghosts keep up their campaign of cursing her and crying. title: The Yiddish Policemen's Union
author: Chabon, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Funny, intelligent, eccentric; and terribly disrespectful and offensive.I'm assuming Michael Chabon is Jewish, perhaps even received a Jewish educatioFunny, intelligent, eccentric; and terribly disrespectful and offensive.I'm assuming Michael Chabon is Jewish, perhaps even received a Jewish education somewhere along the line (although all I saw in the autobiographical data on him was that he was raised (culturally) on a "hearty diet of crap", that his parents are divorced and that his mother smoked marijuana (in 1977 - like most young adults at that time). Anyway, as someone who respects, even reveres, the Lubavitcher Rebbe and his predecessors, I was appalled. On the other hand, well it was a pretty well-written story. The reason I think Michael Chabon is Jewish is not the extent of his knowledge, which is extensive as I just hinted at with the word extent. It is because of the love/hate relationship he has going on here. He mocks religious Judaism, calls the black hatters a bunch of criminals even to the extent of trying to scam G-d (read his diatribe on the eruv, he really has something against the eruv - page 110 - but when he starts talking about the handball court that got built where the fake doorway was he had me laughing). So there is all that sarcasm and nearly vicious offensiveness, but then there is the guy clinging to his people, his culture; Yid this and Yid that. If he doesn't love the Jewish people and count himself among them, I would be surprised. He (his characters) think it is all BS and can't let go. So the story is set in Sitka Alaska, which has been the temporary Jewish territory since 1948 when the Jews (fictionally) failed in holding on to Israel. So they live on borrowed land on borrowed time among an Indian population that doesn't like them much. Our Detective Landsman, a child of survivors, son of an avid and unhappy chess player, is living in a dump of a hotel in an alcoholic haze. A body is found in one of the rooms, a junkie shot in the back of the head. A chess board is set up in the room, mid-game, and it appears that the junkie uses a tefillin strap to tie off. Detective Landsman and his Jewish/Indian cousin Berko start to investigate. Detective Landsman's ex-wife Bina is his boss and she black flags the case (not active). Of course he investigates anyway. This brings him to Verbover Island and the Verbover Rebbe. And on it goes. This book is almost painful with love for the Jewish people despite all the mocking. ...more

title: Path of the Just: Mesillas Yesharim, Compact
author: Luzzatto, Moshe Chayim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An excellent book, well laid out, so clear and understandable although the subject is very serious. As I understand it this is a famous book of mussarAn excellent book, well laid out, so clear and understandable although the subject is very serious. As I understand it this is a famous book of mussar, Mesillat Yesharim. He lays the book out in the stages necessary to attain closeness with our Creator. "These stages are: Watchfulness, Zeal, Cleanliness, Separation, Purity, Saintliness, Humility, Fear of Sin and Holiness."These are my notes in brief:Watchfulness (depart from evil)Zeal (do good) (the positive commandments)Cleanliness (Vanquish evil inclination) (negative commandments)--------these things lead to righteousness-----------Separation (Be holy, separate yourselves) (negative commandments)Purity (Create in my G-d a pure heart) (positive commandments)Saintliness (comprehensive performance of all the mitzvot) (positive commandments) (The Torah begins and ends with lovingkindness)Humility: "The essence of humility is in a person's not attachings importance to himself for any reason whatsoever. His company is pleasant, he gives pleasure to his fellowman. He is perforce never aroused to anger and to controversy. He does everything quietly and calmly. Happy are those who have been privileged to attain this trait.""Pride is most prevalent among the more ignorant.""Another deterrent to humility is keeping company with or being served by flatterers."Fear of Sin (negative commandments)(Know what is above you: a seeing eye, a listening ear and a book in which all of your deeds are inscribed.)Holiness (positive commandments) (But first, he must have attained all of the noble traits previously mentioned) ...more

For a really really stupid, insane reason.So that is basically the story, Nestor gets locked in the freezer, someone is laughing on the other side of the door. Everyone who thinks Nestor knows a secret about them is a possible suspect. They are all quite grateful when he is dead. He has one friend who is sad he is gone, but even that one dismisses the death after a moment and goes on, blindly and blithely. The cockroach is symbolic; for gossip, for "indiscretions", for ugliness in general perhaps.This book was translated from Spanish. It may be a cultural divide, my failure to enjoy this book. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The main character, Hattie, who is supposed to be a grown-up (she is the aunt of the 15 and 11 year old kids in this book), seems to be stuck in a teeThe main character, Hattie, who is supposed to be a grown-up (she is the aunt of the 15 and 11 year old kids in this book), seems to be stuck in a teen-age time warp. She acts barely older than the kids; smoking pot with the 15 year old and letting him drive without a license, letting the 11 year old go for days without a bath or change of clothes. The story basically goes like this: These two kids have a mentally ill mother, unable to function. The aunt comes back from Paris where her boyfriend has just dumped her, ostensibly to go to an ashram in India. She sees that the mother gets admitted to the psych ward, takes over with the kids, and now what? She decides to take them on a road trip from Canada to somewhere in the U.S. to look for their father.Hattie thinks a lot, remembering what her sister was like growing up and basically how did each character get from birth to this condition, time and place that they are currently in. The ending seemed kind of fairy-tale, wishful thinking like. If you have read that Dave Eggers book, A Staggering Work of Incredible Genius (or something like that), this book is a bit like that. Someone too young and immature is stuck into the parental role of younger family members, muddles their way through and somehow makes it work. ...more

No revelation in the ending, just a sad remembrance, a sad question.The story is about a man, remembering when he was a boy and in particular the summer he was 15. title: One-Eyed Cat
author: Fox, Paula
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Set in rural New York, some time ago (the family car is a Packard), this is a story of a boy, 11 I think he is, facing a crisis. He receives an air guSet in rural New York, some time ago (the family car is a Packard), this is a story of a boy, 11 I think he is, facing a crisis. He receives an air gun as a BD present and his father thinks he is too young for it. The gun is stored in the attic but our boy, Ned, can't leave it alone. He sneaks it out one night and shoots at a shadow. Later, when a one-eyed cat shows up at his neighbor's house, he becomes sure that this is the shadow he shot at. He is filled with guilt and is sure that if anybody finds out they will think he is a terrible person. He attempts to care for the cat, but he also becomes proficient at telling lies and half truths to hide his feelings. The book is written in a very pleasant way, a quiet voice, and contains a lot more than I just put in that short paragraph. I think this book is one that would often be chosen for school libraries as it has moral lessons but is not preachy. Kids and adults alike can read this and enjoy it. Although my 10 year old, an avid reader, has no interest in it....more

title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think there are 3 things about this story that work to make it the classic that it is:AtmosphereNostalgiaThe personalities of Holmes and Watson and I think there are 3 things about this story that work to make it the classic that it is:AtmosphereNostalgiaThe personalities of Holmes and Watson and the relationship between them.The book is not gruesome but I experienced a dread and nervousness that I don't with most detective fiction. This is the atmosphere I am talking about: the moors, the gloom, the ancient stone buildings, the isolation, the baying of the hound, candles as a light source etc.Old England, I've never been to England but my idea of old England is very much influenced by books. The flat on Baker Street, the foul weather outside, the rooms filled with pipe smoke, the sounds of horses hooves on cobblestones, the roll of the wheels and creak of carriages. How much of this comes straight out of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's books? And feels familiar and loved.The characters: Holmes the arrogant, think outside the box, eccentric brainiac. Watson the solid, stodgy, feet on the ground, practical man. It works.I have seen the same technique used by Ruth Rendell in her Inspector Wexford series. It is more modern of course but I think a lot of the reason the series is as successful as it is is that she has mastered the atmosphere, the nostalgia (even now for what is rapidly changing) and the characters.The Hound of the Baskervilles, in less talented hands, would have been just a story, pretty good but nothing exceptional. Written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, it is indeed exceptional and memorable.Only one complaint; too much talking between Holmes and Watson to explain the plot. I actually think that this is supposed to be part of the charm, and it is somewhat charming, but those parts could be slightly boring....more
